commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

This change fixes `requirements-check` Zuul job.

Change-Id: I9c3dff8c0a87d3bad327f83770f8a6f8484abac6
Closes-Bug: #1831410

commit_message:
Change set variable in openstack helm gate job

The volume variables is changed in mariadb chart.

It affects openstack helm gating job of mariadb, so we need to
change varible to
volume.use_local_path_for_single_pod_cluster.enabled.

Enable the local host path for mariadb data so if the container
is restarted during the gate jobs it can recover successfully.

Story: 2004702
Task: 33462
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/661955

Change-Id: Ib55779ddcbe7033da1900f5cd21de46543392d11

[{'created': '2019-06-03 16:04:30.000000000', 'message': 'Create separate users for helm test

Currently each service uses the same name for their helm test user,
"test". While this works when services are ran sequentially, when
multiple services are deployed and tested at the same time, it can
lead to a race condition where one service deletes the user before
the other is done testing, causing a failure.

This change makes it so that each service defines its own test user
in the form of [service]-test.

Change-Id: Idd7ad3bef78a039f23fb0dd79391e3588e94b73c

commit_message:
Create separate users for helm test

Currently each service uses the same name for their helm test user,
"test". While this works when services are ran sequentially, when
multiple services are deployed and tested at the same time, it can
lead to a race condition where one service deletes the user before
the other is done testing, causing a failure.

This change makes it so that each service defines its own test user
in the form of [service]-test.

Change-Id: Idd7ad3bef78a039f23fb0dd79391e3588e94b73c

commit_message:
Ranger: Add pod/container security context

This updates the Ranger chart to include the pod
security context on the pod template

when I set to true It is going into crashloopbackoff

Change-Id: I00304483de5109e75860bde826ed18370610e286

commit_message:
Adds Qinling Ansible role

Qinling is an OpenStack project to provide "Function as a Service".
This project aims to provide a platform to support serverless functions.

Change-Id: I239a0130f8c8b061b531dab530d65172b0914d7c
Implements: blueprint ansible-qinling-support
Story: 2005760
Task: 33468

subject: Propagate vendor_data from nova-cloud-controller
messages:
[{'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-07 19:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-08 16:38:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

A few points;

I don't think we should support this beyond what it has been requested for i.e. you have it going back to icehouse but imho lets start with Queens and if anyone needs it for earlier releases we can extend later.

Second, as of rocky metadata is moved to nova-cloud-controller. This unfortunately means that the same config opts exist on both neutron-gateway and nova-cloud-controller but I would like to see them only exist in one place so if we could somehow rely on them coming from nova-cc for all scenarios that would be great - gateway and compute are both able to consume these settings via their relation to nova-cloud-controller.

You mentioned earlier that when using dvr-snat you see metadata served from nova-compute but i think that might still be querying the metadata api on the nova-cc so need to dbl check since if true then nova-cc should be enough."}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-10 18:45:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-10 18:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-13 16:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

Looks good on the whole but got a few things that need fixing. Do we really need to implement this going back as far as Mitaka though? Would Queens not suffice?'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-13 16:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-13 19:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2424, 'date': '2019-05-14 13:57:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-14 14:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1 Workflow-1

(2 comments)

WIP'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-17 15:43:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

This lgtm on the whole. One small nit about catching json exception and also, due to the fact that this code is being coordinated across 3 charms now I reckon it would be a good idea to get at least one functional/amulet test in there to prove it works as expected for all the intended releases.'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Following discussion with Rodrigo, it makes sense to have the functional tests in the nova-cloud-controller charm since that is the point from the which config is set and propagated. Also the json is validated in the charmhelpers base context class so it should not be possible for an  invalid json value to reach this charm via the relation.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-30 08:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-30 12:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-05-30 13:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

[{'created': '2019-05-07 19:43:10.000000000', 'message': "Allow vendor_data to be set on nova-compute

When using DVR and L3HA neutron deployment options,
Nova API Metadata requests are served from compute nodes,
instead of from neutron-gateway nodes.

Adding 'vendor-data' and 'vendor-data-url' config options
allows the nova-compute node to have its Nova API Metadata
configured to provide the vendor data appropriately.

Change-Id: I0c79e1bfac9fbe7009a7e862ad010cfa2de8cfda
Closes-bug: #1777714

commit_message:
Propagate vendor_data from nova-cloud-controller

When using DVR and L3HA neutron deployment options,
Nova API Metadata requests are served from compute nodes,
instead of from neutron-gateway nodes.

This change allows nova-compute to receive vendor_data
configuration values from nova-cloud-controller charm
relation and write to nova-compute's nova.conf
appropriately.

This will be effictive for Queens and later OpenStack
releases.

Synced charm-helpers in order to import new context
for writing the vendor_data.json file.

Change-Id: I0c79e1bfac9fbe7009a7e862ad010cfa2de8cfda
Closes-Bug: #1777714

commit_message:
Remove remaining vestiges of fake_libvirt_utils from unit tests.

A final cleanup of the libvirt driver testing to not use
fake_libvirt_utils.

Change-Id: If11d6df99a6774b783f77a18f2f00d261534b208

commit_message:
Update cirros image to 0.4.0

In DevStack CI, cirros-0.4.0 is already used and older cirros
images has issue and is causing flaky issues while running
network basic ops tests.

Updating the cirros image to 0.4.0 fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I60ec95632b4ec7fe0b7927992d025d82dd0690f3
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove readonly rootfs Elasticsearch

This removes ReadonlyRootfs from
Elasticsearch data pods as this is
required in order for the data pods
to recover from outages

Change-Id: I603d3a25b6580eab20e2b20e1b1cd0cf740c7ab2

commit_message:
Add support for ceilometer custom pipeline.yaml

This file can be modified to adjust polling intervals or other configurations.
We can add a custom 'pipeline.yaml' file to override it.

Change-Id: I325523edc4f7e37db55a2e21fe52e76138e6d114
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Use the default policy.json for Qinling

To avoid complexity and possible issue during the Qinling usage
we should build the Qinling Docker images with the policy.json file.

The reason why is because Qinling doesn't have default policies.

Change-Id: I13f64fcbfb3150efcb94af267f463eaddb11621d
Closes-Bug: #1830900
Implements: blueprint qinling-support

commit_message:
Set Content-Type header explictly for SessionClient

SessionClient is subclassed from keystoneauth LegacyJsonAdapter.
LegacyJsonAdapter does not set the Content-Type explicitly
and results in decodeing issues in some cases.

Change-Id: Idf23022b394607c332490331fc4b216de6ff1313
Story: 2005237
Task: 30027
(cherry picked from commit bd33e310e09339a21097c66d4022538f6bcbad2f)

commit_message:
Add upper constraints

py27 is currently broken due to a Sphinx failure that is resolved if you
properly include the upper constraints.

Change-Id: I4bcafb92bd307fe469bcab4db760d4245ceecb76
(cherry picked from commit 98368f114f9a96c7dbb1284c82042362ea26fc50)

Implements: blueprint support-extra-volumes
'}]
commit_message:
Make kolla-ansible support extra volumes

When integrating 3rd party component into openstack with kolla-ansible,
maybe have to mount some extra volumes to container.

Change-Id: I69108209320edad4c4ffa37dabadff62d7340939
Implements: blueprint support-extra-volumes

commit_message:
Add IPV6 support for SolidFire MVIP

The upcoming release of SolidFire will include IPV6 support
for the MVIP (san_ip).  This patch simply adds a check for
IPV6 formatted addresses being specified in the cinder.conf
and makes the minor formatting changes needed to make it
work with the requests library.

Change-Id: Icd89fda46860b241592f95b6a457ba8e52b8db00

commit_message:
Add support for ceilometer custom event yaml

* event_definitions.yaml:
  This file provides a standard set of events and corresponding traits
that may be of interest.

* event_pipeline.yaml:
  This file can be modified to adjust which notifications to capture and
where to publish the events.

Change-Id: I9c1698e07b65102af9b3ee448ad07f8fa6428b74
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

The instance.flavor is lazy-loaded currently in the resize method
in nova/compute/api.py.

Set expected_attrs=['flavor'] at the common.get_instance
in the _migrate method
in nova/api/openstack/compute/migrate_server.py
to avid lazy-loading instance.flavor.

Change-Id: Iba3b7c3e027ec78395a102c1fed46fa7a2ffa7be
Closes-Bug: #1829877
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid lazy-loading instance.flavor in cold migration

The instance.flavor is lazy-loaded currently in the resize method
in nova/compute/api.py.

Set expected_attrs=['flavor'] at the common.get_instance
in the _migrate method
in nova/api/openstack/compute/migrate_server.py
to avid lazy-loading instance.flavor.

Change-Id: Iba3b7c3e027ec78395a102c1fed46fa7a2ffa7be
Closes-Bug: #1829877

commit_message:
Enable kolla-ansible to use a custom metrics files with Cloudkitty

Cloudkitty has a default (built-in the container) metrics.yml file
 in the /etc/cloudkitty/metrics.yml files. We would like to be able
 to overwrite/customize these metrics configurations via kolla-ansible.
 Cloudkitty is able to use a custom metric file via "metrics_conf".
 Therefore, we are enabling this configuration via Kolla-ansible.

Change-Id: Id9019298482c040be05f540e71dacfdf0bd77469
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 20:08:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fluentd: Update configuration defaults and overrides

This updates the default fluentd configuration to include
recommended settings for preventing the elasticsearch plugin from
reloading the connection after 10000 requests (default for the
ruby gem). This also updates the configuration overrides for the
fluentd-daemonset deployment to provide input parity with the
default fluentbit configuration by adding inputs for the docker
and kubelet systemd units, inputs for ceph, libvirt, kernel logs,
and auth logs on the host.  Finally, this updates the fluentd
template to include environment variables for the host name and
the fluentd pod name so they can be added to logged events through
fluentd filter plugins

Change-Id: I21f7a89a325c44f8b058ff01a20191bea1a210b4
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Fluentd: Update configuration defaults and overrides

This updates the default fluentd configuration to include
recommended settings for preventing the elasticsearch plugin from
reloading the connection after 10000 requests (default for the
ruby gem). This also updates the configuration overrides for the
fluentd-daemonset deployment to provide input parity with the
default fluentbit configuration by adding inputs for the docker
and kubelet systemd units, inputs for ceph, libvirt, kernel logs,
and auth logs on the host.  Finally, this updates the fluentd
template to include environment variables for the host name and
the fluentd pod name so they can be added to logged events through
fluentd filter plugins

Change-Id: I21f7a89a325c44f8b058ff01a20191bea1a210b4
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Elasticsearch: Update cluster-wait job script

This updates the cluster-wait job script to include a sleep for
when no nodes of a given type are detected.  This check was
previously executed only when a node count of (0 < x < expected)
was detected.  This update reduces the number of queries executed
against the Elasticsearch http endpoint

Change-Id: I15cb39250a5ab9a7f6df0d62c35289a55e109dbd
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Add periodic building

We do not have periodics for the image building.

This is a problem, as people will only see failures at build
time/patch time, and not over time.
Adding periodics makes it possible to see if any external
factor breaks us.

Change-Id: I732eaa546985f34a2f394b1049879d7fd0a3cb8a

subject: Add exclude-groups option to config validator
messages: [{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-03-26 20:00:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-04-02 09:33:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2019-06-03 15:38:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-26 20:00:15.000000000', 'message': "Add exclude-groups option to config validator

When dynamic groups are used, the sample config data may not know
about those group names. As a result, validation of such files will
always fail. This makes it hard to automate config checks since the
output would need to be inspected manually to verify that the missing
options are all from the dynamic group.

Ideally, we would provide some way to map sample config groups to
the dynamic group name used in the actual config, but that would be
more complicated and still might not work in every case if a project
doesn't include sample sections for a dynamic group (although they
_should_ be doing so).

Allowing certain group names to be excluded from validation lets
us to solve this problem in a simple way and maintain validation of
99%[0] of the config options and enables the validation to be scripted
since it won't need manual verification of the error output.

Change-Id: I352fd48f86ecb876fe26a5e50e9a2633af1fff3d
0: citation needed ;-)
"}]
commit_message:
Add exclude-groups option to config validator

When dynamic groups are used, the sample config data may not know
about those group names. As a result, validation of such files will
always fail. This makes it hard to automate config checks since the
output would need to be inspected manually to verify that the missing
options are all from the dynamic group.

Ideally, we would provide some way to map sample config groups to
the dynamic group name used in the actual config, but that would be
more complicated and still might not work in every case if a project
doesn't include sample sections for a dynamic group (although they
_should_ be doing so).

Allowing certain group names to be excluded from validation lets
us to solve this problem in a simple way and maintain validation of
99%[0] of the config options and enables the validation to be scripted
since it won't need manual verification of the error output.

Change-Id: I352fd48f86ecb876fe26a5e50e9a2633af1fff3d
0: citation needed ;-)

commit_message:
Consider default_schedule_zone = None as None Type

When None is provided as value for default_schedule_zone in
nova.conf. The value None comes as a sting rather None Type
value from the Oslo Config. Nova registers default_schedule_zone
as a string option. Oslo Config does not consider None as python
keyword and it consider as string.

Change-Id: Ifed6e67d6db17dbafbd994fe26e813b5a1073f3a
Closes-Bug: #1730918

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 14:26:26.000000000', 'message': "[ironic] Don't remove instance info twice in destroy

During teardown, at the end of the ironic virt driver's destroy method,
we call _cleanup_deploy, which since
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/563722/ removes instance_info from the
ironic node. Given that we're destroying the node, the instance_info
will have been cleared from the node anyway, so we don't need to do
this.

Further, it can cause tear down to fail if automated cleaning is
enabled in ironic. This happens because ironic prevents updates to nodes
that are undergoing a state transition, as is the case during cleaning.
The virt driver will retry this request by default every 2 seconds with
60 attempts. Typically this is not long enough for cleaning to complete,
so tear down fails with the following error:

  Conflict: Node a00696d5-32ba-475e-9528-59bf11cffea6 can not be updated
  while a state transition is in progress. (HTTP 409)

This change skips the instance info update in _cleanup_deploy in the
case of tear down.

Change-Id: Iea337f73c231db2cb9d9f639b92475daaede6793
Closes-Bug: #1815799
(cherry picked from commit 060e42b7fd185bf3b827b7aa5c9ab6131f6a21d7)
"}]
commit_message:
[ironic] Don't remove instance info twice in destroy

During teardown, at the end of the ironic virt driver's destroy method,
we call _cleanup_deploy, which since
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/563722/ removes instance_info from the
ironic node. Given that we're destroying the node, the instance_info
will have been cleared from the node anyway, so we don't need to do
this.

Further, it can cause tear down to fail if automated cleaning is
enabled in ironic. This happens because ironic prevents updates to nodes
that are undergoing a state transition, as is the case during cleaning.
The virt driver will retry this request by default every 2 seconds with
60 attempts. Typically this is not long enough for cleaning to complete,
so tear down fails with the following error:

  Conflict: Node a00696d5-32ba-475e-9528-59bf11cffea6 can not be updated
  while a state transition is in progress. (HTTP 409)

This change skips the instance info update in _cleanup_deploy in the
case of tear down.

Change-Id: Iea337f73c231db2cb9d9f639b92475daaede6793
Closes-Bug: #1815799
(cherry picked from commit 060e42b7fd185bf3b827b7aa5c9ab6131f6a21d7)

commit_message:
Release 0.13.0 of os-traits

This version cleans up and extends the collection of cpu traits
for x86 architectures and improves documentation to more
accurately explain the lifecycle of a trait.

Change-Id: Ib9aa0dc28b901cd7941a696d0093cb0b10ce4522

commit_message:
Custom projects in owners skips default legacy

When supplying -p/--projects to the owners script for a custom
projects list, assume this means not to apply the default legacy
projects list. If -l/--legacy is also supplied, the indicated custom
legacy projects are still incorporated into the results.

Change-Id: I383317c8fdac3f6d8cfa2972326ff9fb9f64ab39

(1 comment)

noted a nit, but also wanted to respond to dmitry:

The benefit of these sorts of things isn't so much for the individual contribution, but in resolving decision making process when multiple contributors or contributors and some authority (e.g., their management) is involved. Having this stuff written down means that document acts an authority without all the hairiness of humans stating their opinions.

In the "we hold these truths..." sense.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-01-08 15:13:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sure, sure, I don't mind merging it when it's cleaned up a bit. I wonder if the governance repo is a better place for it though."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-01-08 22:06:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Sure, sure, I don't mind merging it when it's cleaned up a bit. I
 > wonder if the governance repo is a better place for it though.

I'm -1 to putting it in the governance repository. These are things up to each individual project, and adding governance review process overhead means that a project can't update it easily or on their own. It requires external actions."}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-01-16 16:05:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(5 comments)

Some nits inline.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-01-16 23:43:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Thanks Julia for making a great start on this very valuable initiative.

I wonder if it would also be helpful, especially for new developers, to describe the things that Ironic is already doing well to implement the vision? e.g. the design goals that Ironic contributes to are Basic Physical Data Center Management and (in the sense that it provides an abstraction over various vendors' BMCs) Hardware Virtualisation. It does so in a way that complies with the two pillars of cloud because it provides robust multitenancy (e.g. network-level separation of different projects' servers), presumably reports billing-related information over the oslo notifications bus, is (via Nova) subject to quotas, and (again via Nova) is accessible to applications via an API. Those are all important things to preserve and would be worth documenting as explicit goals of the Ironic project."}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-01-17 08:03:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add a high level vision reflection document

As part of the TC effort to raise visibility, we want to add
a short high level document which attempts to detail the areas
that could use additional focus where the project as a whole
does not seemingly align with the rest of the OpenStack Cloud
vision.

Some aspects really don't apply, but these seem to be valid areas
and it is important that we write these sorts of things down.

Change-Id: I280c73b8cabcd214d791293d25aef57216464ec7

commit_message:
Add option to skip OSF member filter in owners

Passing -m or --nonmember (-n is already taken) to the owners script
will cause it to include contributors who aren't OSF members when
creating electoral rolls.

Change-Id: Ia79ad0bc09b14b37f3288d018c680f9283f4a510

we removed port 35357 deployment and can be removed in
Train.

commit_message:
Ensure that metadata proxy raises correct exception

When nova has a configuration using metadata_proxy_shared_secret
and neutron NSXv does not have the metadata_shared_secret we
need to make sure that a valid exception is raised.

Change-Id: I5d94a6f4d4f78ad821567164f6810d19ac5e3e67
Closes-bug: #1830535

commit_message:
Include election process in rendered documentation

Create a stub process document which includes the readme so it will
be incorporated into the published election site content. Link to it
from within the main index as well. Overhaul the semi-compliant
reStructuredText syntax in README.rst so it will parse correctly,
and add some additional markup for readability. Also include a note
in the main page section on officials with a call for volunteers.

Change-Id: If78b23a5c8d385d58a2c3125a704d15b5f04a0f1

subject: Extract email bodies to Jinja templates
messages:
[{'account_id': 30492, 'date': '2019-05-24 18:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-05-24 18:30:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30492, 'date': '2019-05-24 19:46:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-05-28 01:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Test Ceph upgrade in CI

Add CI jobs for testing an upgrade of a multinode system with Ceph
enabled. As for the existing upgrade job, we upgrade from the previous
release to the current release.

Change-Id: I931772ca4c63757769467a57c80dc0726a11167a
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/658163

messages: [{'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2019-06-03 09:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-06-03 09:20:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-06-03 15:05:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-03 09:09:30.000000000', 'message': "Preserve list order in _pymod2pkg_translate

Previously, we converted the py_versions list into a set to substract
the versions to be skipped. However, Python does not guarantee the
item order in a set, so some unit tests could fail when the order
was reversed from ['py2', 'py3'] to ['py3', 'py2'].

This change fixes that by making sure the order is maintained.

Change-Id: I5bcdfa3a3dfe2583cc9653d6c87f6c24464b60a5
"}]
commit_message:
Preserve list order in _pymod2pkg_translate

Previously, we converted the py_versions list into a set to substract
the versions to be skipped. However, Python does not guarantee the
item order in a set, so some unit tests could fail when the order
was reversed from ['py2', 'py3'] to ['py3', 'py2'].

This change fixes that by making sure the order is maintained.

Change-Id: I5bcdfa3a3dfe2583cc9653d6c87f6c24464b60a5

commit_message:
Remove 'cp' command from rootwrap filters

Remove the 'cp' command from the rootwrap filters
and use oslo.privsep.

Change-Id: I4d4bf985bb29726a55a6c9b9b836ebaceff74ffc
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add support for network-data-file.

TripleO offers a default network topology when deploying
with network isolation enabled, and this is reflected in
the network_data.yaml file in tripleo-heat-templates.
If this is the case it has to be handled during update/upgrade.

Change-Id: If50109753d4845357c869986c256186e8e22006d
(cherry picked from commit 663d380f6fe0e21d58de3aa55cce3cdf9c849ef1)
(cherry picked from commit 44810b2a10a712eee64de119a90b02b13360be19)
(cherry picked from commit da7c11883b823bcf62c4da76cafbb6011e8ba0f7)

'virsh capabilities' reports 'armv6l' not 'armv6':

22:43 (0s) hrw@puchatek:~$ virsh capabilities|grep 'arch name'|grep arm
    <arch name='armv6l'>
    <arch name='armv7l'>

Change-Id: I19bdfd1a3a438c0775de8ffa0e9997b80121f97f

commit_message:
virt/arch: use 'armv6l' for ARMV6 architecture

'virsh capabilities' reports 'armv6l' not 'armv6':

22:43 (0s) hrw@puchatek:~$ virsh capabilities|grep 'arch name'|grep arm
    <arch name='armv6l'>
    <arch name='armv7l'>

Change-Id: I19bdfd1a3a438c0775de8ffa0e9997b80121f97f

commit_message:
Add extra logging to request filters

This adds a timing decorator to request_filter.py which logs the
filters that we ran and how long they took. This requires a small
calling convention change for these request filters to return
True if they are enabled and/or did anything.

This also sprinkles some debug logging into all the existing filters
to provide contextual information about what they are doing to
make debugging scheduling decisions easier.

Change-Id: Ibf62c5398a95c75fde815309e7a4f82f1bd9649c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-26 11:06:35.000000000', 'message': 'Adds peer persistence feature to HPE 3PAR driver

First attempt at a naive implementation for Peer Persistence volumes in the
HPE 3PAR driver for Cinder.

This is a cleaned-up version of a patch we are currently using on a
standalone Cinder installation (non-OpenStack). This means that the basic
functionality of being able to create cinder volumes with peer persistence
has been validated. However, a multitude of tests will be required in order
to merge this functionality upstream.

A first attempt at listing the tests to be executed:

- Validation of the "replication:peer_persistence" setting
- Double-check implementation/configuration of peerpersistent volumes
- Validate creation of peerpersistent volumes when one 3PAR instance is
  unavailable
- Validate automatic fail-over of an existing peerpersistent volume when
  a 3PAR instance goes offline
- Validate manual fail-over of a peerpersistent volumes
- Evaluate retype functionality for peerpersistent volumes

Changed:

- Fixed invalid variable name
- Resolved all Flake8 warnings
- Fixed one invalid if-clause when replication is not enabled
- Dict comprehension instead of dict constructor for PEP8
- Fix dict comprehension syntax instead of dict constructor for PEP8

Change-Id: Ibb0f39943c5283e6c894988bd25f4b61b89477df
'}]
commit_message:
Adds peer persistence feature to HPE 3PAR driver

First attempt at a naive implementation for Peer Persistence volumes in the
HPE 3PAR driver for Cinder.

This is a cleaned-up version of a patch we are currently using on a
standalone Cinder installation (non-OpenStack). This means that the basic
functionality of being able to create cinder volumes with peer persistence
has been validated. However, a multitude of tests will be required in order
to merge this functionality upstream.

A first attempt at listing the tests to be executed:

- Validation of the "replication:peer_persistence" setting
- Double-check implementation/configuration of peerpersistent volumes
- Validate creation of peerpersistent volumes when one 3PAR instance is
  unavailable
- Validate automatic fail-over of an existing peerpersistent volume when
  a 3PAR instance goes offline
- Validate manual fail-over of a peerpersistent volumes
- Evaluate retype functionality for peerpersistent volumes

Changed:

- Fixed invalid variable name

commit_message:
Fix shell upload-to-image with no volume type

Upload-to-image would error after launching
the operation if the volume type is None.

Closes-Bug: #1821818

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 19:41:12.000000000', 'message': 'Add user_domain_name to keystone client.

Use user_domain_name as a fallback if no user_domain_id is provided,
the default keystone password auth uses only user_domain_id, if not
provided aodh will fail getting a token, add the extra
user_domain_name parameter to the authentication.

Closes-Bug: #1831181

Change-Id: I170267ddbed31f63717e1c8fe119b2557afc812e
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add user_domain_name to keystone client.

Use user_domain_name as a fallback if no user_domain_id is provided,
the default keystone password auth uses only user_domain_id, if not
provided aodh will fail getting a token, add the extra
user_domain_name parameter to the authentication.

Closes-Bug: #1831181

Change-Id: I170267ddbed31f63717e1c8fe119b2557afc812e
Signed-off-by: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Force amp-agent communication to TLSv1.2

Also allow configuration of this minimum.
The previous default of SSLv2/3 is very insecure.

Change-Id: If34c7c34d9a6a77685fb177976dc2070760c7b37

(2 comments)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Thanks for contribution Kasper. Have you based the implementation
 > on any official documentation on Redis upgrade? If so, please refer
 > it in the commit message. Also, please describe the upgrade
 > procedure briefly.

Redis documentation refers to the rolling upgrade procedure. It requires using slave nodes within a cluster: https://redis.io/topics/admin
Actually this code doesn't perform real rolling upgrade. Thanks to that we may skip creating slave nodes for each cluster node. I haven't found any official documentation how to perform "partial" rolling upgrade but as long as new Redis version doesn't break cluster bus compatibility it works well.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-04-26 04:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Kasper, thanks so much for this contribution. '}, {'created': '2019-04-24 14:02:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add Redis datastore upgrade

This patch adds support for upgrading Redis datastore - both single
instance and cluster.

It is achievied in a similar way to MySQL/Mariadb. Steps are:
    + For each node do:
        + stop database
        + preserve configuration files,
        + unmount data volume,
        + create new instance with new datastore,
        + enter restarting mode
        + mount data volume,
        + restore configuration files,
        + reload datastore

Note that due to the Redis Cluster design and Trove approach (all
nodes are master nodes) we do not perform real rolling upgrade - some
Redis slots may be unavailable while upgrading node associated with
them.

commit_message:
Add Redis datastore upgrade

This patch adds support for upgrading Redis datastore - both single
instance and cluster.

It is achievied in a similar way to MySQL/Mariadb. Steps are:
    + For each node do:
        + stop database
        + preserve configuration files,
        + unmount data volume,
        + create new instance with new datastore,
        + enter restarting mode
        + mount data volume,
        + restore configuration files,
        + reload datastore

Note that due to the Redis Cluster design and Trove approach (all
nodes are master nodes) we do not perform real rolling upgrade - some
Redis slots may be unavailable while upgrading node associated with
them.

This patch adds also a user documentation about upgrading datastores
using Redis as an example.

Story: #2005421
Task: #30443
Co-Authored-By: Kasper Hasior <k.hasior@samsung.com>
Change-Id: I60cddb3a41d2cc7024cbec3d2fd2038d79446507
Signed-off-by: Kasper Hasior <k.hasior@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Use arping, not arping2 for SUSE's neutron image

Default rootwrap config is set for 'arping' so if the config should stay
same accross the distributions, it's better if applications are same as well.

Co-Authored-By: Itxaka <igarcia@suse.com>
Change-Id: I483ff17c956f57013f9a8345e01223dbd743963c

Looks good for me :D'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-04-16 20:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-04-16 20:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Maybe Dean has some experience on another CLI that tries to do something like this.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-04-16 20:18:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Matt's comments are why I didn't leave much of a vote before.

I want the client to reflect the way the API expresses things because that's the way I think: the API is the important thing, the client is a convenience that should operate as an on ramp to understanding the structure, grammar and expressiveness of the API.

This is not at all what openstack CLI in general is trying to do or be (at least as far as I can tell).

The bit about forbidden member_of in microversion 1.32 is a compelling (to me) reason to carry on with `!` here. We'd like to avoid a collision later.

But I'm saying that as

a) the guy who decided we should use ! in the query parameters
b) the guy who said the above about the CLI being an onramp to understanding the API

So even though I'm personally perfectly fine with the way the client is expressing itself now, I've got a big bias that could very well be wrong."}, {'account_id': 30202, 'date': '2019-04-17 10:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2019-05-08 10:08:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Add support for 1.22 microversion

The 1.22 microversion of placement adds support for
excluding resource providers and allocation candidates
with specified traits. A forbidden trait may be specified
with --forbidden option.

Change-Id: I4760fe6119e29d80f63ec7bd6c4a5f2395a9291e

commit_message:
Use stable ARA setup interface for defining the callback location

ARA ships simple setup modules to help figure out the paths
to where things are located.
These are backwards compatible from ARA 1.0 to 0.x.

Change-Id: I1cbc23d01eb22e43a6820aa5aee4506cf8cb069a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-03 11:02:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix importing engine module from flake8

In some distros, like e.g. Fedora when unit tests are run, there is
flake8 > 3 used as there is such version available in distro's
repositories.
Flake8 in version 3 losts backward compatybility, see [1], and module
flake8.engine is not available anymore.
That broke unit tests from neutron.tests.unit.hacking module.

This patch fixes imports of flake8.engine module in such case.

[1] https://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/python-api.html#legacy-api

Change-Id: I536cffb0aaa8c5a4a6ee3dde17e488e40bf9c2cc
"}, {'created': '2019-06-03 11:06:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix importing engine module from flake8

In some distros, like e.g. Fedora when unit tests are run, there is
flake8 > 3 used as there is such version available in distro's
repositories.
Flake8 in version 3 losts backward compatybility, see [1], and module
flake8.engine is not available anymore.
That broke unit tests from neutron.tests.unit.hacking module.

This patch fixes imports of flake8.engine module in such case.

[1] https://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/python-api.html#legacy-api

Change-Id: I536cffb0aaa8c5a4a6ee3dde17e488e40bf9c2cc
"}]
commit_message:
Fix importing engine module from flake8

In some distros, like e.g. Fedora when unit tests are run, there is
flake8 > 3 used as there is such version available in distro's
repositories.
Flake8 in version 3 losts backward compatybility, see [1], and module
flake8.engine is not available anymore.
That broke unit tests from neutron.tests.unit.hacking module.

This patch fixes imports of flake8.engine module in such case.

[1] https://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/python-api.html#legacy-api

Change-Id: I536cffb0aaa8c5a4a6ee3dde17e488e40bf9c2cc

commit_message:
Block swap volume on volumes with >1 rw attachment

If we're swapping from a multiattach volume that has more than one
read/write attachment, another server on the secondary attachment could
be writing to the volume which is not getting copied into the volume to
which we're swapping, so we could have data loss during the swap.

This change does volume read/write attachment counting for the volume
we're swapping from and if there is more than one read/write attachment
on the volume, the swap volume operation fails with a 400 BadRequest
error.

Conflicts:
      api-ref/source/os-volume-attachments.inc

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
I5fc4d0ba3bb1c49dfaba2b2eed056441509cb9da in Queens. Also, the
uuidsentinel has to be imported in the test_volumes module because
change I9acc2e4d6c57ea0f45ba161116993d9f1a0e1e9f is not in Queens.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/573025/
Closes-Bug: #1775418
Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778
(cherry picked from commit 5a1d159d142997bb4288d4bf86d4e144334905cd)
(cherry picked from commit 9b21d1067a071ab17758068dfca5cd2ebd29d868)
(cherry picked from commit c19d602f9be536ee8412bac0f0951a995424f25e)

commit_message:
Rebuild initramfs after applying change in kernel parameters

This patch makes sure that initramfs is rebuilt after applying
change in kernel pamraters, so that we also have these change
applied in initramfs.

Change-Id: I3de131c022e183cb29aa1c5c9913af736afd0c4d
Closes-Bug: #1830574
(cherry picked from commit 3ef8e3e35dbb43414becc4f561830bb731643ead)

commit_message:
Add support for network-data-file.

TripleO offers a default network topology when deploying
with network isolation enabled, and this is reflected in
the network_data.yaml file in tripleo-heat-templates.
If this is the case it has to be handled during update/upgrade.

Change-Id: If50109753d4845357c869986c256186e8e22006d
(cherry picked from commit 663d380f6fe0e21d58de3aa55cce3cdf9c849ef1)
(cherry picked from commit 44810b2a10a712eee64de119a90b02b13360be19)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4690, 'name': 'melanie witt', 'display_name': 'melwitt', 'email': 'melwittt@gmail.com', 'username': 'melwitt'}, {'_account_id': 9555, 'name': 'Matthew Booth', 'email': 'mbooth@redhat.com', 'username': 'MatthewBooth'}, {'_account_id': 10135, 'name': 'Lee Yarwood', 'display_name': 'Lee Yarwood', 'email': 'lyarwood@redhat.com', 'username': 'lyarwood'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 17216, 'name': 'Martin Schuppert', 'email': 'mschuppert@redhat.com', 'username': 'mcschupp'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 20778, 'name': 'Damien Ciabrini', 'email': 'dciabrin@redhat.com', 'username': 'dciabrin'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-05-04 22:04:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-04 22:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Since the patch breaking wsgi in nova has been introduced in stein only, I think until nova is fixed, this is fine. But ultimately nova folks need to be okay with this (and if not propose other solutions)'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-05-04 22:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

just a note https://review.opendev.org/647310 is right now in gate checks to be merged. hopefuly should land today'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-05-04 22:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Ifb1c407df1f888c72e008578232d53a76b3d2e40 is the real solution here, AFAIK this is just going to cause other issues.'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-04 23:27:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Ifb1c407df1f888c72e008578232d53a76b3d2e40 is the real solution
 > here, AFAIK this is just going to cause other issues.

Looks like it yes, but I guess it depends on ETA and if/or that will get backported to stein. What puzzles me is what https://review.opendev.org/#/c/592285/ tried to fix at all, since it is what broke things in the first place. So this patch effectively should put us in a pre https://review.opendev.org/#/c/592285/ position. Up to you guys in any case ;)'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-04 23:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> just a note https://review.opendev.org/647310 is right now in gate
 > checks to be merged. hopefuly should land today

We see this issue *with* this review merged already, since we pull it in RDO (without it ssl undercloud explodes). The real review that broke heartbeat is https://review.opendev.org/#/c/592285/'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-05-21 11:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

You must not merge this.

As the author of the patch which added this to Nova, I'd like to veto this. This is not intended to be used here, and will break Nova.

Our current thinking is to change the log level of the reconnection messages down to INFO, as they don't impact functionality.

In case that wasn't clear, don't merge this. It would make n-api unsupportable.

Don't merge this."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-05-21 11:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

the heart beat being broken is not considered an error that needs to be fixed. we would like it to work however the current consensus is that it is inappropriate for nova to deliberately circumvent the execution model of the wsgi server.

as a result https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650172/14 which replace the use of eventlet with a thread executor will likely not proceed.
as a result we currently have no path forward to fix the heartbeat.

this is not an issue form a nova perspective as oslo messaging correctly recovers internally so the lack of a heartbeat does not break the nova api provided there is 1 thread per process in the wsgi server.

in anycase while disableing eventlet monkey patching might fix the heartbeat it has three problems. firstr the cells scater gater code
would become serial severly degrading the performce of multi cell actions such as instnce list. second it would circumvent the treading model of the wsgi server by spawning a addtion heart beat thread. Third if the wsgi server suspends the execution of the python interperter it will also suspend the heatbeat thread so this wont actully fix the problem in all cases.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-05-21 12:34:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Quick update, I'm totally fine abandoning that patch as we all seem to agree it's not addressing all the issues.
 
 > in anycase while disableing eventlet monkey patching might fix the
 > heartbeat it has three problems. firstr the cells scater gater code
 > would become serial severly degrading the performce of multi cell
 > actions such as instnce list. second it would circumvent the
 > treading model of the wsgi server by spawning a addtion heart beat
 > thread. Third if the wsgi server suspends the execution of the
 > python interperter it will also suspend the heatbeat thread so this
 > wont actully fix the problem in all cases.

I just want to answer to that last paragraph (specifically point Third), as maybe my claim/point was unclear in the first place.

Prior to enabling eventlet in the nova_api code, there was no monkey patching involved in the nova_api service. That means that the heartbeat python thread created by oslo_messaging wasn't a greenthread, but was a real pthread.

Having a real pthread hosting the AMQP heartbeat thread is what made heartbeat work under mod_wsgi.

Mod_wsgi runs the main python interpreter in the a pthread. When a transaction finishes, the python interpreter ran by mod_wsgi (in the mod_wsgi pthread) goes to rest, and mod_wsgi waits idle until another transaction comes in.

_But_: there is still another pthread which runs a python interpreter for the AMQP heartbeat. That pthread is never stopped or suspended, so the python interpreter running inside that pthread can monitor the AMQP connection on a regular basis.

The fact of moving to eventlet monkey_patch makes the AMQP heartbeat thread become a green thread. As such it is only processed by the main python interpreter, which goes to rest as soon as a transaction is finished. This in turns break the whole background heartbeat mechanism as long as mod_wsgi is not awaken frequently enough.

I hope that clarifies the problem that I was trying to solve."}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-06-03 11:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning the review since removing monkey-patch is not working and is not the solution as agreed.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-04 22:04:21.000000000', 'message': "Do not monkey_patch nova_api running under mod_wsgi

With [1] and [2] nova_api seems to be calling eventlet.monkey_patch()
when it runs under mod_wsgi.

This impacts the AMQP heartbeat thread, which is meant to be a
native thread: instead of checking AMQP sockets every 15s, It is
now suspended and resumed by eventlet. However, resuming
greenthreads can take a very long time if mod_wsgi isn't
processing traffic regularly, which can cause rabbitmq to close
the AMQP connection.

The problem is currently being discussed in lp#1825584, but until
a clean fix is proposed, workaround the issue by forcing nova_api
to not do any monkey patching to revert to the original heartbeat
behaviour. By doing so, we effectively impact work for [1] and [2].

[1] Ie7bf5d012e2ccbcd63c262ddaf739782afcdaf56
[2] Id46e76666b553a10ec4654d4418a9884975b5b95

Related-Bug: #1825584
Closes-Bug: #1827744

Change-Id: I3efdcbb4f56e545830ebb0c39bc9dc9508d1418c
"}]
commit_message:
Do not monkey_patch nova_api running under mod_wsgi

With [1] and [2] nova_api seems to be calling eventlet.monkey_patch()
when it runs under mod_wsgi.

This impacts the AMQP heartbeat thread, which is meant to be a
native thread: instead of checking AMQP sockets every 15s, It is
now suspended and resumed by eventlet. However, resuming
greenthreads can take a very long time if mod_wsgi isn't
processing traffic regularly, which can cause rabbitmq to close
the AMQP connection.

The problem is currently being discussed in lp#1825584, but until
a clean fix is proposed, workaround the issue by forcing nova_api
to not do any monkey patching to revert to the original heartbeat
behaviour. By doing so, we effectively impact work for [1] and [2].

[1] Ie7bf5d012e2ccbcd63c262ddaf739782afcdaf56
[2] Id46e76666b553a10ec4654d4418a9884975b5b95

Related-Bug: #1825584
Closes-Bug: #1827744

Change-Id: I3efdcbb4f56e545830ebb0c39bc9dc9508d1418c

commit_message:
Improve registration of Monasca InfluxDB database

Monasca is not yet compatible with InfluxDB > 1.1.10, which means
that the official Ansible modules for managing InfluxDB don't work [1].
We therefore fall back to manual commands to register the database
and a default retention policy.

[1] https://github.com/influxdata/influxdb-python
    #influxdb-pre-v110-users

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I59ceda1e7a6e945b13872089011045db04548b94

commit_message:
Change the order of parameters for lsp_bind method

The function parameters "chassis" and "name" of the lsp_bind method of
OvnSbApiIdlImpl is in reverse order compared to the corresponding abstract
method in the API class.

This change fixes the order.

Change-Id: Ibaee0ad1c78414982dab10f696c9fb4b6c3cbfbf
Closes-Bug: 1827210

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 13:08:31.000000000', 'message': 'Convert Swift connection errors into more obvious ones

Currently we handle Swift errors on putting/getting objects, but not
on connections. This patch improves it for better error messages.

This also means that commit 09938a397595b92f19f6415bb3cfec8be76fe6a3
is incomplete and does not actually fix the extra-hardware plugin
when Swift is absent. This change corrects it.

Change-Id: I0e8e76291653dd2e0cd3cde35d18a1e8f9c91853
'}]
commit_message:
Convert Swift connection errors into more obvious ones

Currently we handle Swift errors on putting/getting objects, but not
on connections. This patch improves it for better error messages.

This also means that commit 09938a397595b92f19f6415bb3cfec8be76fe6a3
is incomplete and does not actually fix the extra-hardware plugin
when Swift is absent. This change corrects it.

Change-Id: I0e8e76291653dd2e0cd3cde35d18a1e8f9c91853

commit_message:
rgw keystone setup fix python interpreter

When using a user defined setup host, we need to set
openstack_service_setup_host_python_interpreter, this fix make the
playbook use it if provided.

Change-Id: Ia97608fc192e2238b37b9eab0fedadfdcb3a8c0f
Closes-Bug: 1830220
(cherry picked from commit dbf0e55b132be7cf398a88788d9bdf0c24c23a66)

commit_message:
Separate requirements for documents tox job

This commit separates the requirements libraries for the docs job in
tox.ini. The latest sphinx doesn't work in Python2 environments anymore.
So, we need to split that into the test and docs jobs.

Change-Id: I7255cd9af0dfb5c1f66c1aa65d0ddfb144079836

we can more easily guarantee test stability, while not harming
out ability to improve on the testing library during a cycle.

This change backports the zaza namespace change landing, and
adds a stable branch of the zaza-openstack-charms project to
the test-dependencies.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-27 09:01:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Pod creation do not triggers affected SVC SG update

The LBaaS SG is not updated when a pod is created on a namespace different
than a service, and this pod affects the pods under a Network Policy
enforcement, which are the same as the backend pods of that service.
This commit fixes the issue by looking for all services in all namespaces,
not only the ones with same namespace as the created pod.

Change-Id: Idb3365e70e66dd8544f5b97aece312bc18c57ee5
Closes-Bug: 1830598
'}, {'created': '2019-05-28 14:24:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Pod creation do not triggers affected SVC SG update

The LBaaS SG is not updated when a Pod that affects the traffic to another
pods/services is on a different namespace than those pods/services.
For example: pod-A on namespace-A is created and according to a network
policy should affects the traffic to pod-B on namespace-B, and
consequently to the service that has pod B as a backend pod.

Change-Id: Idb3365e70e66dd8544f5b97aece312bc18c57ee5
Closes-Bug: 1830598
'}, {'created': '2019-05-29 07:45:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Pod creation do not triggers affected SVC SG update

The LBaaS SG is not updated when a pod that is referenced by a
service has a network policy that restrict/accept traffic from
pods in different namespaces. For example: pod-A on namespace-A is
created and according to a network policy should affects the traffic
to pod-B on namespace-B, and consequently to the service that has
pod B as a backend pod.

Change-Id: Idb3365e70e66dd8544f5b97aece312bc18c57ee5
Closes-Bug: 1830598
'}, {'created': '2019-05-30 07:49:44.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Pod creation do not triggers affected SVC SG update

The LBaaS SG is not updated when a pod that is referenced by a
service has a network policy that restrict/accept traffic from
pods in different namespaces. For example: pod-A on namespace-A is
created and according to a network policy should affects the traffic
to pod-B on namespace-B, and consequently to the service that has
pod B as a backend pod.

Change-Id: Idb3365e70e66dd8544f5b97aece312bc18c57ee5
Closes-Bug: 1830598
'}, {'created': '2019-06-02 07:56:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Pod creation do not triggers affected SVC SG update

The LBaaS SG is not updated when a pod that is referenced by a
service has a network policy that restrict/accept traffic from
pods in different namespaces. For example: pod-A on namespace-A is
created and according to a network policy should affects the traffic
to pod-B on namespace-B, and consequently to the service that has

Change-Id: Idb3365e70e66dd8544f5b97aece312bc18c57ee5

commit_message:
Fix Pod creation do not triggers affected SVC SG update

The LBaaS SG is not updated when a pod that is referenced by a
service has a network policy that restrict/accept traffic from
pods in different namespaces. For example: pod-A on namespace-A is
created and according to a network policy should affects the traffic
to pod-B on namespace-B, and consequently to the service that has
pod B as a backend pod.

Change-Id: Idb3365e70e66dd8544f5b97aece312bc18c57ee5
Closes-Bug: 1830598

[{'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-05-28 10:50:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-05-28 10:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-05-28 13:42:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-05-29 07:04:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Perhaps the note should be included into the documentation, not just inside the code. Ideally, there may be a unittest checking that both versions are the same'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-05-29 11:57:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Perhaps the note should be included into the documentation, not
 > just inside the code. Ideally, there may be a unittest checking
 > that both versions are the same

This note is needed only for someone who will want to modify api.proto.
This should be a rare case.

And I'm not sure how to write a unit test as we're not installing 'protoc'
compiler anywhere. It's responsibility of developer who updates api.proto
to re-generate files using correct compiler version. Should this unit test
re-build files with correct version of compiler and check that resulted
files are equal to ones inside the repo? There are no protobuf version marks
inside generated files.

Probably, I could write more detailed 'devref' document on how to update
pod-resources gRPC API files. Another option is to prepare the script that

commit_message:
Add note about 'protoc' compiler version

'protoc' compiler which is used to generate gRPC API files should have
the same version as 'protobuf' in lower-constraints.txt.
Code generated by the old compiler supported in newer runtime, but
code generated by newer compiler could be not supported in older
runtime. At the same time there is no much sense using compiler older
than our lower requirements on 'protobuf'.

Change-Id: If79186185f72210eafd69c1ebdc2338782d31037
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Block swap volume on volumes with >1 rw attachment

If we're swapping from a multiattach volume that has more than one
read/write attachment, another server on the secondary attachment could
be writing to the volume which is not getting copied into the volume to
which we're swapping, so we could have data loss during the swap.

This change does volume read/write attachment counting for the volume
we're swapping from and if there is more than one read/write attachment
on the volume, the swap volume operation fails with a 400 BadRequest
error.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to Stein change
I7d5bddc0aa1833cda5f4bcebe5e03bdd447f641a changing the
decorators on the _test_snapshot_and_backup method.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/573025/
Closes-Bug: #1775418
Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778
(cherry picked from commit 5a1d159d142997bb4288d4bf86d4e144334905cd)
(cherry picked from commit 9b21d1067a071ab17758068dfca5cd2ebd29d868)

commit_message:
Avoid 'non-zero return code' msg when ceph-ansible isn't installed

This patch uses 'rpm' command to know if the ceph-ansible package is installed
Whatever the return code, the command will return:

- 'package ceph-ansible is not installed'
or
- 'ceph-ansible-3.1.9-1.el7.noarch'

Adding '|| true' to the rpm command will get rid of the message
'exited with code: 1: non-zero return code' when ceph-ansible is not installed.

NOTE:
Up to *stable/rocky*, all the validations playbooks were located in the
`validations` directory. From *stable/stein*, the validations have been
migrated into Ansible roles located in the `basedir/roles` directory.

In order to facilitate the maintenance of any backports
from *stable/stein* to *stable/rocky* (or previous stable branches), all
the fixes and improvements done during the validation framework
blueprint will have to be backported in *stable/rocky*.

Change-Id: Ida251a81d0fe7b6904f43b4f78f2f4e26d93325a
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 67e5da4005e732ca98d562ca42d4ea6e8c4f705f)

commit_message:
Set Content-Type header explictly for SessionClient

SessionClient is subclassed from keystoneauth LegacyJsonAdapter.
LegacyJsonAdapter does not set the Content-Type explicitly
and results in decodeing issues in some cases.

Change-Id: Idf23022b394607c332490331fc4b216de6ff1313
Story: 2005237
Task: 30027

subject: hw: cpu: Rework the directory layout; add missing traits
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 2394, 'name': 'Adam Spiers', 'email': 'aspiers@suse.com', 'username': 'adam.spiers'}, {'_account_id': 6962, 'name': 'Kashyap Chamarthy', 'email': 'kchamart@redhat.com', 'username': 'kashyapc'}, {'_account_id': 7634, 'name': 'Takashi Natsume', 'email': 'takanattie@gmail.com', 'username': 'natsumet'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-23 16:45:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-23 19:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-24 07:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-24 08:12:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-24 11:44:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-24 15:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Based on the reference, it seems like

- stibp and pdpe1gb are common to Intel and AMD
- pcid and spec-ctrl are Intel-specific
- ssb has different variants for Intel and AMD

This leads me to think we should probably introduce new modules so we can distinguish:

- hw/cpu/x86.py (common to both Intel and AMD)
- hw/cpu/x86/amd.py (AMD-specific) <== new (but see below)
- hw/cpu/x86/intel.py (Intel-specific) <== new

This leaves the existing hw/cpu/amd.py kind of orphaned. Forgive my ignorance, but perhaps AMD produces x86 and $other, and SEV is common to those? If not, we may want to add SEV to the new hw/cpu/x86/amd.py and "deprecate" (via comment, sad-face) the existing one.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-04-24 15:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Not knowing anything about the specifics of these traits, I noticed that there are two with essentially the same names (removing the double AMD Eric noted):

  HW_CPU_X86_SSBD
  HW_CPU_AMD_SSBD

Is it because 'SSBD' means different thing in x86 and AMD worlds? Or do they represent the same "thing", but maybe done better/worse?'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-24 21:49:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> This leads me to think we should probably introduce new modules so we can distinguish:
> 
> hw/cpu/x86.py (common to both Intel and AMD)
> hw/cpu/x86/amd.py (AMD-specific) <== new (but see below)
> hw/cpu/x86/intel.py (Intel-specific) <== new

That makes sense to me.

> This leaves the existing hw/cpu/amd.py kind of orphaned. Forgive my ignorance, but perhaps AMD produces x86 and $other, and SEV is common to those?

I'm no expert, but AFAIK AMD *has* produced a small number of non-x86 architectures:

  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_AMD_CPU_microarchitectures#Other_microarchitectures
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_AMD_microprocessors

however these are mostly historical and in any case dwarfed in relevance compared to their x86-compatible architectures.  Also AFAIK SEV is x86-only.

> If not, we may want to add SEV to the new hw/cpu/x86/amd.py and "deprecate" (via comment, sad-face) the existing one.

Fine by me; I don't anticipate that causing any problems since nothing using HW_CPU_AMD_SEV ever got merged yet.  Of course having an unused trait lying around forever is somewhat ugly but it can be hidden away in the source with a comment explaining its deprecation, so in practice the ugliness would hardly ever be seen.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-25 09:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-25 09:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Not knowing anything about the specifics of these traits, I noticed
 > that there are two with essentially the same names (removing the
 > double AMD Eric noted):
 > 
 > HW_CPU_X86_SSBD
 > HW_CPU_AMD_SSBD
 > 
 > Is it because 'SSBD' means different thing in x86 and AMD worlds?
 > Or do they represent the same "thing", but maybe done better/worse?

"SSB" (Speculative Store Bypass) is a vulnerability which affects AMD 
and Intel (and ARM).  And "SSBD" (Speculative Store Bypass Disable) is 
the *mitigation* for "SSB".

Intel addressed SSB flaw by introducing a hardware CPU flag called: 
`ssbd` (which must be explicitly enabled for all Intel models).

And AMD addressed the SSB flaw by introducing three CPU features:

- `virt-ssbd`  -- This is a feature for virtual machines (and does not
                  exist in the physical host CPUs), and must be exposed 
                  to Nova instances for maximum guest compatibility.
                  Along with 'amd-ssbd' (refer below).

- `amd-ssbd`   -- This provides a higher performance than `virt-ssbd`,
                  so it should be exposed to the guest whenever it is 
                  available in the host CPU

- `amd-no-ssb` -- To indicate that future AMD CPUs are *not* vulnerable 
                  to SSB

Back to traits: So we need both: HW_CPU_X86_SSBD _and_ HW_CPU_AMD_SSBD.

Hope I've answered your question.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-25 11:24:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Bearing in mind the proposed reorganisation here, see also https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655673/'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-04-25 12:55:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-04-26 17:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

1) all of these traits should go into the hw/cpu/x86.py module

2) While I agree completely with Ed that there is no such thing as a "negative trait", unfortunately due to poor naming of the upstream CPU feature, "no-ssb" is actually not the same thing as "doesn't have the 'ssb' feature" :( It actually means that the CPU doesn't have the *vulnerability* that the ssb CPU feature addresses. *sigh* So, this does indeed need to be a separate trait.

The interesting thing is that the virt-ssb, ssb, and no-ssb traits are all mutually exclusive. I don't fully understand how these traits are intended to be used in conjunction with the nova scheduler actually. I mean, do we really intend to have a flavor that says "find a host that has the speculative execution fixes applied to it OR that is on a host with a CPU that doesn't have this vulnerability OR that has some emulated fix for the speculative execution (virt-ssb)"?

Seems more likely that this "trait" will be used by some low-level baremetal hypervisor node management system to identify the hypervisor hosts that *haven't* had a Meltdown/Spectre firmware fix rolled out to it. In other words, it's not really a Nova use case but more of a use case for using placement to decorate low-level compute node information for a datacenter management system to use for identifying hosts that need fixing.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-26 18:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> 1) all of these traits should go into the hw/cpu/x86.py module

So we should prefix the AMD-specific ones with AMD_ and the Intel-specific ones with INTEL_ rather than splitting them into separate modules, yah?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-04-26 18:31:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > 1) all of these traits should go into the hw/cpu/x86.py module
 > 
 > So we should prefix the AMD-specific ones with AMD_ and the
 > Intel-specific ones with INTEL_ rather than splitting them into
 > separate modules, yah?

I would put all of these into the hw/cpu/x86.py module since they are all x86 CPU instruction set extensions. 

My preference would be to not include any AMD_ prefix at all and instead only have the following:

 PCID
 PGPE1GB
 SPEC_CTRL
 SSBD
 NO_SSBD
 VIRT_SSBD
 IBPD

I see no reason whatsoever to have separate "SSBD" and "AMD_SSBD" traits. After all, it's not like you're going to have a single compute node (resource provider) with *both* an Intel *and* an AMD processor in it.

Keep it simple, I'd say.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-26 18:46:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm watching this conversation with baited breath to see whether it will impact HW_CPU_AMD_SEV too ;-)  As a reminder, we already debated this vs. HW_CPU_X86_SEV a long time ago, and settled on the AMD namespace:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/609779/12/specs/stein/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.rst@95"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-04-26 18:54:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I'm watching this conversation with baited breath to see whether it
 > will impact HW_CPU_AMD_SEV too ;-)  As a reminder, we already
 > debated this vs. HW_CPU_X86_SEV a long time ago, and settled on the
 > AMD namespace:
 > 
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/609779/12/specs/stein/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.rst@95

right, but SEV is an AMD CPU-only feature, no?"}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-26 19:24:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yep but there was also talk of moving AMD traits under HW_CPU_X86_AMD_*. Don't mind me though, I've got plenty of popcorn here ;-)"}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 08:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[...]

 > I would put all of these into the hw/cpu/x86.py module since they
 > are all x86 CPU instruction set extensions.

I'm up for any suggestion that all the "Traits People" agree with.  But to think out loud: We now have amd.py file with just SEV trait, which is the AMD-specific CPU flag.  Meanwhile we have "SVM", an AMD-only feature in x86.py — which I assumed to be Intel-only; otherwise why would you create an amd.py file to begin with?  (I realize that the term "x86" is Intel-based, it can apply to AMD and other vendors who hold an x86 architecture license.)

 > My preference would be to not include any AMD_ prefix at all and
 > instead only have the following:

Agreed in general.  I named the trait as "AMD-SSB" (because the CPU flag itself is named as such).

 > PCID
 > PGPE1GB
 > SPEC_CTRL
 > SSBD
 > NO_SSBD
 > VIRT_SSBD
 > IBPD
 > 
 > I see no reason whatsoever to have separate "SSBD" and "AMD_SSBD"
 > traits. After all, it's not like you're going to have a single
 > compute node (resource provider) with *both* an Intel *and* an AMD
 > processor in it.

Good point.  And while I'm chewing on your suggestion, I named the traits to be as close to the original CPU flag names (to reduce cognitive load).

 > 
 > Keep it simple, I'd say.

I'm all for it.

Thanks for the suggestions!'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 08:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[...]

 > I'm up for any suggestion that all the "Traits People" agree with. 
 > But to think out loud: We now have amd.py file with just SEV trait,
 > which is the AMD-specific CPU flag.  Meanwhile we have "SVM", an
 > AMD-only feature in x86.py — which I assumed to be Intel-only;
 > otherwise why would you create an amd.py file to begin with?  (I
 > realize that the term "x86" is Intel-based, it can apply to AMD and
 > other vendors who hold an x86 architecture license.)

The reason I mentioned above is that as it stands, we've already muddied the "os-traits" waters by having an AMD-only trait ("SVM") in x86.py, while we have an amd.py file sitting in the repo.

[...]'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 08:34:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[...]

 > The interesting thing is that the virt-ssb, ssb, and no-ssb traits

The above is not entirely—e.g. in case of AMD: You _must_ provide "virt-ssb" to the Nova instance _even if_ you have provided it the "amd-ssb" flag.  (So they're not "mutually exclusive", but rather "mutually necessary".)

[...]'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 08:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> [...]

s/"not entirely"/not entirely true"/

e.g. in case of AMD: You _must_ provide

But "amd-no-ssb" is mutually exclusive with "virt-ssbd" and "amd-ssbd".'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 08:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (3 comments)

While the above is cleanest, but the "least invasive" might be to treat "x86.py" for Intel-only, and just have amd.py and x86.py?  Because as it stands, to an unsuspecting reader, having an amd.py "implies" x86.py is Intel-only ... until they closely squint at x86.py.
