naming is hard. I don't have an opinion how this should be but it looks like plenty of people do."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-10 19:29:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Okay, so this iteration is a) not bothering to stuff 'intel' and 'amd' sub-namespaces under 'x86'; b) not worried about DRYing the flags that clearly *are* duplicates (stibp, pdpe1gb).

Perhaps I need to be larned on what the actual use case for these traits is supposed to be. It seems like it should be the ability to express "land me on a host that has spectre/meltdown mitigation"; or "don't land me on a host that's vulnerable to spectre/meltdown". Absent required=in:<list> support from Placement [1], if the hosts are exposing these (vendor-specific) traits, you'll be forced to pick Intel or AMD ahead of time. That doesn't sound very useful.

So while it wouldn't really hurt anything to merge this, or to expose these traits from hosts as appropriate, I wonder if we should consider something more broadly relevant to operators. Like a pair of generic roll-up traits: HW_CPU_HAS_MELTDOWN_CURE, HW_CPU_HAS_SPECTRE_CURE. Point being, does the operator really care that AMD has both virtual and hardware-based mitigations, or care about the distinction between "has mitigation" and "not susceptible"? I would tend to think usually not.

Conveniently, I can -1 for the typo noted inline while we discuss :)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/649992'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-05-13 13:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Okay, so this iteration is a) not bothering to stuff 'intel' and
 > 'amd' sub-namespaces under 'x86'; b) not worried about DRYing the
 > flags that clearly *are* duplicates (stibp, pdpe1gb).

Correct.  Instead of one "x86", probably we should keep the Intel/AMD
distinction for utmost clarity.  But that's just me.

 > Perhaps I need to be larned on what the actual use case for these
 > traits is supposed to be. It seems like it should be the ability to
 > express "land me on a host that has spectre/meltdown mitigation";
 > or "don't land me on a host that's vulnerable to spectre/meltdown".

That would have been ideal, but having granular flags is still useful,
as this patch is proposing (refer the "Another Idea" section below).

 > Absent required=in:<list> support from Placement [1], if the hosts
 > are exposing these (vendor-specific) traits, you'll be forced to
 > pick Intel or AMD ahead of time. That doesn't sound very useful.
 > 
 > So while it wouldn't really hurt anything to merge this, or to
 > expose these traits from hosts as appropriate, I wonder if we
 > should consider something more broadly relevant to operators. Like
 > a pair of generic roll-up traits: HW_CPU_HAS_MELTDOWN_CURE,
 > HW_CPU_HAS_SPECTRE_CURE. Point being, does the operator really care
 > that AMD has both virtual and hardware-based mitigations, or care
 > about the distinction between "has mitigation" and "not
 > susceptible"? I would tend to think usually not.

Ideally, we'd want to have *both* — the granular traits, and the
"generic roll-up traits".  However, given the complexity of the real
world in this case, we should do away with (as in, not go the route of)
the "generic roll-up traits", as, I'm told, that is over-thinking.
Allow me to explain (after discussion with DanPB, who has expertise in
the QEMU / libvirt area on this topic):
  difference between the AMD and Intel flag names for the fix ('IBRS' vs
  'IBPB').  However, we  likely going to want feature- based traits for
  other things: AES, PCID, etc.

* The HW_CPU_HAS_SPECTRE_CURE is ill-defined :-( since there are many
  Spectre-related bugs.

So we should avoid the "generic roll-up traits".

Another Idea
------------

(Credit where it's due: thanks to DanPB for the discussion) 

For "Meltdown" (and for other vulnerabilities; it should be
case-by-case), we can potentially make Nova check the 'sysfs' directory
for vulnerabilities.  And if it reports "Vulnerable" (instead of
"Mitigation", as shown below):

    $> cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/meltdown
    Mitigation: PTI
Then we can print a log warning for the current release that the host is
vulnerable and warn that future Nova will refuse to run VMs on it, and
then next release, make it mandatory.

Likewise for "Spectre":

    $> grep . /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_*
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_v1:Mitigation: __user pointer sanitization
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_v2:Mitigation: Full generic retpoline, IBPB: conditional, IBRS_FW, STIBP: conditional, RSB filling

Although, if you look in the "vulnerabilities" directory, there are
_other_ vulnerabilities:

    $> grep . /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/*
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/l1tf:Mitigation: PTE Inversion; VMX: conditional cache flushes, SMT vulnerable
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/meltdown:Mitigation: PTI
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spec_store_bypass:Mitigation: Speculative Store Bypass disabled via prctl and seccomp
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_v1:Mitigation: __user pointer sanitization
    /sys/devices/system/cpu/vulnerabilities/spectre_v2:Mitigation: Full generic retpoline, IBPB: conditional, IBRS_FW, STIBP: conditional, RSB filling

So one might ask: "Why not refuse to launch an instance if _any_ of the
above vulnerabilities reports 'Vulnerable' (instead of 'Mitigation', as
above)?  Because that would be too strict, and you need a "grace
period".  Why?  E.g. when Spectre first came out, Intel FUBARed the
microcode — so kernel would report "Vulnerable" but people had no
microcode available to mitigate for a few weeks / months.  The same
could potentially happen again for any possible future flaws.  

So if a new flaw is added to 'sysfs' we should probably wait 6 months
before trying to be too strict about refusing to launch VMs.  That's why
we cannot do a blanket check of: "if any of vulnerabilities in the
'/sysfs' do not have 'Mitigation', refuse to launch.

 > Conveniently, I can -1 for the typo noted inline while we discuss
 > :)
 
 Will fix.

 > 
 > [1] https://review.opendev.org/649992'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-13 14:16:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 09:35:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add CPU traits for Meltdown/Spectre mitigation

These important CPU flags provide mitigation from Meltdown and Spectre
flaws.  Or in some cases, the CPU flag will reduce the performance
impact by applying Meltdown fixes.  The said flags are to be used on
Intel and AMD x86 hosts.

Refer to the source in the QEMU Git tree[1].  And its HTML-rendered
version[2].

Notes on the "SSB"/"SSBD" confusion
-----------------------------------

"SSB" (Speculative Store Bypass) is a vulnerability (not a "feature")
which affects AMD and Intel (and ARM).  And "SSBD" (Speculative Store
Bypass Disable) is the *mitigation* for "SSB".

Intel addressed the SSB flaw by introducing a hardware CPU flag called:
`ssbd` (which must be explicitly enabled for all Intel models).

And AMD addressed the SSB flaw by introducing three CPU features:

  - `virt-ssbd`  -- This is a feature for virtual machines (and does not
                    exist in the physical host CPUs), and _must_ be
                    exposed to Nova instances for maximum guest
                    compatibility.  Along with 'amd-ssbd' (refer below).

  - `amd-ssbd`   -- This provides better performance than `virt-ssbd`,
                    so it should be exposed to the guest whenever it is
                    available in the host CPU.

  - `amd-no-ssb` -- This is to indicate that future AMD CPUs are _not_
                    vulnerable to SSB flaw.

The names of Nova traits are _not_ a one-to-one mapping to the CPU
flags.

[1] https://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=blob;f=docs/qemu-cpu-models.texi
[2] https://qemu.weilnetz.de/doc/qemu-doc.html#recommendations_005fcpu_005fmodels_005fx86

Change-Id: I1c9a72d19ef9dadfb931efa3894867099974bcc7
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-05-27 15:43:38.000000000', 'message': 'hw: cpu: Rework the directory layout; add missing traits

The main motivation for this change is to: (a) add missing CPU flags
(including those flags that provide mitigation for the recent CVE flaws)
as 'traits'; and (b) adjust and clean up the layout of the 'hw/cpu/'
directory.

To that end, the following are the set of changes in this patch.

(*) Introduce a new cpu/x86 directory; and vendor-specific files: amd.py
    and intel.py; with __init__.py containing the *common* stuff:

    - hw/cpu/x86/amd.py  -- AMD-only traits.
    - hw/cpu/x86/intel.py  -- Intel-only traits.
    - hw/cpu/x86/__init__.py  -- Common for both AMD and Intel.
    - hw/cpu/x86.py -- Deprecate the contents of this file with a
      comment; and copy them into x86/__init__.py, which is its new
      location.
    - hw/cpu/amd.py -- Deprecate the contents of this file with a
      comment; and copy them into hw/cpu/x86/amd.py, which is its new
      location.

    Comparison between the old and the new layouts of os_traits/hw/cpu/:

      Old Layout                     New Layout
      ----------                     ----------

        cpu/                           cpu/
        ├── aarch64.py                  ├── aarch64.py
        ├── amd.py                      ├── amd.py
        ├── __init__.py                 ├── __init__.py
        └── x86.py                      ├── x86
                                        │\xa0\xa0 ├── amd.py
                                        │\xa0\xa0 ├── __init__.py
                                        │\xa0\xa0 └── intel.py
                                        └── x86.py

(*) Add various missing CPU flags to x86/intel.py, x86/amd.py and to

commit_message:
hw: cpu: Rework the directory layout; add missing traits

The main motivation for this change is to: (a) add missing CPU flags
(including those flags that provide mitigation for the recent CVE flaws)
as 'traits'; and (b) adjust and clean up the layout of the 'hw/cpu/'
directory.

To that end, the following are the set of changes in this patch.

(*) Introduce a new cpu/x86 directory; and vendor-specific files: amd.py
    and intel.py; with __init__.py containing the *common* stuff:

    - hw/cpu/x86/amd.py  -- AMD-only traits.

    - hw/cpu/x86/intel.py -- Intel-only traits.

    - hw/cpu/x86/__init__.py -- Common traits for both AMD and Intel.

    - hw/cpu/x86.py -- Two things: (a) move the contents of this file
      into x86/__init__.py, which is its new location; this move
      preserves the integrity of the string trait names and Python
      paths, as they were before; and (b) given point (a), remove the
      now no longer needed hw/cpu/x86.py.  (Justification: We are
      removing this file to maintain consistency with the way it's done
      througout the 'os-traits' repository.)

    - hw/cpu/amd.py -- Deprecate the contents of this file with a
      comment; and copy them into hw/cpu/x86/amd.py, which is its new
      location.

    Comparison between the old and the new layouts of os_traits/hw/cpu/:

      Old Layout                     New Layout
      ----------                     ----------

        cpu/                           cpu/
        ├── aarch64.py                  ├── aarch64.py
        ├── amd.py                      ├── amd.py [DEPRECATED]
        ├── __init__.py                 ├── __init__.py
        └── x86.py                      └── x86/
                                           ├── amd.py
                                           ├── __init__.py
                                           └── intel.py

(*) Add various missing CPU flags to x86/intel.py, x86/amd.py and to
    x86/__intel__.py.

(*) Copy, and deprecate with a comment, flags from cpu/x86.py, i.e..
    "VMX" (Intel) and "SVM" (AMD), into corresponding vendor-specific
    files.

References
----------

[1] Thread start:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006281.html
    -- On reporting CPU flags that provide mitiation (to CVE flaws) as
    Nova 'traits'

[2] Thread conclusion:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006364.html

Closes-Bug: #1830948
Change-Id: I1c9a72d19ef9dadfb931efa3894867099974bcc7
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

[{'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-05-30 09:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2019-05-31 01:32:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Hi dharmendra, 
I checked it. But, I have a question. 
When we use this patch? 
If I made a VNF with admin, can other project see that vnf?'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-06-03 06:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Hi dharmendra,
 > I checked it. But, I have a question.
 > When we use this patch?
 > If I made a VNF with admin, can other project see that vnf?

No, VNFs created with admin is not be accessible to others.

But the scope of this patch is to make force_delete feature for admin only, it means any non-admin can not perform force delete operation.'}, {'account_id': 29236, 'date': '2019-06-03 06:25:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2019-06-03 06:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26588, 'date': '2019-06-03 06:52:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2019-06-03 08:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Adds support force delete VNF: 2

This patch adds:
  - Make force delete admin_only operation.
  - add test cases.

blueprint force-delete-resources

Change-Id: I9d2aa73e5795cfc3b08752615d9c305f18f4b0cc

[{'created': '2017-02-16 14:05:29.000000000', 'message': 'Log exception when hypervisor version check fails

This is useful to debug problems with the hypervisor version check.
It can happen if libvirt itself has problems like:

internal error: Cannot find suitable emulator for x86_64

Change-Id: Idccc4c35cc92252b50aa14f5bc5a52f1ad93876b
'}, {'created': '2017-03-13 09:38:15.000000000', 'message': 'Log exception when hypervisor version check fails

This is useful to debug problems with the hypervisor version check.
It can happen if libvirt itself has problems like:

internal error: Cannot find suitable emulator for x86_64

Change-Id: Idccc4c35cc92252b50aa14f5bc5a52f1ad93876b
'}]
commit_message:
Log exception when hypervisor version check fails

This is useful to debug problems with the hypervisor version check.
It can happen if libvirt itself has problems like:

internal error: Cannot find suitable emulator for x86_64

Change-Id: Idccc4c35cc92252b50aa14f5bc5a52f1ad93876b

commit_message:
object: Add pmem_namespaces field to the NUMACell obj

Introduce the new PMEMNamespace object, add pmem_namespaces
field to NUMACell obj to track the info of pmem namespaces on host.

Partiallly-Implements: blueprint virtual-persistent-memory

Co-Authored-By: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

Change-Id: I3848e8896846581d3668d7e216ed632e040f95a3

Updating the available resources is a periodic task, it will get
the host numa topology, where we need to update the PMEM namespaces
info and update the usage according to the existed instances.

Partiallly-Implements: blueprint supporting virtual persistent memory

Co-Authored-By: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: Update PMEM namespaces info and usage

Updating the available resources is a periodic task, it will get
the host numa topology, where we need to update the PMEM namespaces
info and update the usage according to the existed instances.

Partiallly-Implements: blueprint virtual-persistent-memory

Co-Authored-By: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

Change-Id: I1782a87a159d2be6c9697bacf1620b46a8688304

Placement raises 409 conflict if the provided generation is
inconsistent wich the registered. For Blazar's use case, The
generation inconsistency can occur in cases another thread
updates the same reservation provider for a different reservation.
This patch changes update_inventory() to retry for such cases.

This patch also changes delete_inventory() to retry as well just in
case the deletion of consumer's allocation is not finished before
calling placement.

WIP for unit tests.

Change-Id: I1b57210d623791a49ad5ac19f791c3b17b871ed3
"}, {'created': '2019-01-26 06:31:09.000000000', 'message': "Retry on inventory update conflict

"}, {'created': '2019-01-27 04:22:56.000000000', 'message': "Retry on inventory update conflict

Now delete_inventory() in blazar's placement client is used to delete
reservation class when the reservation ends. It is now called after
instance deletion, but it still raised 409 conflict error if the
deletion is not completed. To fix this, this patch changes it to
detect the 409 case and retry at some interval.

This patch also changes update_inventory() to retry for 409 conflict,
which occurs in cases another thread updates the same reservation
provider for a different reservation.

Change-Id: I1b57210d623791a49ad5ac19f791c3b17b871ed3
Closes-Bug: #1813252

commit_message:
Retry on inventory update conflict

Placement raises 409 conflict if the provided generation is
inconsistent with the registered in placement DB. For Blazar's use
case, The generation inconsistency can occur in cases where another
thread concurrently updates the same reservation provider for a
different reservation.

This patch changes update_inventory() to retry for such cases.

Change-Id: I1b57210d623791a49ad5ac19f791c3b17b871ed3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 14:55:14.000000000', 'message': "Allow failed actions to expire after 3 minutes

As explained here[0], setting failure-timeout=3m means that the cib will
'forget' that a resource agent action failed:
- if 3 minutes have elapsed from the last failure
- if an event wakes up the policy engine (i.e. at the global resource
  recheck in an idle cluster)

Since monitor intervals seem to generally be set at 5s (though it's up
to the relations to decide that), and with the recheck interval down to
1m, this effectively means that failures will be forgotten after about 36 to
48 continuously successful readings

[0] https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/en-US/Pacemaker/1.1/html-single/Pacemaker_Explained/#_failure_response

Change-Id: Ia958a8c5472547c7cf0cb4ecd7e70cb226074b88
Closes-Bug: 1802310
"}, {'created': '2019-05-24 13:58:13.000000000', 'message': "Allow failed actions to expire after 3 minutes

As explained here[0], setting failure-timeout=3m means that the cib will
'forget' that a resource agent action failed:
- if 3 minutes have elapsed from the last failure
- if an event wakes up the policy engine (i.e. at the global resource
  recheck in an idle cluster)

Since monitor intervals seem to generally be set at 5s (though it's up
to the relations to decide that), and with the recheck interval down to
1m, this effectively means that failures will be forgotten after about 36 to
48 continuously successful readings

[0] https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/en-US/Pacemaker/1.1/html-single/Pacemaker_Explained/#_failure_response

Change-Id: Ia958a8c5472547c7cf0cb4ecd7e70cb226074b88
Closes-Bug: #1802310
"}, {'created': '2019-05-31 21:15:14.000000000', 'message': "Enable custom failure-timeout configuration

As explained here[0], setting failure-timeout means that the cib will 'forget'
that a resource agent action failed by setting failcount to 0:
- if $failure-timeout seconds have elapsed from the last failure
- if an event wakes up the policy engine (i.e. at the global resource
  recheck in an idle cluster)

By default the failure-timeout will be set to 0, which disables the feature,
however this change allows for tuning.

[0] https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/en-US/Pacemaker/1.1/html-single/Pacemaker_Explained/#_failure_response

Change-Id: Ia958a8c5472547c7cf0cb4ecd7e70cb226074b88
Closes-Bug: #1802310
"}]
commit_message:
Enable custom failure-timeout configuration

As explained here[0], setting failure-timeout means that the cib will 'forget'
that a resource agent action failed by setting failcount to 0:
- if $failure-timeout seconds have elapsed from the last failure
- if an event wakes up the policy engine (i.e. at the global resource
  recheck in an idle cluster)

By default the failure-timeout will be set to 0, which disables the feature,
however this change allows for tuning.

[0] https://clusterlabs.org/pacemaker/doc/en-US/Pacemaker/1.1/html-single/Pacemaker_Explained/#_failure_response

Change-Id: Ia958a8c5472547c7cf0cb4ecd7e70cb226074b88
Closes-Bug: #1802310

commit_message:
update _numa_fit_instance_cell for the support of virtual_pmems

_numa_fit_instance_cell is used to get the instance cell based on
a fitted host cell. It will be called by numa_topology_filter to
find out fitted hosts for the instance, so we can update this to
support NUMA affinity. Also it will be called by instance_claim
when building an instance to update the instance's numa_topology.

Partiallly-Implements: blueprint virtual-persistent-memory

Co-Authored-By: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

Change-Id: Ie6a3d8a903aa3c705b273998412a246c7c1e87fd

[{'created': '2019-05-29 06:54:57.000000000', 'message': 'Add floatingip plugin in devstack

Floating-ip plugin is partially supported in Stein release, but it is
not enabled by default for environment built by devstack because of
lack of the plugin configuration in blazar.conf file.

This patch adds the new plugin to the configuration file in
devstack environment.

Change-Id: Ifd43c21ccefbbe643849a8a825e61eb8bb63bd9c
Blueprint: floatingip-reservation
'}]
commit_message:
Add floatingip plugin in devstack

Floating-ip plugin is partially supported in Stein release, but it is
not enabled by default for environment built by devstack because of
lack of the plugin configuration in blazar.conf file.

This patch adds the new plugin to the configuration file in
devstack environment.

Change-Id: Ifd43c21ccefbbe643849a8a825e61eb8bb63bd9c
Blueprint: floatingip-reservation

commit_message:
Add release note for the Distributed OVSDB events work

This patch is a follow-up adding a release note for the work adding a
new mechanism to handle OVSDB events in a distributed way.

The release note is important to make people aware of the change itself
as well as the new dependency on the tooz library.

Related-Bug: #1823715
Change-Id: I79b2aa4c9f09cc1b0cbff8e0252d28c5f4ea2a2c
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-22 12:48:08.000000000', 'message': 'Added mount fstype based validation of Quobyte mounts

The validation of Quobyte mounts is extended to validate based
on a mounts file system type being set to "fuse.quobyte".
This includes adding a new StaleVolumeMount exception type to
the Nova exceptions.
This also closes a bug concerning multi-registry configurations
for Quobyte volumes due to no longer using the is_mounted()
method that failed in that case.
Finally this adds exception handling for the unmount call that
is issued on trying to mount an already mounted volume.

Closes-Bug: #1730933
Closes-Bug: #1737131

Change-Id: Ia5a23ce1123a68608ee2ec6f2ac5dca02da67c59
(cherry picked from commit 05a73c0f3a9f8edf9024f9870279bc6fb7bba2e7)

Besides, this adds exception handling for the unmount call that

commit_message:
Fixes multi-registry config in Quobyte driver

This closes a bug concerning multi-registry configurations
for Quobyte volumes due to no longer using the is_mounted()
method that failed in that case.
Besides, this adds exception handling for the unmount call that
is issued on trying to mount an already mounted volume.

NOTE: The original commit also added a new feature (fs type
based validation) which is omitted in this backport.

Closes-Bug: #1737131

Change-Id: Ia5a23ce1123a68608ee2ec6f2ac5dca02da67c59
(cherry picked from commit 05a73c0f3a9f8edf9024f9870279bc6fb7bba2e7)

commit_message:
Fix CRD update on SG rule creation

The CRD is not updated with the created SG rule
when a Network Policy that contains more than one selector
in the ingress/egress rules and a pod that matches any selector
that is not the first are created.
This commit fixes the issue by ensuring the flag that indicates
when the CRD needs update is not overwritten when handling each
selector.

Change-Id: I02c9b9929a3156d9d40e5aeefef5456f6befa0ab
Closes-Bug: 1829041

subject: Specification for support pxe/IPMI boot for instance
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 7166, 'name': 'Sylvain Bauza', 'email': 'sbauza@redhat.com', 'username': 'sbauza'}, {'_account_id': 15888, 'name': 'Zhenyu Zheng', 'email': 'zheng.zhenyu@outlook.com', 'username': 'Kevin_Zheng'}, {'_account_id': 22290, 'name': 'hyunsik Yang', 'email': 'yangun@dcn.ssu.ac.kr', 'username': 'hyunsikYang'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-06-21 05:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-06-21 06:15:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-06-21 06:51:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-07-03 19:24:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

This is almost exactly what I proposed a year and a half ago. :-)

Details inline about why it wasn't accepted at the time and possible paths forward."}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-07-04 13:02:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > This is almost exactly what I proposed a year and a half ago. :-)
 > 
 > Details inline about why it wasn't accepted at the time and
 > possible paths forward.

Hello Ben Nemec

I understood current situation and I have a question about it.

First, I want to use this proposal for deploying OPNFV.

When jump server installs the OPNFV environment, Jump server turn on/off server several times using IPMI according to procedure and it also uses a PXE for installing OS.

Exactly, Jump server turn off the physical server after PXE setting and when jump server is ready to deploy, it turn on the server.

In this situation, we thought the case of using rescue mode.

If we use a rescue mode, the opnfv install procedure is like below.

1. Jump server configures the Target server as a pxe boot mode. 
   In this scenario, configuration request message goes to the vBMC and it changes the request message from pxe boot request to rescue mode request and then it sends to the nova instance. 


2. Target server boots as a rescue_pxe mode and tries to find TFTP server (Jump server).
   ( Target server can’t find TFTP since TFTP is not ready and then Target server will change the boot option.)

3. Jump server sends shut down message to the Target server using IPMI. But, it occurs error. Because rescue mode doesn't have a power option controls.

4. Jump server sends turn on message to the Target server using IPMI. But it occurs error since Target server already was running rescue mode.


5. Jump server is ready, but, Target server will not work. Because Target server already changed boot mode due to the step2.

when we change the code to try to connect until the target server is connected to the tftp server, we can prevent the error in step 2.

I don’t know we can configure the ipxe like above. 
However, even we use this way, every user should setup ipxe image for this.
Therefore, if my proposal is not against the nova policy, I want to contribute it

Because this is simple and easy way to support pxe for instance."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-23 19:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-10-23 20:36:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Are you allowed to change the BDM after initial boot? I guess that's the only possible drawback I could see. Making it instance metadata allows the setting to be changed on the fly.

That said, at this point I could probably be convinced to compromise on that. Even if we could only set the boot order statically for a given instance it would be better than using a PXE image."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-24 12:27:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Are you allowed to change the BDM after initial boot? I guess that's the only possible drawback I could see. Making it instance metadata allows the setting to be changed on the fly.

Sorry but why does it need to change after the initial boot?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-10-24 13:41:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > Are you allowed to change the BDM after initial boot? I guess
 > that's the only possible drawback I could see. Making it instance
 > metadata allows the setting to be changed on the fly.
 > 
 > Sorry but why does it need to change after the initial boot?

In my case because I'm writing an IPMI controller and I want it to behave as much like a real IPMI controller as possible. That means Ironic should be able to change the boot device to disk after deployment.

However, it isn't a strict requirement because after deployment Ironic stops serving PXE to the node so even if it tries to net boot it just fails and falls back to disk."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-10-24 16:11:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I'm pretty against to have a boot behaviour managed by userdata. MHO is that I feel it should be set by the image (if end-user) or flavor (if admin) but I could be wrong."}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2019-06-03 06:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-27 16:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-05-27 17:20:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You should probably provide a spec for this blueprint first.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-05-30 10:55:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-19146 : SUCCESS in 1h 22m 34s'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-30 13:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:08:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

There are no tests for this, the blueprint isn't approved, there would need to be a release note, and what about specifying hw:boot via the image properties?

The process for proposing specless blueprints for approval can be found here:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/blueprints.html#specs

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/readme.html#trivial-specifications"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:09:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

This would need a spec, and a different implementation.

We had previously NAKd the ability to force the instance to PXE boot, since it completely sidesteps most of what nova is doing for the instance. The preferred way to do this is just upload an iPXE image to glance, let nova boot it like normal, and then provision from there.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:10:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We would also need the hw:boot flavor extra spec documented in here:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/flavors.html#extra-specs'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:46:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-19158 : SUCCESS in 1h 18m 54s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-05-30 20:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

However, in the current OpenStack environment, NOVA manages the lifecycle of the VM, so IPMI operation based on KVM does not work normally.

Therefore, this proposal intends to add a function for normal control of IPMI and PXE in NOVA.

commit_message:
support pxe boot between the VM

When Virtual machine which run on the OpenStack are used to
deploy the cloud environment such as OPNFV, IPMI and PXE should
operate well like as a physical server.
However, in the current OpenStack environment, NOVA manages
the lifecycle of the VM, so IPMI operation based on KVM doesn't work normally.
To support this, NOVA should support IPMI and PXE.
Therefore, this proposal intends to add a function for normal control of IPMI
and PXE in NOVA.

Change-Id: I3d340841ba9db01d81ecf0774cfaca1faf4dde6d
Implements: blueprint  support-nova-pxe

commit_message:
Adds support force delete resources

This patch adds '--force' parameter to vnf delete command,
to force delete VNF instances.

e.g: openstack vnf delete --force VNF1

blueprint force-delete-resources

Co-Authored-By: Dharmendra Kushwaha <dharmendra.kushwaha@india.nec.com>
Change-Id: I457f237d23022259a30ae1c19ea8d5203344512e

commit_message:
Fix the path of the panel navigator

This commit also introduces an admin_urls module, because there
are two containers panels (admin and project) and each panel
need to have a dedicate instance of urlpatterns.
In before, both panels share the same urlpattern in the urls
module, which lead to issues that both panels try to set
the 'dashboard' and 'panel' parameters in the same view.
As a result, the UI could use the wrong dashboard and panel
to render the view.

Change-Id: I046742fa5889be6b2cf9e616b7fd2f62928c7147
Closes-Bug: #1822925

commit_message:
rgw keystone setup fix python interpreter

When using a user defined setup host, we need to set
openstack_service_setup_host_python_interpreter, this fix make the
playbook use it if provided.

Change-Id: Ia97608fc192e2238b37b9eab0fedadfdcb3a8c0f
Closes-Bug: 1830220
(cherry picked from commit dbf0e55b132be7cf398a88788d9bdf0c24c23a66)

commit_message:
Quote keypair name in keypair panel

In Openstack Pike version,
Key pair name has multiple spaces and cannot be deleted
under keypair panel
This patch is quote keypair name.

Change-Id: I337f09056dcf94ac4d0440db1246b4c602d4c3e5
Closes-Bug: #1824959

commit_message:
Fix typo in publish-infra-index

It's "subpath" not "sub_path" - fix typo in publish-infra-index so that
publishing works again.

The typo was introduced in https://review.opendev.org/662604, this
change should really fix the job.

Change-Id: Ib0d40aff3b902c6662733fcfdf90b54c12c52558

commit_message:
Add region to Monasca Log API

This is required for upcoming log query support and it also
causes an error in the Keystone middleware if it's missing.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I2bcb32bc0c079c799d2b0e45a97b454d38896986

subject: Fix publish-infra-index job
messages: [{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-06-01 07:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-01 11:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-06-01 12:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-02 16:02:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-01 07:46:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix publish-infra-index job

We publish currently to /project-config, see
http://files.openstack.org/docs/project-config/ and
http://logs.openstack.org/a0/a0e4c65d653df3078df4c118c911928ccbafbe80/post/publish-infra-index/2916962/ara-report/result/298fd932-b3be-4f00-b2be-b6c2dfe0f5a6/

Set afs_sub_path instead of afs_path, so that the value is propagated
corectly to the playbook at
https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/publish/openstack-afs.yaml#L7

Change-Id: I090132cbb53143b469cc55c890e0639324627973
'}]
commit_message:
Fix publish-infra-index job

We publish currently to /project-config, see
http://files.openstack.org/docs/project-config/ and
http://logs.openstack.org/a0/a0e4c65d653df3078df4c118c911928ccbafbe80/post/publish-infra-index/2916962/ara-report/result/298fd932-b3be-4f00-b2be-b6c2dfe0f5a6/

Set afs_sub_path instead of afs_path, so that the value is propagated
corectly to the playbook at
https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/publish/openstack-afs.yaml#L7

Change-Id: I090132cbb53143b469cc55c890e0639324627973

commit_message:
Retiring TripleO-UI

Removing master from jobs but keeping stable branches on.

Retire completely ansible-role-tripleo-ui, it's unused.

Update ansible and hacking versions

We run ansible 2.7 with zuul, so update the version we use for linting.

Update hacking to current versions to get new versions of pep8 as well.

To share docker registries between build nodes, we need this port
open.

[{'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-14 12:58:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-14 14:38:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-02-17 22:57:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-18 13:40:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-18 13:51:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Ian: My main motivation for this was hoping that splitting py2-based system packages from a py3-based openstack installation might help with uncapping pip again, see https://review.openstack.org/561597. 

If that doesn't work out, I'm fine with dropping Centos7 here, though I'm still worried what centos users will be facing next year, then."}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-19 09:41:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-02-19 10:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-19 11:52:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-20 14:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-02-20 14:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-03-28 16:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-03-29 18:46:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-29 20:13:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-04-01 08:27:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-03 06:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-04-03 09:41:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Ian: So in order to avoid wrongly interpreting this, do you object to using py36 and would like to see py35 instead? Or are you claiming that centos7 folks will continue to use py27 even when it is EOLd upstream and we should cater for that?

The issue is that there seems to be no easy way to remove the "pip<10" cap running with py27, because there are lots of dependencies in various system packages. Nobody has volunteered to work on that, either.

We could decide to keep the cap only for centos7, but that would make that job a special snowflake in a different way, which I'm not sure is the better solution.

We did keep the pip cap in place for almost a year now and I think that was way too long, so in the interest of devstack as a whole, I'd rather drop centos7 support than keeping the cap for another cycle.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-04-03 12:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-04-03 12:36:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Anyway, I dropped the centos7 part of this change, so that we can proceed with the remainder that is hopefully uncontroversial and handle the centos question independently.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-04-03 15:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-04-15 19:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-05-28 16:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

Looks like this has centos 7 back to running on python2. LGTM'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-06-02 13:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-06-02 13:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

lgtm'}]

commit_message:
Make most platform jobs run with python3

python2.7 will be EOL soon, let's test on python3 instead.
Exclude CentOS 7, as there is no python3 easily available.

Change-Id: I24d8812c0c37b6d376fd5ae38067513bb62a2804

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I7baf4fd7aeef4b012268fd95208019c1fa744fef

hmm, I have mixed feeling here. We encourage to use stestr directly instead of ostestr command now..'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-04 14:46:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I feel like there's a pretty big difference between saying "we recommend you use another tool" and "this tool is unmaintained; if you run into issues, you *must* use another tool".

FWIW, requirements recently updated stestr to 2.3.1, which broke all of swift's func tests. We've got https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651277/ working its way through the gate now to allow 9 other already-approved patches to land; I'll look at what needs to change to use stestr directly instead next.

Even then, though, having this bad interaction negatively impacts my ability to

- bring up swift services from master,
- have a separate checkout from an older tag, and
- run the old functional tests against the newer service

as the old version will still want to invoke ostestr with --serial.'}, {'account_id': 8655, 'date': '2019-05-06 10:00:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8655, 'date': '2019-05-06 10:07:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> hmm, I have mixed feeling here. We encourage to use stestr directly
 > instead of ostestr command now..

Do you have any links where this is recommended? I found only Matthew's message on the ML that states "Moving forward I'd like to get everything switched over to using stestr, either
directly or indirectly via ostestr.".

If it's true to call stestr directly, it might be good to issue a warning message when running ostestr to increase visibility of the transition.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-05-06 10:30:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-05-06 10:32:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Default concurrency to 0 to avoid TypeError in stestr

The traceback would look like

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".../bin/ostestr", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File ".../os_testr/ostestr.py", line 263, in main
    exit(ostestr(sys.argv[1:]))
  File ".../os_testr/ostestr.py", line 259, in ostestr
    return _select_and_call_runner(opts, regex, others)
  File ".../os_testr/ostestr.py", line 212, in _select_and_call_runner
    black_regex=opts.black_regex)
  File ".../os_testr/ostestr.py", line 167, in call_testr
    black_regex=black_regex)
  File ".../stestr/commands/run.py", line 334, in run_command
    concurrency = _to_int(concurrency)
  File ".../stestr/commands/run.py", line 39, in _to_int
    i = int(possible)
TypeError: int() argument must be a string or a number, not 'NoneType'

New enough stestr will tolerate it, but still write a warning to stderr.
See https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/commit/ac8dac0

Change-Id: I70a3ed6c3edaafc8bb6269b1ae07bd46b06f4db4

commit_message:
Support using name in show and delete templates

Vitrage can show and delete templates by name
So remove the constraints on using only uuid
in CLI for deleting templates

renamed the parameters also to be more clear

Change-Id: Iaf68f994bdceee4a01ca445bde935ca42077f541

[{'created': '2019-01-14 14:09:20.000000000', 'message': "Use correct variable for default certificate paths

The variable {{ node_config_directory }} is used for the configuration
directory on the remote hosts, and should not be used for paths on the
deploy host (localhost).

This changes the default value of the TLS certificate and CA file to
reference {{ CONFIG_DIR }}, in line with the directory used for
admin-openrc.sh (as of I0709482ead4b7a67e82796e17f85bde151e71bc0).

This change also introduces a variable, {{ node_config }}, that
references {{ CONFIG_DIR | default('/etc/kolla') }}, to remove
duplication.

Change-Id: Ibd82ac78630ebfff5824c329d7399e1e900c0ee0
Closes-Bug: #1804025
(cherry picked from commit 9223deeecd5a6c6efa238463962ea8604d4ce103)
"}]
commit_message:
Use correct variable for default certificate paths

The variable {{ node_config_directory }} is used for the configuration
directory on the remote hosts, and should not be used for paths on the
deploy host (localhost).

This changes the default value of the TLS certificate and CA file to
reference {{ CONFIG_DIR }}, in line with the directory used for
admin-openrc.sh (as of I0709482ead4b7a67e82796e17f85bde151e71bc0).

This change also introduces a variable, {{ node_config }}, that
references {{ CONFIG_DIR | default('/etc/kolla') }}, to remove
duplication.

Change-Id: Ibd82ac78630ebfff5824c329d7399e1e900c0ee0
Closes-Bug: #1804025
(cherry picked from commit 9223deeecd5a6c6efa238463962ea8604d4ce103)

commit_message:
Update json module to jsonutils

oslo project provide jsonutils, and the others use it in many place,
this PS to update the json module to oslo jsonutils for consistency.

Change-Id: I2051af567c0ea0c142169fe08731029658a2cc9a

commit_message:
rgw keystone setup fix python interpreter

When using a user defined setup host, we need to set
openstack_service_setup_host_python_interpreter, this fix make the
playbook use it if provided.

Change-Id: Ia97608fc192e2238b37b9eab0fedadfdcb3a8c0f
Closes-Bug: 1830220

[{'created': '2019-05-26 18:04:06.000000000', 'message': 'Allow driver to properly unplug VIFs on destination on confirm resize

Update PCI related VIFs with the original PCI address on the source
host to allow the virt driver to properly unplug VIFs from

from the integration bridge in case of a hardware offloaded OVS.

While other approaches are possible for solving the issue,

commit_message:
Allow driver to properly unplug VIFs on destination on confirm resize

Update PCI related VIFs with the original PCI address on the source
host to allow the virt driver to properly unplug VIFs from
hypervisor, e.g allow the proper VF representor to be unplugged
from the integration bridge in case of a hardware offloaded OVS.

While other approaches are possible for solving the issue,
The approach proposed in the series allows the fix to be safely
backported.

Closes-Bug: #1809095

Conflicts:
    nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

Change-Id: Id3c4d839fb1a6da47cfb366b65c0904d281a218f
(cherry picked from commit 000e93df09fd4941bb69f715c955b940871a1ec6)

commit_message:
Use oslo_middleware to support CORS configuration

Currently there is no way in Qinling configuration file
to configure the CORS.

oslo_middleware should be implemented to be able to
set [cors] section in qinling.conf.

Change-Id: Ib4664ba7cbda28a9dfda1c1dd9f0e7457c0ee7de
Story: 2005788
Task: 33515

commit_message:
optimize the description in the image creatation page.

the description is not a required field in the image form
but the error message seems to say, the description is required,
which can be confusing to cloud users.

Change-Id: I2cf40ed2cd0ba6132c0e042f40677a38843f5da3

commit_message:
Removing existing dirs from .gitignore

There are a couple of dirs present in the neutron tree that have
erroneously been added to the .gitignore file with [0]. Drop those so
that content there may be regularly updated again.

Affected directories:

- bin/
- neutron/tests/functional/agent/linux/bin/
- devstack/lib/
- neutron/tests/var/

[0] https://review.opendev.org/632094

Change-Id: Id56f61965bfc4ba3dcce3319cfda467d89f897b1

subject: Update the heat service egg name to openstack_heat
messages: [{'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-06-01 18:55:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-06-01 18:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-01 19:24:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-01 18:55:36.000000000', 'message': "Update the heat service egg name to openstack_heat

In https://review.openstack.org/606160 the dist name was changed
from 'heat' to 'openstack-heat'. The egg name needs to be updated
or the package will fail to install or be usable.

This is needed in Rocky because the change for the heat package name
was backported. As of the recent Rocky SHA bump[1], Heat will no
longer build in OSA without this fix.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/334096f6a9e84acbceca64ef08d1390fdb790da3

Related: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650438/
Change-Id: Ida55bc030800c512d64bb715f704697875cd5738
(cherry picked from commit 3621ce76b706a1707cc986859f4c7b5eaa0b1f23)

commit_message:
Update the heat service egg name to openstack_heat

In https://review.openstack.org/606160 the dist name was changed
from 'heat' to 'openstack-heat'. The egg name needs to be updated
or the package will fail to install or be usable.

This is needed in Rocky because the change for the heat package name
was backported. As of the recent Rocky SHA bump[1], Heat will no
longer build in OSA without this fix.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/334096f6a9e84acbceca64ef08d1390fdb790da3

Related: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650438/
Change-Id: Ida55bc030800c512d64bb715f704697875cd5738
(cherry picked from commit 3621ce76b706a1707cc986859f4c7b5eaa0b1f23)

commit_message:
kvm: add support for booting uefi instances

In order to boot UEFI instances successfully, the OVMF image
must be installed and located at the path that is hardcoded
inside Nova.

This patch takes care of installing the OVMF images and sets
up links to point towards the hardcoded path for operating
systems that don't install at the expected path.

Change-Id: I62f4aa26ffd0d2f3ba4aa19fbdb72578ef0223e4
Closes-Bug: #1825386
Closes-Bug: #1831279

commit_message:
Add element to install all openstack clients

Let's add an element to ensure all the python openstack clients are
properly installed on the controllers. These were previously being
pulled in because we installed the actual services. Since we moved to
containers, these clients are no longer installed by default.

Closes-Bug: #1829769
Change-Id: I551d6ac2d064bff05862b3ffa025240657fafd36

commit_message:
Remove  code that supports  older version falcon

In the requierment.txt, falcon version is required to be greater than 1.0 ("falcon>=1.0"),
So remove code that supports older version falcon.

Change-Id: I803397a6b0f0269d1548718aa8826f0a73521405

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-20 12:11:26.000000000', 'message': 'Disable some CI jobs

Why we need to run Trove functional jobs for python-troveclient?
Especialy, the python-troveclient-tempest-neutron-src is running all
the core tempest jobs which are definitely unrelated to either Trove or
python-troveclient.

Disable those jobs until we have good reasons.

Change-Id: I91b41e19d40bc09cb883ef18d26949613196c439
'}]
commit_message:
Disable some CI jobs

Why we need to run Trove functional jobs for python-troveclient?
Especialy, the python-troveclient-tempest-neutron-src is running all
the core tempest jobs which are definitely unrelated to either Trove or
python-troveclient.

Disable those jobs until we have good reasons.

Change-Id: I91b41e19d40bc09cb883ef18d26949613196c439

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-06 22:14:08.000000000', 'message': "Remove the server_default value for spares_pool table creation

A new table was introduced in the commit
a205ab3ebe4ae14668f25328c062f9383d6c69cb, although `server_default` was
removed in the subsequent commit
0b468090e6eef1483f6f7c53708f500802a57d51, the db migration script still
fails for some database backend such as MariaDB 5.5 which doesn't
support `DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP`[1][2]. What's more, the
`server_default` is actually doing nothing during the db migration.

This patch removes `server_default` in the migration script.

Story: #2005578
Task: #30767

[1]: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/sqlalchemy/h8hiDfpLKkE
[2]: https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/mariadb-1001-release-notes/#new-features-re-implemented-from-a-similar-mysql-feature

Change-Id: I94712562ae65c7d19b79a5482a5238b4c9549b50
"}]
commit_message:
Remove the server_default value for spares_pool table creation

A new table was introduced in the commit
a205ab3ebe4ae14668f25328c062f9383d6c69cb, although `server_default` was
removed in the subsequent commit
0b468090e6eef1483f6f7c53708f500802a57d51, the db migration script still
fails for some database backend such as MariaDB 5.5 which doesn't
support `DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP`[1][2]. What's more, the
`server_default` is actually doing nothing during the db migration.

This patch removes `server_default` in the migration script.

Story: #2005578
Task: #30767

[1]: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/sqlalchemy/h8hiDfpLKkE
[2]: https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/mariadb-1001-release-notes/#new-features-re-implemented-from-a-similar-mysql-feature

Change-Id: I94712562ae65c7d19b79a5482a5238b4c9549b50

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I713b33a9ecb2c1767e09ff8bc6568b146d859909

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-26 18:04:06.000000000', 'message': 'Move get_pci_mapping_for_migration to MigrationContext

In order to fix Bug #1809095, it is required to update
PCI related VIFs with the original PCI address on the source
host to allow virt driver to properly unplug the VIF from hypervisor,
e.g allow the proper VF representor to be unplugged
from the integration bridge in case of a hardware offloaded OVS.

To do so, some preliminary work is needed to allow code-sharing
between nova.network.neutronv2 and nova.compute.manager

This change:
- Moves common logic to retrieve the PCI mapping between
  the source and destination node from nova.network.neutronv2
  to objects.migration_context.
- Makes code adjustments to methods in nova.network.neutronv2
  to accomodate the former.

Change-Id: I9a5118373548c525b2b1c2271e7d210cc92e4f4c
Partial-Bug: #1809095
(cherry picked from commit 5a1c385b996090b80f5881680e04c88abc21828a)
'}]
commit_message:
Move get_pci_mapping_for_migration to MigrationContext

In order to fix Bug #1809095, it is required to update
PCI related VIFs with the original PCI address on the source
host to allow virt driver to properly unplug the VIF from hypervisor,
e.g allow the proper VF representor to be unplugged
from the integration bridge in case of a hardware offloaded OVS.

To do so, some preliminary work is needed to allow code-sharing
between nova.network.neutronv2 and nova.compute.manager

This change:
- Moves common logic to retrieve the PCI mapping between
  the source and destination node from nova.network.neutronv2
  to objects.migration_context.
- Makes code adjustments to methods in nova.network.neutronv2
  to accomodate the former.

Change-Id: I9a5118373548c525b2b1c2271e7d210cc92e4f4c
Partial-Bug: #1809095
(cherry picked from commit 5a1c385b996090b80f5881680e04c88abc21828a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 18:00:59.000000000', 'message': 'DEMO: Update instance.availability_zone on revertResize

When resizing a server that was not created in an explicit
zone, the scheduler can pick a host in another zone and
conductor will update the instance.availability_zone value
for the new dest host zone.

The problem is when reverting the resize, the server goes
back to the original source host/zone but the
instance.availability_zone value in the database is not
updated which can lead to incorrect results when listing
servers and filtering by zone.

This fixes the bug by updating the instance.availability_zone
value in the API (where we have access to the aggregates
table in the API DB) before casting to nova-compute to
complete the revert. As noted in the comment within, this
is not fail-safe in case the revert fails before the
instance.host is updated in finish_revert_resize, but we
don't have a lot of great backportable options here that
don't involve "up-calls" from the compute to the API DB.

Change-Id: I927e105f9fc9303391e498140016d194ccfca0f0
Closes--Bug: #1819963
'}, {'created': '2019-04-17 18:04:47.000000000', 'message': 'DEMO: Update instance.availability_zone on revertResize

When resizing a server that was not created in an explicit
zone, the scheduler can pick a host in another zone and
conductor will update the instance.availability_zone value
for the new dest host zone.

The problem is when reverting the resize, the server goes
back to the original source host/zone but the
instance.availability_zone value in the database is not
updated which can lead to incorrect results when listing
servers and filtering by zone.

This fixes the bug by updating the instance.availability_zone
value in the API (where we have access to the aggregates
table in the API DB) before casting to nova-compute to
complete the revert. As noted in the comment within, this
is not fail-safe in case the revert fails before the
instance.host is updated in finish_revert_resize, but we
don't have a lot of great backportable options here that

commit_message:
DEMO: Update instance.availability_zone on revertResize

When resizing a server that was not created in an explicit
zone, the scheduler can pick a host in another zone and
conductor will update the instance.availability_zone value
for the new dest host zone.

The problem is when reverting the resize, the server goes
back to the original source host/zone but the
instance.availability_zone value in the database is not
updated which can lead to incorrect results when listing
servers and filtering by zone.

This fixes the bug by updating the instance.availability_zone
value in the API (where we have access to the aggregates
table in the API DB) before casting to nova-compute to
complete the revert. As noted in the comment within, this
is not fail-safe in case the revert fails before the
instance.host is updated in finish_revert_resize, but we
don't have a lot of great backportable options here that
don't involve "up-calls" from the compute to the API DB.

Change-Id: I927e105f9fc9303391e498140016d194ccfca0f0
Closes-Bug: #1819963

commit_message:
DEMO: Functional recreate test for bug 1819963

When resizing a server that was not created in an explicit
zone, the scheduler can pick a host in another zone and
conductor will update the instance.availability_zone value
for the new dest host zone.

The problem is when reverting the resize, the server goes
back to the original source host/zone but the
instance.availability_zone value in the database is not
updated which can lead to incorrect results when listing
servers and filtering by zone.

This adds a functional recreate test for the bug.

through the process of fixing a bug by introducing a patch that proves
the broken behavior, and then putting a patch to fix it on top. I'm
going to do this with bug 1819963, so this patch reverts the substance
of [1] and [2] so I can repropose trimmed-down versions of those for the
demo.

[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643155/

"}]
commit_message:
DNM: DEMO: Reinstate bug 1819963

For the Nova onboarding session at the Train summit, I'm going to walk
through the process of fixing a bug by introducing a patch that proves
the broken behavior, and then putting a patch to fix it on top. I'm
going to do this with bug 1819963, so this patch reverts the substance
of [1] and [2] so I can repropose trimmed-down versions of those for the
demo.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643151/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643155/

Change-Id: I0bac991207480ee4d1cf2fb8a63d168aec0c3be3

commit_message:
Make OVS controller inactivity_probe configurable

This parameter applies to the OVSDB Controller table when the
native openflow driver is used. There are reports that increasing
it can reduce errors on busy systems. This patch also sets the
default value to 10s which is more than the OVS default of 5s.
See the ovs-vswitchd.conf.db man page for full description.

Change-Id: If0d42919412dac75deb4d7f484c42cea630fbc59
Partial-Bug: #1817022
(cherry picked from commit 540d00f68ecf1c11b0296922f965ef60d15d1a86)

commit_message:
Use instance mappings to count server group members

This adds a get_count_by_uuids_and_user() method to the InstanceMapping
object and uses it to count instance mappings for the purpose of
counting quota usage for server group members. By counting server group
members via instance mappings, the count is resilient to down cells in
a multi-cell environment.

Part of blueprint count-quota-usage-from-placement

Change-Id: I3ff39d5ed99a68ad8678e5ff62b343f3018b4768

commit_message:
Use list instead of six.viewkeys to avoid py2 to py3 problems

This change fixes an 'RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during
iteration' error that is raised because of different behaviour between
python2 and python3.  An earlier attempt [1] to use the six library did
not fix the issue.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/660427

Resolves-Bug: #1829304
Change-Id: Ic4c5790a5d66e10a606327f4f4e4c92611f161d8
(cherry picked from commit a65ae9c81eea909133446c0be4d54ce389f6e0e1)

commit_message:
Use list instead of six.viewkeys to avoid py2 to py3 problems

This change fixes an 'RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during
iteration' error that is raised because of different behaviour between
python2 and python3.  An earlier attempt [1] to use the six library did
not fix the issue.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/660427

Resolves-Bug: #1829304

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-28 18:16:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add regression recreate test for bug 1830747

Before change I4244f7dd8fe74565180f73684678027067b4506e in Stein, when
a cold migration would reschedule to conductor it would not send the
RequestSpec, only the filter_properties. The filter_properties contain
a primitive version of the instance group information from the RequestSpec
for things like the group members, hosts and policies, but not the uuid.
When conductor is trying to reschedule the cold migration without a
RequestSpec, it builds a RequestSpec from the components it has, like the
filter_properties. This results in a RequestSpec with an instance_group
field set but with no uuid field in the RequestSpec.instance_group.
That RequestSpec gets persisted and then because of change
Ie70c77db753711e1449e99534d3b83669871943f, later attempts to load the
RequestSpec from the database will fail because of the missing
RequestSpec.instance_group.uuid.

The test added here recreates the pre-Stein scenario which could still
be a problem (on master) for any corrupted RequestSpecs for older
instances.

Change-Id: I05700c97f756edb7470be7273d5c9c3d76d63e29
Related-Bug: #1830747
'}, {'created': '2019-05-31 19:19:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add regression recreate test for bug 1830747

Before change I4244f7dd8fe74565180f73684678027067b4506e in Stein, when
a cold migration would reschedule to conductor it would not send the
RequestSpec, only the filter_properties. The filter_properties contain
a primitive version of the instance group information from the RequestSpec
for things like the group members, hosts and policies, but not the uuid.
When conductor is trying to reschedule the cold migration without a
RequestSpec, it builds a RequestSpec from the components it has, like the
filter_properties. This results in a RequestSpec with an instance_group
field set but with no uuid field in the RequestSpec.instance_group.
That RequestSpec gets persisted and then because of change
Ie70c77db753711e1449e99534d3b83669871943f, later attempts to load the
RequestSpec from the database will fail because of the missing
RequestSpec.instance_group.uuid.

The test added here recreates the pre-Stein scenario which could still
be a problem (on master) for any corrupted RequestSpecs for older
instances.

Change-Id: I05700c97f756edb7470be7273d5c9c3d76d63e29
Related-Bug: #1830747
'}]
commit_message:
Add regression recreate test for bug 1830747

Before change I4244f7dd8fe74565180f73684678027067b4506e in Stein, when
a cold migration would reschedule to conductor it would not send the
RequestSpec, only the filter_properties. The filter_properties contain
a primitive version of the instance group information from the RequestSpec
for things like the group members, hosts and policies, but not the uuid.
When conductor is trying to reschedule the cold migration without a
RequestSpec, it builds a RequestSpec from the components it has, like the
filter_properties. This results in a RequestSpec with an instance_group
field set but with no uuid field in the RequestSpec.instance_group.
That RequestSpec gets persisted and then because of change
Ie70c77db753711e1449e99534d3b83669871943f, later attempts to load the
RequestSpec from the database will fail because of the missing
RequestSpec.instance_group.uuid.

The test added here recreates the pre-Stein scenario which could still
be a problem (on master) for any corrupted RequestSpecs for older
instances.

Change-Id: I05700c97f756edb7470be7273d5c9c3d76d63e29
Related-Bug: #1830747

commit_message:
Move _fill_provider_mapping to the scheduler_utils

The _fill_provider_mapping is called during boot and reschedule so far
but to support move operations with ports having resource request we
need to call it during various coductor tasks. So this patch move the
function to the utils and adjust the name and the signature accordingly.

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports

Change-Id: I76f777e4f354b92c55dbd52a20039e504434b3a1

[{'created': '2019-05-31 12:06:14.000000000', 'message': "Return None for attributes of sd with no actions

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and
that results in TypeError as we try to make an rpc call to
show the software deployment for None.

Change-Id: Iefd3cdd20bb51c63e7267ae0628e0f15544c0427
Task: 33516
(cherry picked from commit ee061103477ed7c9b4692a8b90817a127064fbcd)
"}]
commit_message:
Return None for attributes of sd with no actions

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and
that results in TypeError as we try to make an rpc call to
show the software deployment for None.

Change-Id: Iefd3cdd20bb51c63e7267ae0628e0f15544c0427
Task: 33516
(cherry picked from commit ee061103477ed7c9b4692a8b90817a127064fbcd)

subject: Spec for Grafana proxy datasource
messages:
[{'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-14 15:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-14 15:42:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(9 comments)

Some comments and questions inline. It's unfortunate that with the grafana datasource you still have to have db-specific translators, which seems like it's not much better than just adding new db-specific datasources like for influxdb, but maybe the advantage is grafana handles the aggregation for those backends so you don't have to use something like influxdb cluster software (which is closed source and licensed)?"}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-14 17:15:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (9 comments)
 > 
 > Some comments and questions inline. It's unfortunate that with the
 > grafana datasource you still have to have db-specific translators,
 > which seems like it's not much better than just adding new
 > db-specific datasources like for influxdb, but maybe the advantage
 > is grafana handles the aggregation for those backends so you don't
 > have to use something like influxdb cluster software (which is
 > closed source and licensed)?

The primary advantage is that you have a single endpoint you have to know the url for and authenticate with. Of course the functionality could be extended if Grafana allows it for example I have yet to investigate what is new in Grafana 6."}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-14 17:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-14 17:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-14 21:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-15 06:08:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)

I am uncertain if Grafana will be able to 'aggregate' depending on what you mean by that. Let me explain step by step.

Every datasource / instance in Grafana gets a project id.
Every instance of influxdb could contain multiple databases / 'schema's just like a mysql server.

Keep in mind that what Grafana calls datasources is what I call instances in this explanation because otherwise it would get confusing with the datasource definition from Watcher.

To scale we have many influxdb instances all with a single database this prevents having to pay for the enterprise version of influxdb.

The configuration of the new datasource will allow to specify a project, database per metric so each metric can be retrieved from a different influxdb instance and later even different types of instances.

So to retrieve different metrics Watcher will query grafana with different project ids which in turn will make requests to different instances. In my opinion this means the aggregation is done in Watcher and not by Grafana. Furthermore, this has the limitation that you can not spread a single metric across multiple instances of influxdb.

I hope this clarifies."}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-05-15 07:45:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > I am uncertain if Grafana will be able to 'aggregate' depending on
 > what you mean by that. Let me explain step by step.
 > 
 > Every datasource / instance in Grafana gets a project id.
 > Every instance of influxdb could contain multiple databases /
 > 'schema's just like a mysql server.
 > 
 > Keep in mind that what Grafana calls datasources is what I call
 > instances in this explanation because otherwise it would get
 > confusing with the datasource definition from Watcher.
 > 
 > To scale we have many influxdb instances all with a single database
 > this prevents having to pay for the enterprise version of influxdb.
 > 
 > The configuration of the new datasource will allow to specify a
 > project, database per metric so each metric can be retrieved from a
 > different influxdb instance and later even different types of
 > instances.
 > 
 > So to retrieve different metrics Watcher will query grafana with
 > different project ids which in turn will make requests to different
 > instances. In my opinion this means the aggregation is done in
 > Watcher and not by Grafana. Furthermore, this has the limitation
 > that you can not spread a single metric across multiple instances
 > of influxdb.
 > 
 > I hope this clarifies.

I wish you add these explanation to spec."}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-05-16 09:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Spec for Grafana proxy datasource

Spec for a new datasource to collect metrics using Grafana as a proxy
to the databases it integrates with.

Change-Id: Id224bf37a72347e634567c933c42a12ef9b048d3
Implements: blueprint grafana-proxy-datasource

commit_message:
Remove fake_libvirt_utils from libvirt imagebackend tests.

I can't really explain why there was so much mocking of
methods that only appear in fake_libvirt_utils (but not
libvirt.utils) here. I guess we're just lucky.

Change-Id: I9a9dab1dd71073ce94f40c782fd6c0275144265f

commit_message:
Notify ironic on port status changes

This patch adds an ironic notifier that sends notifications
to ironic endpoint /v1/events. The events are triggered by
port updates and deletions. Only ports with vnic_type
baremetal are honored.

Story: 1304673
Task: 22263
Closes-Bug: #1828367
Implements: blueprint event-notifier-ironic
Authored-By: Vasyl Saienko <vsaienko@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Harald Jensås <hjensas@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Julia Kreger <juliaashleykreger@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0bb3187a88a7f20adb8c60e24945db159afb83f1

commit_message:
mistral-event-engine: only import ::tripleo::profile::base::mistral

::tripleo::profile::base::mistral is the only puppet manifest that is
needed since ::mistral::event_engine (imported by
tripleo::profile::base::mistral::event_engine) does nothing else but
configuring services, installing packages (things we don't need with
containers) and configuring some parameters that aren't overriden in
THT.

Change-Id: I4a54742671446f07b2fbd1fa230b4fb5b133db8a

commit_message:
Rebuild initramfs after applying change in kernel parameters

This patch makes sure that initramfs is rebuilt after applying
change in kernel pamraters, so that we also have these change
applied in initramfs.

Change-Id: I3de131c022e183cb29aa1c5c9913af736afd0c4d
Closes-Bug: #1830574
(cherry picked from commit 3ef8e3e35dbb43414becc4f561830bb731643ead)
(cherry picked from commit 65471401b694cca93798a59ed9875474dab43c82)

commit_message:
Remove fake_libvirt_utils from virt driver tests.

We were mocking this for all virt drivers, and the replacement to
the big scary magical thing is trivial.

Change-Id: I2f90d6b109fe319f6b03fab9a3a2e2ca5c4e54e6

[{'created': '2019-05-30 17:55:25.000000000', 'message': 'update sriov config docs for live migration support.

- In the train release of Nova SR-IOV live migration
  support was added to the libvirt virt driver.
- This change updated the admin config docs to reflect
  that live migration is now supported.

Change-Id: I429d2477d1b379de06d666edbdef4a9afcfe4b5d
'}]
commit_message:
update sriov config docs for live migration support.

- In the train release of Nova SR-IOV live migration
  support was added to the libvirt virt driver.
- This change updated the admin config docs to reflect
  that live migration is now supported.

Change-Id: I429d2477d1b379de06d666edbdef4a9afcfe4b5d

commit_message:
Elasticsearch: kill process after data node drain

This updates the Elasticsearch entrypoint override for the data
nodes to include a signal to kill the process after the trap to
drain each data node completes

Change-Id: Iccd4342fe16d06787cb24342d9a57e4de12e6980

commit_message:
Check ACLs for all namespaces

Remove hardcoded list of namespaces with iterating over all directories
in the check of valid ACLs.

Remove parameter, we don't need to pass it in.

Be more verbose and report directories scanned and number of ACL files
read.

Change-Id: I4193ac59b431d31f3ce835c93950745e5b742418

commit_message:
Fluentd: Use fqdn hostname for Elasticsearch service

This moves Fluentd to use the helm-toolkit endpoint lookup for
using the fqdn for the Elasticsearch hostname instead of the
standard short host name

Change-Id: Ibe640979002331693f0a9b6155c9014572294664
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 12:05:54.000000000', 'message': "Return None for attributes of sd with no actions

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and
that results in TypeError as we try to make an rpc call to
show the software deployment for None.

Change-Id: Iefd3cdd20bb51c63e7267ae0628e0f15544c0427
Task: 33516
(cherry picked from commit ee061103477ed7c9b4692a8b90817a127064fbcd)
"}]
commit_message:
Return None for attributes of sd with no actions

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and
that results in TypeError as we try to make an rpc call to
show the software deployment for None.

Change-Id: Iefd3cdd20bb51c63e7267ae0628e0f15544c0427
Task: 33516
(cherry picked from commit ee061103477ed7c9b4692a8b90817a127064fbcd)
