Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-21 19:01:21.000000000', 'message': 'Allow match_ip in LrNatDelCommand to be IP network

__init__ of LrNatDelCommand in schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py takes
optional match_ip parameter to find one or more specific NAT Table rows
of a logical router to delete. This match_ip is searched in the
"logical_ip" column for NAT rows of type "snat" and in "external_ip"
column for other types. While "external_ip" column value has to be an
IP address, "logical_ip" column value can be IPv4 network or
IP address. Currently the code only allows match_ip to be an IP address
and raises an error when an IP network is passed.

This change allows match_ip to be IP network when NAT type is "snat".

Closes-Bug: #1825740
Change-Id: I90dfdb5b5fe625ca8af768dfe9dac10f6d3c1430

commit_message:
Allow match_ip in LrNatDelCommand to be IP network

__init__ of LrNatDelCommand in schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py takes
optional match_ip parameter to find one or more specific NAT Table rows
of a logical router to delete. This match_ip is searched in the
"logical_ip" column for NAT rows of type "snat" and in "external_ip"
column for other types. While "external_ip" column value has to be an
IP address, "logical_ip" column value can be IPv4 network or
IP address. Currently the code only allows match_ip to be an IP address
and raises an error when an IP network is passed.

This change allows match_ip to be IP network when NAT type is "snat".

Closes-Bug: #1825740
Change-Id: I90dfdb5b5fe625ca8af768dfe9dac10f6d3c1430

subject: Distributed OVSDB lock: Make use of the HashRing
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1131, 'name': 'Brian Haley', 'email': 'haleyb.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-haley'}, {'_account_id': 5756, 'name': 'Terry Wilson', 'email': 'twilson@redhat.com', 'username': 'otherwiseguy'}, {'_account_id': 6773, 'name': 'Lucas Alvares Gomes', 'email': 'lucasagomes@gmail.com', 'username': 'lucasagomes'}, {'_account_id': 8655, 'name': 'Jakub Libosvar', 'email': 'libosvar@redhat.com', 'username': 'jlibosva'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23804, 'name': 'Daniel Alvarez', 'email': 'dalvarez@redhat.com', 'username': 'dalvarez'}]

I expect tempest to be good tho but functional and unit needs some work."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-04-25 13:53:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-09 08:41:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-09 13:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

recheck

pep8 should be fixed now'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-10 08:37:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck pep8 should be fixed now'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-22 09:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-05-22 11:01:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Impressive, I've been testing the patch and as per our conversation on IRC, my only concern is with regards to the startup. When many workers connect at the same time, the hash ring cache of each worker will/may differ from other workers leading to OVSDB events being processed multiple times.

While this shouldn't be a big deal in terms of data consistency, it may cause unnecessary processing (e.g. router scheduling), calls to the plugin (eg. updating the parent port of a subport) or API calls (eg. Neutron to Nova) that would lead to a possible delay in the startup time of neutron-server.

Let's see if we can think of a way for handling this. I'll -1 for now to bring the discussion but the patch looks awesome otherwise!"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-22 11:05:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Impressive, I've been testing the patch and as per our conversation
 > on IRC, my only concern is with regards to the startup. When many
 > workers connect at the same time, the hash ring cache of each
 > worker will/may differ from other workers leading to OVSDB events
 > being processed multiple times.
 > 
 > While this shouldn't be a big deal in terms of data consistency, it
 > may cause unnecessary processing (e.g. router scheduling), calls to
 > the plugin (eg. updating the parent port of a subport) or API calls
 > (eg. Neutron to Nova) that would lead to a possible delay in the
 > startup time of neutron-server.
 > 
 > Let's see if we can think of a way for handling this. I'll -1 for
 > now to bring the discussion but the patch looks awesome otherwise!

Thanks for bringing it up!

After talking on IRC we discussed the possibility of the cache kicking in only after the first time the node is touched (created_at != updated_at). That would make it cacheless when things are started up."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-22 12:14:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-22 12:14:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

'}, {'created': '2019-05-09 08:41:07.000000000', 'message': 'Distributed OVSDB lock: Make use of the HashRing

Changes:

* New OvnIdlDistributedLock class added. This is now the base class
  which the NB and SB OVSDBs IDLs will inherit from. The old OvnIdl
  class was kept because services like the Metadata agent and Octavia
  driver uses it and for those services the OVSDB lock seems sufficient
  (but nothing prevents us from updating them too in the future)

* A new pre_fork_initialize() hook was added to the mechanism driver.
  This hook runs before the process is forked (to create the workers)
  and it does two things:

  - Set a signal handler for SIGTERM. So, in case where a SIGTERM is
    sent the service will handle it and clean up the Hash Ring before
    exiting.

  - Clean up the Hash Ring at start up. If there's some leftover (in
    case of a SIGKILL for example) the workers will be considered part
    of the Hash Ring until they timeout. And in the start of the service
    we can get rid of those dead entries.

* Remove OvnWorker: The OvnWorker was responsible for running the
  ovn_db_sync() code and handling the events from OVSDB. Now, this
  patch moved the ovn_db_sync() into the MaintenanceWorker and since
  OVSDB events are now handled by all other workers in parallel there's
  no more use for the OvnWorker and it has been removed from the code.

* The unittests test_notify_no_ovsdb_lock() and
  test_notify_ovsdb_lock_not_yet_contended() were converged into a single
  test called test_notify_different_target_node(). Different from the
  OVSDB lock that has "locked" and "lock contended" the Hash Ring only
  cares about whether the hash matches with the node_uuid of the
  instance or not.

Closes-Bug: #1823715
Change-Id: I00b24cd1f8eaae2386d732af34365fa1f81e565a
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Distributed OVSDB lock: Make use of the HashRing

Changes:

* New OvnIdlDistributedLock class added. This is now the base class
  which the NB and SB OVSDBs IDLs will inherit from. The old OvnIdl
  class was kept because services like the Metadata agent and Octavia
  driver uses it and for those services the OVSDB lock seems sufficient
  (but nothing prevents us from updating them too in the future)

* A new pre_fork_initialize() hook was added to the mechanism driver.
  This hook runs before the process is forked (to create the workers)
  and it does two things:

  - Set a signal handler for SIGTERM. So, in case where a SIGTERM is
    sent the service will handle it and clean up the Hash Ring before
    exiting.

  - Clean up the Hash Ring at start up. If there's some leftover (in
    case of a SIGKILL for example) the workers will be considered part
    of the Hash Ring until they timeout. And in the start of the service
    we can get rid of those dead entries.

* Remove OvnWorker: The OvnWorker was responsible for running the
  ovn_db_sync() code and handling the events from OVSDB. Now, this
  patch moved the ovn_db_sync() into the MaintenanceWorker and since
  OVSDB events are now handled by all other workers in parallel there's
  no more use for the OvnWorker and it has been removed from the code.

* The unittests test_notify_no_ovsdb_lock() and
  test_notify_ovsdb_lock_not_yet_contended() were converged into a single
  test called test_notify_different_target_node(). Different from the
  OVSDB lock that has "locked" and "lock contended" the Hash Ring only
  cares about whether the hash matches with the node_uuid of the
  instance or not.

Closes-Bug: #1823715
Change-Id: I00b24cd1f8eaae2386d732af34365fa1f81e565a
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

OvS-DPDK requires the vhostuser socket directory to be
specific directory, which need to be shared between OvS
and qemu. Deployer will create a directory with required
access permissions. OVN should use the provided directory
to create the vhostuser sockets.

commit_message:
Add DPDK support for OVN

OvS-DPDK requires the vhostuser socket directory to be
specific directory, which need to be shared between OvS
and qemu. Deployer will create a directory with required
access permissions. OVN should use the provided directory
to create the vhostuser sockets.

Change-Id: Idf81990d4075f4332d99326170ed733452a85cab
(cherry picked from commit c24b1dd86d54a939ed0a044e1d09eb1afc5dc4c1)

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I896a0640e7fb0a12d50c89e1964641a9e9e37976

commit_message:
xenapi: log quality warning in init_host

The xenapi driver has not had working third party CI
for several months. As a result, this change logs a
warning on startup of the service in the init_host
method indicating the lack of testing and the possibility
that the driver may be deprecated in the future if the
situation does not change.

This was discussed at the 2019-05-30 nova meeting [1] and
also at the Train PTG.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2019/nova.2019-05-30-14.00.log.html

Change-Id: I7f8eb7d5c5a9b1cb0a8d5e607d719b49a22675d3

commit_message:
extract baselineCPU API call from _get_cpu_traits()

_get_cpu_traits() in the libvirt driver was quite complicated, dealing
with multiple modes of the guest CPU model config, and also invoking
libvirt's baselineCPU API.  This made it hard to see at a glance the
flow through the method, and which variables were used where.

So extract the baselineCPU API call into a separate method, resulting
in clearer variable scoping.  Also document the API call and its
inputs and outputs, based on the official API docs:

https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-host.html#virConnectBaselineCPU

Change-Id: I6f42da5e2fd2e65d31b8e9191e3dff98b011d0bf

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and

commit_message:
Return None for attributes of sd with no actions

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and
that results in TypeError as we try to make an rpc call to
show the software deployment for None.

Change-Id: Iefd3cdd20bb51c63e7267ae0628e0f15544c0427
Task: 33516
(cherry picked from commit ee061103477ed7c9b4692a8b90817a127064fbcd)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-30 14:23:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix regression with SW deployments when region not configured

The region name eventually has to pass through an os-collect-config.conf
file, the format of which is unable to distinguish between the JSON null
(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528
(cherry picked from commit d580565abff2997002eff856535bdfd2ddb44da7)

(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528
(cherry picked from commit d580565abff2997002eff856535bdfd2ddb44da7)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix regression with SW deployments when region not configured

The region name eventually has to pass through an os-collect-config.conf
file, the format of which is unable to distinguish between the JSON null
(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528
(cherry picked from commit d580565abff2997002eff856535bdfd2ddb44da7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-30 11:23:13.000000000', 'message': "cleanup evacuated instances not on hypervisor

When the compute host recovers from a failure the compute manager
destroys instances that were evacuated from the host while it was down.
However these code paths only consider evacuated instances that are
still reported by the hypervisor. This means that if the compute
host is recovered in a way that the hypervisor lost the definition
of the instances (for example the compute host was redeployed) then
the allocation of these instances will not be deleted.

This patch makes sure that the instance allocation is cleaned up
even if the driver doesn't return that instance as exists on the
hypervisor.

Note that the functional test coverage will be added on top as it needs
some refactoring that would make the bugfix non backportable.

Change-Id: I4bc81b482380c5778781659c4d167a712316dab4
Closes-Bug: #1724172
(cherry picked from commit 9cacaad14e8c18e99e85d9dc04308fee91303f8f)
"}]
commit_message:
cleanup evacuated instances not on hypervisor

When the compute host recovers from a failure the compute manager
destroys instances that were evacuated from the host while it was down.
However these code paths only consider evacuated instances that are
still reported by the hypervisor. This means that if the compute
host is recovered in a way that the hypervisor lost the definition
of the instances (for example the compute host was redeployed) then
the allocation of these instances will not be deleted.

This patch makes sure that the instance allocation is cleaned up
even if the driver doesn't return that instance as exists on the
hypervisor.

Note that the functional test coverage will be added on top as it needs
some refactoring that would make the bugfix non backportable.

Change-Id: I4bc81b482380c5778781659c4d167a712316dab4
Closes-Bug: #1724172
(cherry picked from commit 9cacaad14e8c18e99e85d9dc04308fee91303f8f)

commit_message:
Fix live-migration when glance image deleted

When block live-migration is run on instance with
a deleted glance image, image.cache() is called
without specyfing instance disk size parameter,
preventing the resize of disk on the target host.

Change-Id: Id0f05bb1275cc816d98b662820e02eae25dc57a3
Closes-Bug: #1829000
(cherry picked from commit c1782bacd8461bdd8c833792864e61228fa451f1)

commit_message:
Ensure we don't have any trailing "requires" for paunch units

It might happen people want to disable the health checks in an update.
This change will ensure paunch cleans things up before (re)creating the
main service unit file, in order to avoid failed dependencies in systemd
configuration.

Change-Id: Ia8ebe35a9edc41f3ec635cc05dde08783c5e2a44
(cherry picked from commit ecc2047b2ec5eaf39cce119abe1678ac19139d79)

commit_message:
Corrected how health check unit and link are removed

I681fa0eb225d43ecbaa1b765f6761dd07031bce1 introduced some logic and
links between main service and its health check. The removal wasn't that
clean, so this patch intends to make things faster and cleaner.

We also remove the "systemctl daemon-reload" call, since it's useless:
its only value is for modified units, and here we're stopping, disabling
and deleting units.

This last change allows to get a cleaner, safer removal of the health
check dependency.

Change-Id: Ib5d61ed0e3b85dfbc256cb46cbfb611f8a785d71
(cherry picked from commit 52d0b2d5f557e199b757826289b06a8951496621)

commit_message:
Introduce the systemctl module to provide simple systemctl commands wrap

Centralize all the subprocess dedicated to call systemctl in a dedicated
wrapper to ensure straightforward usage and dedicated unit test less
in a functional approach and also reduce the technical debt.

This module can continue to evolve to reflect the real systemctl command
signatures and dedicated parameters and related checks if needed.

Change-Id: Ia0e278bf5731aa5d09739d54f4db64dbaf85d037
(cherry picked from commit 2567495f158903a9adb6ee1be2fda383103c9416)

(9 comments)

I just wonder if this level of dynamically-adjusted micro-resources is appropriate for a compute abstraction layer like Nova. Where is the "abstraction" any more?'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-04-24 06:09:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-04-24 13:28:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(31 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-04-29 22:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-04-30 07:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(26 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-05-02 21:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

My summit-brained summary of what I said in the PTG session here:

1. Make nova capable of reading a yaml (.d directory hopefully) description of additional resource inventory during u-p-t, which it will squash into its own inventory as reported to placement
2. RMD on the host can write things like cache regions or whatever into that, which will be exposed in placement by nova-compute
3. Flavors can be updated to include standard resource overrides for those things (i.e. resource:CUSTOM_CACHE=4) so that static resource counts of these fancy resources get included in the scheduler decisions
4. RMD on the host can do its under-the-covers massaging of resources directly on the instances, reading policy information from the instance flavors if desired.

tl;dr; no initial nova changes directly for RMD, but we add the generic extra resource function to nova-compute to enable the scheduling component and assume RMD can do the enforcement completely out of band.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-30 16:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1 Workflow-1

Per discussions at the Train PTG [1], the RMD effort is going in a different direction, so this spec can be abandoned. I'm putting a -W on it for now to get it off the "open train specs" dashboard [2].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005809.html
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:openstack/nova-specs+status:open+path:%255Especs/train/approved/.*+NOT+label:Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-05-30 18:24:51.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

RMD integration with OpenStack will be decoupled and hence this proposal is abandoned. For next steps, we will continue to progress from directions obtained at the Train PTG here - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005809.html'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-31 18:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> My summit-brained summary of what I said in the PTG session here:
> 
> 1. Make nova capable of reading a yaml (.d directory hopefully) description of additional resource inventory during u-p-t, which it will squash into its own inventory as reported to placement
> 2. RMD on the host can write things like cache regions or whatever into that, which will be exposed in placement by nova-compute
> 3. Flavors can be updated to include standard resource overrides for those things (i.e. resource:CUSTOM_CACHE=4) so that static resource counts of these fancy resources get included in the scheduler decisions
> 4. RMD on the host can do its under-the-covers massaging of resources directly on the instances, reading policy information from the instance flavors if desired.
> 
> tl;dr; no initial nova changes directly for RMD, but we add the generic extra resource function to nova-compute to enable the scheduling component and assume RMD can do the enforcement completely out of band.

@Dan, the file format is being picked up in this spec: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/612497/'}]

commit_message:
Resource Management Daemon - Base Enablement

We propose a solution for OpenStack Nova to leverage the RMD to manage a subset of host resources traditionally not visible to Nova. These are resources that shall allow more fine grain resource control for more predictable performance. This will require running RMD on the compute nodes along with RMD plugins to interface each resource it supports and modifying Nova Compute.

Implements: blueprint rmd-base-enablement

Change-Id: I85ee16635ad80a3ceef8806b8b3bea0e70304565
Signed-off-by: Dakshina Ilangovan  <dakshina.ilangovan@intel.com>

commit_message:
Ensure Pod SG is updated on podSelector of NP spec update

When the podSelector of a Network Policy Spec is updated from '{}'
to any other value, the pods that are not supposed to be enforced
by the policy anymore do not have their Security Group updated
to the default one. This commit fixes the issue by also taking into
account the possible value of '{}' in the podSelector NP spec.

Change-Id: I35519acfdf8ef250880e36bcf789c063ba86b31e
Closes-Bug: 1826548
(cherry picked from commit 59e761afbf838d10484baeb0564db9ae4d5867b1)

commit_message:
Remove Newton from image builds

During the last PTG, we discussed about removing the support of
Newton image building. As nobody was interested in maintaining
newton, there is no reason to test this anymore.

Without this patch, we'll continue to CI test Newton, and should
a failure happen, nobody will care to fix it. It has therefore
no purpose.

To not break compatibility or existing tooling, this patch
removes Newton from CI builds, and doesn't remove the wrapper
script we provide in openstack/loci/.

Change-Id: If2d60001da03930064afa4d873d8597aeb8f2ee7

[{'account_id': 29455, 'date': '2019-05-30 19:58:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-05-30 20:00:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
ceph-base: Update ceph-ansible default playbook

The main ceph-ansible playbook for containerized deployment is named
site-container.yml because it isn't only used for docker.
Currently the site-docker playbook is a symlink to site-container and
this symlink will probably be remove in the future.

Change-Id: Ie623e91517f2b310d58181233f06bc3e7c9e9c71
(cherry picked from commit c450bae2ba7717a3fd0d2116b3d901d50a511d4d)

Rebuild initramfs after applying change in kernel parameters

This patch makes sure that initramfs is rebuilt after applying
change in kernel pamraters, so that we also have these change
applied in initramfs.

Change-Id: I3de131c022e183cb29aa1c5c9913af736afd0c4d
Closes-Bug: #1830574
(cherry picked from commit 3ef8e3e35dbb43414becc4f561830bb731643ead)

commit_message:
neutron: force project_name for midonet & bigswitch

Related to https://review.opendev.org/661416
In TripleO we use 'service', and not 'services'.
So we need to force the midonet & bigswitch configs to be 'service'.

Change-Id: If04a3f055ce9ebb1bdfeb20cbf82638fadcda71a

commit_message:
novajoin: set project_name to service

Related to https://review.opendev.org/661418
We use 'service' in TripleO so we need to ensure that
novajoin is using the right project name even if the upstream changes in
puppet-nova.

Change-Id: Ie82e10774066fcfb91708691bb59500998dbf465

commit_message:
Support configuring Monasca Persister performance

On a single node deployment, the Monasca persister can
limit the rate at which Monasca can persist metrics to
InfluxDB. Increasing the thread count can remove this
bottle neck.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I763a5ae6aa8c8ab3bf766ab5b58c386da74a188b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 09:33:16.000000000', 'message': 'Restrict Rocky on Leap 15.0

The default base image for opensuse/leap:15 is now pointing
to 15.1 on dockerhub.

In LOCI, we are using opensuse/leap:15 as base image by
default. It is not a problem, as we are always targetting
master in LOCI.

However, Rocky is older, and the upper-constraints for
libvirt currently points to 4.6.0, which is unable to build
on leap 15.1, due to 15.1 having a too recent version of
libvirt.

This fixes the requirements building by ensuring Rocky
will always stay on a 15.0 base.

Change-Id: I033f1f5dc39c47b748b3887f25e1dfa02fc0f800
'}]
commit_message:
Restrict Rocky on Leap 15.0

The default base image for opensuse/leap:15 is now pointing
to 15.1 on dockerhub.

In LOCI, we are using opensuse/leap:15 as base image by
default. It is not a problem, as we are always targetting
master in LOCI.

However, Rocky is older, and the upper-constraints for
libvirt currently points to 4.6.0, which is unable to build
on leap 15.1, due to 15.1 having a too recent version of
libvirt.

This fixes the requirements building by ensuring Rocky
will always stay on a 15.0 base.

Change-Id: I033f1f5dc39c47b748b3887f25e1dfa02fc0f800

[{'created': '2019-03-13 11:50:49.000000000', 'message': 'Move get_pci_mapping_for_migration to MigrationContext

In order to fix Bug #1809095, it is required to update
PCI related VIFs with the original PCI address on the source
host to allow virt driver to properly unplug the VIF from hypervisor,
e.g allow the proper VF representor to be unplugged
from the integration bridge in case of a hardware offloaded OVS.

To do so, some perliminary work is needed to allow code-sharing
between nova.network.neutronv2 and nova.compute.manager

This change:
- Moves common logic to retireve the PCI mapping between
  the source and destination node from nova.network.neutronv2
  to objects.migration_context.
- Makes code adjustments to methods in nova.network.neutronv2
  to accomodate the former.

commit_message:
Move get_pci_mapping_for_migration to MigrationContext

In order to fix Bug #1809095, it is required to update
PCI related VIFs with the original PCI address on the source
host to allow virt driver to properly unplug the VIF from hypervisor,
e.g allow the proper VF representor to be unplugged
from the integration bridge in case of a hardware offloaded OVS.

To do so, some preliminary work is needed to allow code-sharing
between nova.network.neutronv2 and nova.compute.manager

This change:
- Moves common logic to retrieve the PCI mapping between
  the source and destination node from nova.network.neutronv2
  to objects.migration_context.
- Makes code adjustments to methods in nova.network.neutronv2
  to accomodate the former.

Change-Id: I9a5118373548c525b2b1c2271e7d210cc92e4f4c
Partial-Bug: #1809095

openstack namespace.

commit_message:
Rename x/compute-hyperv to openstack/compute-hyperv

compute-hyperv is now a "Winstackers" team deliverable, for which
reason we're moving it back to the "openstack" namespace.

Change-Id: I876fdf180368bf16b680b71339922a9c2e752c74

commit_message:
Rename charm-lxd to charm-nova-lxd

This better reflects that the (nova-)lxd charm actually configures LXD
for use with nova, and not just LXD in general.

Change-Id: I0cfe05700067be86fcc80e02d73a2148f20def63

So I'm not sure how the dependency should work, but the corresponding project-config change is at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657155/"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-06 17:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmm, I was going by https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html#add-new-repository-to-the-governance-repository which is for new projects, but I don't know what the story is with renames - they've only just now become a thing again. It's possible we have a circular dependency to break."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-09 19:03:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Will push up a new patch."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-09 19:04:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-05-10 08:31:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

LGTM - thanks Tim. Waiting for the gates.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-10 22:40:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

recheck

I think the check job never triggered because of a circular dep. Dropped the depends-on in the project-config change, and we'll see how this behaves..."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 09:48:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

No clue. it would indeed be weird if there are things that need removal, like the zuul files, for re-adding them later..."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 12:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 12:08:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Rollcall-Vote'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-22 13:46:51.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to project-update'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-27 08:18:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I suggest moving them in with x/ and once the repo is renamed by infra (after this lands), you can propose another change that updates the repo name.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-27 08:19:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-28 14:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-28 14:30:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'll leave the ordering up to you guys. Done."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-05-28 15:06:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Food for thought... liberasurecode is written predominantly in C with typical GNU Automake build toolchain, and pyeclib is non-pure-Python with C extensions (unsurprisingly I suppose, it links liberasurecode). Don't get me wrong, I think this is great and I don't think these are reasons not to have them under the scope of OpenStack governance, but these are firsts for us so I want to make sure we think through the policy implications.

First, I assume we build and test these (because if they're not tested they're broken!), but for other languages we document a standard set of project testing interfaces and supported runtimes:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

Do we need to amend that information, perhaps documenting whatever these two projects do as our initial "standard" for C libraries and Python libraries with C extensions?

Second, do we expect to distribute either of these in compiled form or only in source form? If we're shipping builds of either, then our 2017 resolution on binary artifact release management is probably relevant:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20170530-binary-artifacts.html

It was written with things like container images and distro packages in mind, but most of the same concerns likely apply here unless these projects are being distributed as source only. It would be good for the maintainers to review that resolution and let us know whether the guidelines are applicable or whether we need a new resolution superseding it to also provide appropriate guidance for their situation.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-05-28 21:20:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Just to establish/highlight my perspective, my first priority is (must always be) the consumers of the code we've written. That covers end-users, operators, deployers, packagers, other developers, and everyone in between -- and for their sake, I owe them at minimum the answers to a few questions like

- Where do I go to get help?
- Where do I report bugs?
- Where can I find your latest release?

When these projects were first brought under the openstack namespace [1], these answers changed. This was disruptive (there were still new issues getting filed against the old projects for nearly a year after the transition [2]), but worth it to move away from the original authors' personal bitbucket repositories to something more community-oriented.

These were brought in as unofficial projects deliberately, for a few reasons:

- We knew they could be useful beyond OpenStack.
- We were hopeful that an independent community could form around them.
- We did not want to push the Technical Committee to establish broad new policies based on a single project.

With the OpenDev migration [3] and subsequent halting of GitHub mirroring for unofficial projects [4], our answers for those key questions are changing again, which is less than desirable. Just last week I had a packager wondering why he wasn't seeing the latest tag where he expected [5].

My favored resolution to that is to move them back to the openstack namespace; it has been the canonical location for the past three years and it should continue to be. The simplest way to accomplish that (in my mind) is to reflect reality: the Swift community owns and maintains these projects. While we have had some interest from other developers, I would not say an independent community has formed. So, make the projects official Swift deliverables, rename the projects, and then the names and URLs from two months ago work again.

Perhaps this is the wrong approach -- I wasn't intending to create a lot of governance work or change how we test and deliver code. Certainly, I would hesitate to recommend OpenStack-wide policies based upon a single sample. Still, in light of the contributor history and lacking a better organization under which these should live, returning to the status quo seemed to make sense. Again, I just want to ensure existing links work and accurately reflect the community that's driving development.

Regarding the called-out policy implications:

Yes, these are tested. liberasurecode has two make targets (test and valgrind-test) that are run sequentially in the gate on both ubuntu and centos 7. pyeclib uses tox to run tests with latest distro packages of liberasurecode under py27, py35, py36, and py37; there are further tests that run against tip-of-master liberasurecode.

As far as release artifacts, liberasurecode just has tags in a git repository -- we let distro packagers handle builds for various architectures. pyeclib uploads sdists and x86_64 wheels to tarballs.openstack.org [6], as well as sdists to PyPI [7]. We needed to specifically exclude the wheels from being uploaded to PyPI [8] which would reject them. At first look, I don't see any divergences from the binary-artifacts resolution for those wheels, but if it would simplify matters, I'm fairly certain we'd be content to just stop producing them -- the recommended ways to install pyeclib are (in rough order of freshness):

- from distro packages,
- via pip (which will download and compile the sdist from PyPI), or
- from source, typically as tip-of-master.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/314724/
[2] https://bitbucket.org/kmgreen2/pyeclib/issues/
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005011.html
[4] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005629.html
[5] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-swift/%23openstack-swift.2019-05-24.log.html#t2019-05-24T16:59:34
[6] http://tarballs.openstack.org/pyeclib/
[7] https://pypi.org/project/pyeclib/#files
[8] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649455/"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-05-28 21:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks! Policy wise, it sounds to me like the most we'd need to do to accommodate these is to simply document that we use the GCC/Automake toolchain versions for our target distros in the PTI as our tested runtime, and I don't even feel like that needs to be done before we accept these project additions (but I've no doubt some other TC members will weigh in on that too).

It wasn't immediately apparent that the loss of GitHub mirroring from the OpenDev migration was the initial motivation for this change, and I feel compelled to point out that there are solutions. Projects like https://github.com/openstack/ara-web/ and https://github.com/openstack/airship-shipyard/ worked with the OpenDev sysadmin team to "transfer" them to a different GH org where they have admin rights, and each adds a single $project-upload-git-mirror zuul job to their post pipelines (I'd recommend the release pipeline too) which updates that mirror continuously.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-28 23:57:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

Policy-wise, I think pycelib is a no-brainer: you install it with pip; it's a Python project for all intents and purposes.

liberasurecode is slightly different. We depend on lots of C libraries in OpenStack, but in most cases we don't actually maintain them. In this case, however, the Swift team is actually the owner of this project. I'm a believer in governance documents reflecting reality on the ground, so if this is the path the Swift team want to take I have no objection - in particular I'm not concerned that people will take this as precedent for rewriting OpenStack in C ;)

Of course if the Swift team wanted to continue to pursue the path of trying to form a standalone community around this by creating a separate namespace on OpenDev (and mirroring it to GitHub, with appropriate redirects from the old openstack namespace), then I'd be fine with that as well."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-29 13:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

Agree we might want to adjust some documents to document how to do similar cases in the future, but otherwise in this case it sounds like a more accurate reflection of the current reality (that those repos are maintained by the Swift team, as a part of Swift), so +1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-29 17:41:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-29 19:36:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-05-29 21:59:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-30 12:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-05-30 15:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-05-30 15:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-05-30 15:09:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-30 15:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-05-30 15:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

Agree this reflects reality :)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-05-31 15:47:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Improve behaviour of VIFHandler

Previously VIFHandler run through all the vifs
waiting it to be active. If neutron ports was not
active then exception was raised and new pod state
was not written. Thus each retry VIFHandler should
run through all the vifs even if appropriate neutron
port is active. Check for each neutron port requires
request to neutron that is time consuming process.

This commit allows to update pod state even if state
of single port was changed regardless exceptions for
other ports.

Change-Id: I6f74831831e33c7f1bdbc04df78601f9522d9212
Signed-off-by: Danil Golov <d.golov@samsung.com>

This change enables IPA to receive API endpoints and configuration
via multicast DNS.

Task: #30382
Change-Id: Ibbf07052bea8f5c0305dda098b2879bcbc2fece5

commit_message:
Fix format file message field

The message field for these format files wasn't renamed when
the input field was renamed. This problem was masked by Monasca
which renames the message field back to 'message' for the Fluentd
Monasca output plugin.

Change-Id: I2674958b1e64efddbca4765fefa55431261648e6
Closes-Bug: #1819168
(cherry picked from commit e5d564136b479e83da71ad08d31783a3f793314d)

commit_message:
Fix unreliability of check_remote_as_state() in scenario tests

This change adds simple, limited polling to check_remote_as_state()
as it can be subject to failures stemming from simple timing issues.

Change-Id: Ib354f20702f98227b7d0abbdf283561930a29afd

commit_message:
Drop use git.openstack.org for tox deps

[{'created': '2019-05-30 18:36:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix tripleo::haproxy::stats to be more correct and flexible

1) We make the class parameter 'ip' also be a list so that multiple

a breaking change for operators. We could think about deprecating it

commit_message:
Fix tripleo::haproxy::stats to be more correct and flexible

In this change we do three things:
1) We make the class parameter 'ip' also be a list so that multiple
   bind addresses are possible
2) We remove the hard coded 1993 and move it to a parameter
3) Instead of passing only the controller_virtual_ip as the only bind
   address on all controllers which makes no sense (see linked LP)
   we also bind to the IP specified in the hiera key
   'tripleo::haproxy::haproxy_stats_bind_address'.

Tested this change with the accompanying THT patch and correctly
got the haproxy stats on a custom network (internal_api and the
controller vip):

listen haproxy.stats
  bind fd00:fd00:fd00:2000::16:1993 transparent
  bind 192.168.24.15:1993 transparent
  mode http
  stats enable
  stats uri /
  stats auth admin:password

I did not remove the controller_virtual_ip binding as that might be
a breaking change for operators. We could think about deprecating it
and removing it eventually.

Related-Bug: #1830334
Change-Id: Iab5f11c3065ff34a3543621554e7f05161d069f2
(cherry picked from commit e76519d2c8324e71db1871e2a9219eb66d0ce5c4)

subject: Fix haproxy stats network binding
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-05-31 06:11:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-05-31 10:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-05-31 12:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 06:11:16.000000000', 'message': "Fix haproxy stats network binding

a) The haproxy.stats stanza in haproxy config file has pretty much remained the same since newton:
listen haproxy.stats
  bind 192.168.24.8:1993 transparent
  mode http
  stats enable
  stats uri /
  stats auth admin:tRJre6PnQuN4ZwqKYUygTJArB

b) what we do today with the haproxy stats makes little sense:
- we bind it to the VIP running on the control-plane network on all controller nodes
- de facto we allow to look at the haproxy stat info via web only on the node holding the ctlplane VIP
- since haproxy does not share stats across nodes, we're effectively
  limited at looking at the stats info on a single node.

Now imagine ctrl-0 holding the internal_api VIP and ctrl-1 holding the
ctlplane VIP. Basically now the only stats you will be able to see are
the ones relative to keystone_admin (which for other silly reasons has
been moved to ctlplane by default) and very little else.

Tested this and am able to bind the haproxy stat to another network
and to have it listen to the IP of the node on said network (in addition
to the ctrlplane vip which we do not remove as it might break stuff):

    listen haproxy.stats
      bind fd00:fd00:fd00:2000::16:1993 transparent
      bind 192.168.24.15:1993 transparent
      mode http
      stats enable
      stats uri /
      stats auth admin:password

Closes-Bug: #1830334

Depends-On: Iab5f11c3065ff34a3543621554e7f05161d069f2

Change-Id: If2ee15f1e0fcf6d077cba524fad75dec7e1144b6
(cherry picked from commit 45f5c283e32e4753360c4e4c9627043b20a30e24)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix haproxy stats network binding

a) The haproxy.stats stanza in haproxy config file has pretty much remained the same since newton:
listen haproxy.stats
  bind 192.168.24.8:1993 transparent
  mode http
  stats enable
  stats uri /
  stats auth admin:tRJre6PnQuN4ZwqKYUygTJArB

b) what we do today with the haproxy stats makes little sense:
- we bind it to the VIP running on the control-plane network on all controller nodes
- de facto we allow to look at the haproxy stat info via web only on the node holding the ctlplane VIP
- since haproxy does not share stats across nodes, we're effectively
  limited at looking at the stats info on a single node.

Now imagine ctrl-0 holding the internal_api VIP and ctrl-1 holding the
ctlplane VIP. Basically now the only stats you will be able to see are
the ones relative to keystone_admin (which for other silly reasons has
been moved to ctlplane by default) and very little else.

Tested this and am able to bind the haproxy stat to another network
and to have it listen to the IP of the node on said network (in addition
to the ctrlplane vip which we do not remove as it might break stuff):

    listen haproxy.stats
      bind fd00:fd00:fd00:2000::16:1993 transparent
      bind 192.168.24.15:1993 transparent
      mode http
      stats enable
      stats uri /
      stats auth admin:password

Closes-Bug: #1830334

Depends-On: Iab5f11c3065ff34a3543621554e7f05161d069f2

Change-Id: If2ee15f1e0fcf6d077cba524fad75dec7e1144b6
(cherry picked from commit 45f5c283e32e4753360c4e4c9627043b20a30e24)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-30 14:23:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix regression with SW deployments when region not configured

The region name eventually has to pass through an os-collect-config.conf
file, the format of which is unable to distinguish between the JSON null
(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528
(cherry picked from commit d580565abff2997002eff856535bdfd2ddb44da7)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix regression with SW deployments when region not configured

The region name eventually has to pass through an os-collect-config.conf
file, the format of which is unable to distinguish between the JSON null
(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528
(cherry picked from commit d580565abff2997002eff856535bdfd2ddb44da7)

commit_message:
Stop handling 'InstanceUnknownCell' exception

This was only raised by cells v1 code and therefore no longer needs to be
handled. A future change will remove the exception itself.

Part of blueprint remove-cells-v1

Change-Id: I1dd6abcc2be17ff76f108e7ff3771314f33259c6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: [Queens only] Add --ssh-key argument for overcloud update and upgrade. (WIP)
messages:
[{'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-24 13:49:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-24 17:16:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The tests need to be updated to account for this new logic.

I also realized that python-tripleoclient will actually need to read the private key file and store it / pass it as a string.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-29 17:21:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-29 17:40:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-31 14:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is related to features deprecated in Rocky. config-download users should run updates and upgrades with `--ssh-user tripleo-admin`.'}]

commit_message:
[Queens only] Add --ssh-key argument for overcloud update and upgrade.
(WIP)

The functionality to override the SSH user is deprecated in Rocky. [1]
The ability to override the private key is required to resolve
the mentioned BugZilla so this patch targets only the Queens branch.

1. https://review.opendev.org/#/c/615829

Change-Id: I8db61fe01a986331cc03120e0abadf9462399c17
Resolves: rhbz#1690096
Depends-On: I63f1e61c960fce7f280b83125bdc31a86c58b930
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

subject: [Queens only] Allow a custom SSH key during updates and upgrades. (WIP)
messages:
[{'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-24 13:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-24 17:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My goal here is to have private_key only be looked up if it has not been provided. I have a separate patch that sends private_key=null to this workflow from python-tripleoclient. I am not sure if Mistral understand Python's None data type so I used a string of "null".'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-05-27 10:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-05-27 11:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+1 by Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2019-05-27 11:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2019-05-27 11:35:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Hm and sorry the -2, but unless I'm missing something, you should not commit in the stable/queens but in master and then cherry pick this change through the stein/rocky and queens stable branches.

Add me as reviewer if you re-sent the review in master pls."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-29 17:32:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-29 17:50:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I believe I have fixed the Mistral logic to only get the private key if one was not passed to the workflow.

This is required for Queens only because the feature added is related to functionality that is deprecated in Rocky. I did not want to add something with deprecated functionality into Rocky and Stein. More details are provided in the BugZilla.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-05-31 14:34:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is related to features deprecated in Rocky. config-download users should run updates and upgrades with `--ssh-user tripleo-admin`.'}]

This makes sense to me, assuming the assertions in the commit message are true. I'll proxy a +2 if this gets an ack from another ironic core or two."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2019-05-20 10:15:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This makes sense to me too.

So this all seems to stack up.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-05-30 17:11:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-05-30 19:01:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-30 19:27:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-05-31 14:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 95ace7cf8daf4ff935ff6df877554fdfddef9e4a'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-17 14:30:48.000000000', 'message': "[ironic] Don't remove instance info twice in destroy

During teardown, at the end of the ironic virt driver's destroy method,
we call _cleanup_deploy, which since
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/563722/ removes instance_info from the
ironic node. Given that we're destroying the node, the instance_info
will have been cleared from the node anyway, so we don't need to do
this.

Further, it can cause tear down to fail if automated cleaning is
enabled in ironic. This happens because ironic prevents updates to nodes
that are undergoing a state transition, as is the case during cleaning.
The virt driver will retry this request by default every 2 seconds with
60 attempts. Typically this is not long enough for cleaning to complete,
so tear down fails with the following error:

  Conflict: Node a00696d5-32ba-475e-9528-59bf11cffea6 can not be updated
  while a state transition is in progress. (HTTP 409)

This change skips the instance info update in _cleanup_deploy in the
case of tear down.

Change-Id: Iea337f73c231db2cb9d9f639b92475daaede6793
Closes-Bug: #1815799
"}]
commit_message:
[ironic] Don't remove instance info twice in destroy

During teardown, at the end of the ironic virt driver's destroy method,
we call _cleanup_deploy, which since
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/563722/ removes instance_info from the
ironic node. Given that we're destroying the node, the instance_info
will have been cleared from the node anyway, so we don't need to do
this.

Further, it can cause tear down to fail if automated cleaning is
enabled in ironic. This happens because ironic prevents updates to nodes
that are undergoing a state transition, as is the case during cleaning.
The virt driver will retry this request by default every 2 seconds with
60 attempts. Typically this is not long enough for cleaning to complete,
so tear down fails with the following error:

  Conflict: Node a00696d5-32ba-475e-9528-59bf11cffea6 can not be updated
  while a state transition is in progress. (HTTP 409)

This change skips the instance info update in _cleanup_deploy in the
case of tear down.

Change-Id: Iea337f73c231db2cb9d9f639b92475daaede6793
Closes-Bug: #1815799

commit_message:
Set external web URL for Prometheus services

This change ensures that URLs returned from these services reference
the HAProxy endpoint, rather than the host on which the service is
running.

Closes-Bug: #1825150
Change-Id: I7f966ff749ea37620f1bde7019a598cb9505fa45
(cherry picked from commit 9d495504be57b30343f3f4c64f86413edfb962ad)

commit_message:
Notify ceph-mon relations on version upgrade.

This notification is added to allow ceph-mon to know
when ceph-osd units have upgraded in order to run
post-upgrade commands (required for certain upgrades).

- Add notify_mon_of_upgrade function that sets
ceph_release to release version.

- Refactor some hard coded strings to vars

- Set relation ceph_release when setting bootstrapped-osd

Change-Id: I708b33cafc8818af7e3c63a7fa80c02978e66f65
Partial-Bug: #1828630

commit_message:
Revert "yum_update.sh improvements"

Containers no longer updated in CentOS7 now,
as yum repoquery is not a command.

This reverts commit c475c8394a033e77134ce40dfa8428d17ea7f3d6.

Change-Id: Id12743c0cf83d054189df10cad2c8abec57961e8

[{'created': '2019-05-31 09:13:53.000000000', 'message': "Updates to support Ceph Nautilus release

For Nautilus the Ceph monitors automatically create the admin and
bootstrap keyrings as part of cluster formation so the charm just
needs to retrieve the admin keyring after the monitors have been
bootstrapped.

As the bootstrap process is two quite distinct steps, this change
refactors the bootstrap_monitor_cluster function into two discrete
functions - one to create and start the ceph monitor, and a second
to create the ceph keyrings on the local filesystem.

As the osd-bootstrap keyring is not actually created on disk from
Nautilus onwards, the 'is_bootstrapped' function now looks for the
client.admin keyring across all Ceph releases - this should be
backwards compatible.

Change-Id: I2dfab7404b72e314625ea554ee64595c5e26f3c6

commit_message:
Updates to support Ceph Nautilus release

For Nautilus the Ceph monitors automatically create the admin and
bootstrap keyrings as part of cluster formation so the charm just
needs to retrieve the admin keyring after the monitors have been
bootstrapped.

As the bootstrap process is two quite distinct steps, this change
refactors the bootstrap_monitor_cluster function into two discrete
functions - one to create and start the ceph monitor, and a second
to create the ceph keyrings on the local filesystem.

As the osd-bootstrap keyring is not actually created on disk from
Nautilus onwards, the 'is_bootstrapped' function now looks for the
client.admin keyring across all Ceph releases - this should be
backwards compatible.

This change also adds the standing data for upgrade paths to
Nautilus, however this is as yet untested.

Change-Id: I2dfab7404b72e314625ea554ee64595c5e26f3c6

commit_message:
db_setup: refactor database setup to a common file

This patch refactors the database creation to db_setup.yml which
will eventually be managed by openstack-ansible-tests.

This also re-orders the mq_setup to be done earlier so these system
level dependencies are ready before service activation.

Change-Id: I9bbfe5fb6e1c9f235ec4177ee3f0eedab2afd4e4

I disagree... For *libraries* the plan was to ensure at least one release is done for every milestone. So looking at who has not released since milestone-2 is the right thing to do ?'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-07 10:59:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I disagree... For *libraries* the plan was to ensure at least one
 > release is done for every milestone. So looking at who has not
 > released since milestone-2 is the right thing to do ?

That's what we discussed on the releases channel. One is indeed a subset of the other, and don't report the same things.

If we want to go that direction, we need to define a way to reliably read what happened between milestone2 and now, which means searching through dates, if I am not mistaken.
The source of truth here can be the yaml used to generate the page. But I would like to have an opinion on what we decide first, and use your expertise before we implement the tooling to generate the appropriate data then."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-18 16:52:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

I will take this PR to the next level when I will have more time to clean everything up, and browse to the whole documentation.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-31 13:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2019-05-30 20:59:55.000000000', 'message': "Block swap volume on volumes with >1 rw attachment

If we're swapping from a multiattach volume that has more than one
read/write attachment, another server on the secondary attachment could
be writing to the volume which is not getting copied into the volume to
which we're swapping, so we could have data loss during the swap.

This change does volume read/write attachment counting for the volume
we're swapping from and if there is more than one read/write attachment
on the volume, the swap volume operation fails with a 400 BadRequest
error.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/573025/
Closes-Bug: #1775418
Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778
(cherry picked from commit 5a1d159d142997bb4288d4bf86d4e144334905cd)
"}]
commit_message:
Block swap volume on volumes with >1 rw attachment

If we're swapping from a multiattach volume that has more than one
read/write attachment, another server on the secondary attachment could
be writing to the volume which is not getting copied into the volume to
which we're swapping, so we could have data loss during the swap.

This change does volume read/write attachment counting for the volume
we're swapping from and if there is more than one read/write attachment
on the volume, the swap volume operation fails with a 400 BadRequest
error.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/573025/
Closes-Bug: #1775418
Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778
(cherry picked from commit 5a1d159d142997bb4288d4bf86d4e144334905cd)

commit_message:
db_setup: refactor database setup to a common file

This patch refactors the database creation to db_setup.yml which
will eventually be managed by openstack-ansible-tests.

This also re-orders the mq_setup to be done earlier so these system
level dependencies are ready before service activation.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/660558

Change-Id: If3ac6a4e7002740c8409aef6d378d88bc287a9e7

commit_message:
db_setup: refactor database setup to a common file

This patch refactors the database creation to db_setup.yml which
will eventually be managed by openstack-ansible-tests.

This also re-orders the mq_setup to be done earlier so these system
level dependencies are ready before service activation.

Change-Id: Icfbd5c17da0c1854e6aa15094122bb911665a95e

commit_message:
Add new pcs 0.10 compatible remote addition implementation

New pcs 0.10 needs to implement remotes addition in a completely
different way. It is not sufficient anymore to just create the
ocf::pacemaker::remote resource and make sure that pacemaker_remote is
up and running with the same authkey on all nodes. Now we
need to setup pcsd on all nodes (remotes and controllers), setup the
hacluster user and then do a pcs cluster remote-add command.

We do this only when pcs 0.10 is detected in order to maintain
the old proven behaviour on pcs 0.9x.

Tested this on stein + rhel8 correctly get remotes working on an IHA
setup:
[root@controller-0 galera-bundle-1]# pcs status
Cluster name: tripleo_cluster
Stack: corosync
Current DC: controller-1 (version 2.0.1-4.el8-0eb7991564) - partition with quorum
Last updated: Thu May 23 05:52:33 2019
Last change: Tue May 21 14:20:14 2019 by root via cibadmin on controller-0

17 nodes configured
72 resources configured

Online: [ controller-0 controller-1 controller-2 ]
RemoteOnline: [ compute-0 compute-1 ]

Full list of resources:

 compute-0      (ocf::pacemaker:remote):        Started controller-0
 compute-1      (ocf::pacemaker:remote):        Started controller-1

Also tested on queens to make sure no regressions in the old codepaths
are introduced. Additionally tested a redeploy on stein to make sure
idempotency is preserved.

Change-Id: I852d5d7aa8578c45f0c7215827cedd4ea72c8d0b

commit_message:
Add hostname as a new config option

Without this option, the charm announces its API URL with the VIP
address. It is problematic when using FQDN in the SAN section of the
certificates and not IP addresses.

Change-Id: Id40f7f3d70c1e9b055bd0ed65c1c9a90c95f84c1
Closes-Bug: 1826225
(cherry picked from commit 8b99dc282988b6b395d4c9c867e050213127f07c)

[{'created': '2019-05-31 09:52:56.000000000', 'message': "Ensure fsid variable always exists for mon context

To avoid any occurences of:

 UnboundLocalError: local variable 'fsid' referenced before assignment

ensure that the fsid variable is always defined, but set to None if
the mon cluster has not yet presented this data item.

Change-Id: I497b2553a2f7743763e2ea040ff9276d97bf5d73
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure fsid variable always exists for mon context

To avoid any occurences of:

 UnboundLocalError: local variable 'fsid' referenced before assignment

ensure that the fsid variable is always defined, but set to None if
the mon cluster has not yet presented this data item.

Change-Id: I497b2553a2f7743763e2ea040ff9276d97bf5d73

commit_message:
Use list instead of six.viewkeys to avoid py2 to py3 problems

This change fixes an 'RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during
iteration' error that is raised because of different behaviour between
python2 and python3.  An earlier attempt [1] to use the six library did
not fix the issue.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/660427

Resolves-Bug: #1829304
Change-Id: Ic4c5790a5d66e10a606327f4f4e4c92611f161d8

commit_message:
Fix kolla-docker possible undefined variable

It is possible to reference undefined variable in kolla-docker module if
DockerWorker object initialization fail, so the current behaviour will
crash the playbook with the unwanted error message :

UnboundLocalError: local variable 'dw' referenced before assignment

Change-Id: Ic8d26b11f93255220888b5406f8ab4a6f81736c2
Closes-Bug: #1819361
(cherry picked from commit 3bb4c199817c8aa4ecd4ae684bd28f84933fb14d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-23 09:28:03.000000000', 'message': 'Use td-agent-gem to install fluentd monasca plugin on ubuntu

If monasca is enabled on ubuntu, we see the following error in fluentd:

[error]: config error file="/etc/td-agent/td-agent.conf"
error_class=Fluent::ConfigError error="Unknown output plugin 'monasca'.
Run 'gem search -rd fluent-plugin' to find plugins"

This is because we use 'fluent-gem install' to install the gem, which
works on CentOS but on Ubuntu it is necessary to use 'td-agent-gem
install'.

Change-Id: I515f9764ca93a41a871e520696193a9298856d08
Closes-Bug: #1830147

commit_message:
Use td-agent-gem to install fluentd monasca plugin on ubuntu

If monasca is enabled on ubuntu, we see the following error in fluentd:

[error]: config error file="/etc/td-agent/td-agent.conf"
error_class=Fluent::ConfigError error="Unknown output plugin 'monasca'.
Run 'gem search -rd fluent-plugin' to find plugins"

This is because we use 'fluent-gem install' to install the gem, which
works on CentOS but on Ubuntu it is necessary to use 'td-agent-gem
install'.

Change-Id: I515f9764ca93a41a871e520696193a9298856d08
Closes-Bug: #1830147

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-29 13:14:15.000000000', 'message': 'Support deploying Monasca Thresh

Monasca Thresh is a Storm topology which generates alerts from
metric streams according to alarms defined via the Monasca API.

This change runs the thresholder in local mode, which means that
the log output for the topology is directed to stdout and the
topology is restarted if the container is restarted. A future
change will improve the log collection and introduce a better
way of the checking the topology is running for multi-node
clusters.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I063dca5eead15f3cec009df62f0fc5d857dd4bb0
'}]
commit_message:
Support deploying Monasca Thresh

Monasca Thresh is a Storm topology which generates alerts from
metric streams according to alarms defined via the Monasca API.

This change runs the thresholder in local mode, which means that
the log output for the topology is directed to stdout and the
topology is restarted if the container is restarted. A future
change will improve the log collection and introduce a better
way of the checking the topology is running for multi-node
clusters.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I063dca5eead15f3cec009df62f0fc5d857dd4bb0

commit_message:
Support deploying Monasca Log Metrics

The log metrics service generates metrics from log messages
which allows further analysis and alerting to be performed
on them. Basic configuration is provided so that metrics
are generated for high level warning logs such as error, or
warning.

Change-Id: I45cc17817c716296451f620f304c0b1108162a56
Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles

This option doesn't actually do anything and a bug to remove
it from the Monasca API config file has been raised.

commit_message:
Use alembic migrations to bootstrap Monasca database

Alembic uses the monasca-agent config file for the DB
credentials. These are therefore no longer required.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: Id076e7a0b838888314159dd9e76697f89adecb5e

commit_message:
Add playbook to test placement

As placement is already a separate service[1],
we need to add a playbook to serve those roles
like os_tempest[2] that runs funcional tests and
needs to install nova, that should use the
placemenet service.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova/commit/5bffb86bbb0f9e41e17f5ef31d721a9b733262bc
[2] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/blob/c1b1399ddd528c02afd4833814c6d1b9a99af773/zuul.d/jobs.yaml#L17

Change-Id: I36dd33dc77f8a0c3f91b872279d5fd313908be3d

[{'created': '2018-05-28 07:59:52.000000000', 'message': "vBMC for openstack instance
vBMC currently works well when it is used to control virtual machine which is made by KVM.

With this, user uses a virtual machine as like as a baremetal.

In addition, each KVM node should have vBMC to control the virtual machine.

However, current vBMC doesn't support instance which is made by openstack.

Therefore, I uploaded this patch for supporting vBMC for openstack instance.

commit_message:
vBMC for openstack instance

vBMC currently works well when it is used to control virtual machine
which is made by KVM.
With this, user uses a virtual machine as like as a baremetal.
In addition, each KVM node should have vBMC to control the virtual
machine.
However, current vBMC doesn't support instance which is made
by openstack.
Therefore, this patch can be used for supporting vBMC for
openstack instance.

Change-Id: I4da0b011250451cff5fbf209e2fae80c391a5df5

commit_message:
Remove system ansible after it's use is over

ansible is installed currently to run docker-playbook.yaml,
we need to cleanup it up as currently docker_login module
from ansible-2.8 conflicts with ansible running in zuul
executor as mentioned in bug #1829736.

Related-Bug: #1829736
Change-Id: I7ec6a6a6fd063c4b92e3147ccb5c76a254ef83ea

commit_message:
Pin ARA to <1.0.0 and use stable setup interface to find callback plugin

ARA 1.0 will be released in the near future and isn't backwards
compatible. Pin it so it doesn't break things unexpectedly.

ARA ships simple setup modules to help figure out the paths
to where things are located.
These are backwards compatible from ARA 1.0 to 0.x.

Change-Id: I3fe3f4082279c2fd9a629605619a97aa5f5b0b73

[{'created': '2019-05-04 23:45:16.000000000', 'message': "Rewrite IPv6 goal to be clearer that we already v6

The original IPv6 community goal is laudable, but misleading. It
behooves us to avoid incorrectly implying that we lack solid IPv6
support. We've provided solutions for IPv6 connectivity to user
resources for a very long time and even have users successfully
deploying OpenStack environments with IPv6 control planes. What we
can't demonstrate with confidence yet is that OpenStack is usable in
IPv6-only environments (those with no traditilnal IPv4 addressing),
so we should clarify that the goal is about taking that next step.

Change-Id: Ic657850a06ec70dedf153ac754cfa707dbee2b90
"}, {'created': '2019-05-20 17:22:27.000000000', 'message': "Rewrite IPv6 goal to be clearer that we already v6

Change-Id: Ic657850a06ec70dedf153ac754cfa707dbee2b90

commit_message:
Rewrite IPv6 goal to be clearer that we already v6

The original IPv6 community goal is laudable, but misleading. It
behooves us to avoid incorrectly implying that we lack solid IPv6
support. We've provided solutions for IPv6 connectivity to user
resources for a very long time and even have users successfully
deploying OpenStack environments with IPv6 control planes. What we
can't demonstrate with confidence yet is that OpenStack is usable in
IPv6-only environments (those with no traditional IPv4 addressing),
so we should clarify that the goal is about taking that next step.

Change-Id: Ic657850a06ec70dedf153ac754cfa707dbee2b90

commit_message:
Add charm-vault to Charms governance

Charm-vault has been an official member of the OpenStack Charms
project for some time, but was left out of governance in the past
for a few reasons. These reasons have recently been re-evaluated
by the team and the conclusion has been to include this charm in
governance.

Change-Id: I5b147d2845d27d982c97abf18275fcff798a516d

commit_message:
Add DPDK support for OVN

OvS-DPDK on host requires the datapath type to be set
as netdev and then invoking vswitch::dpdk to apply the
DPDK specific parameters. Exposing those parameters
to be used by the deployer.

Change-Id: I7e098075580721dfb7d3fb4b696ca8d33743ef84
(cherry picked from commit 97132fbf778b3cc0e0957f03cce08d4319de3a9c)

commit_message:
Upgrade identity v2 to identity v3 API

As of the Queens release, Keystone solely implements the Identity
API v3. Support for Identity API v2.0 has been removed since Queens
in favor of the Identity API v3.

Change-Id: If65b26935e8bd1e6655d84259499f4013762e4e3
Closes-Bug: #1778846

[{'created': '2019-05-17 15:18:49.000000000', 'message': 'Constrain the size of Docker logs

Even though Kolla services are configured to log output to file rather than
stdout, some stdout still occurs when for example the container re(starts).
Since the Docker logs are not constrained in size, they can fill up the
docker volumes drive and bring down the host. One example of when this is
particularly problematic is when Fluentd cannot parse a log message. The
warning output is written to the Docker log and in production we have seen
it eat 100GB of disk space in less than a day. We could configure Fluentd
not to do this, but the problem may still occur via another mechanism.

Change-Id: Ia6d3935263a5909c71750b34eb69e72e6e558b7a
Closes-Bug: #1794249
(cherry picked from commit bd54b99132d019b747dcd98af9371628625c8a1b)
'}]
commit_message:
Constrain the size of Docker logs

Even though Kolla services are configured to log output to file rather than
stdout, some stdout still occurs when for example the container re(starts).
Since the Docker logs are not constrained in size, they can fill up the
docker volumes drive and bring down the host. One example of when this is
particularly problematic is when Fluentd cannot parse a log message. The
warning output is written to the Docker log and in production we have seen
it eat 100GB of disk space in less than a day. We could configure Fluentd
not to do this, but the problem may still occur via another mechanism.

Change-Id: Ia6d3935263a5909c71750b34eb69e72e6e558b7a
Closes-Bug: #1794249
(cherry picked from commit bd54b99132d019b747dcd98af9371628625c8a1b)

[{'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-03-07 15:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-03-07 16:48:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

24MB seems far too conservative. Looking at a few references[0][1][2][3] shows that most OS's default to a ESP size of anywhere from 100-500MB. I struggled to find any OS or distro that defaults or recommends less than a 100MB ESP.

It seems like, given that OS's expect to have at least 100-200MB to work with in the ESP, DIB will predictably continue to produce images that later break when system updates are applied until it produces a more appropriately sized ESP.

[0] https://www.ctrl.blog/entry/esp-size-guide
[1] https://help.ubuntu.com/community/DiskSpace
[2] https://superuser.com/questions/1310927/what-is-the-absolute-minimum-size-a-uefi-partition-can-be
[3] https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/installation_guide/sect-disk-partitioning-setup-x86#sect-recommended-partitioning-scheme-x86"}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-04-09 21:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-04-09 21:44:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you Logan, that's very good feedback! I've updated my patch by selecting a size recommended at https://www.rodsbooks.com/efi-bootloaders/principles.html"}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-04-11 16:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-18 06:40:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2
