[{'created': '2019-03-07 15:53:12.000000000', 'message': 'Increase size of EFI system partition (again)

When I said in I8594d1fe05242f246a5809740a115ab2f84ac5a3 that 12 MiB ought to
be enough, I should have expected that I would be proven wrong. While 12 MiB is
enough to fit shim-x64 and grub2-efi-x64, yum fails to update these packages to
newer versions:

Transaction check error:
  installing package shim-x64-15-2.el7.centos.x86_64 needs 7MB on the /boot/efi filesystem
  installing package grub2-efi-x64-1:2.02-0.76.el7.centos.1.x86_64 needs 3MB on the /boot/efi filesystem

Error Summary
-------------
Disk Requirements:
  At least 7MB more space needed on the /boot/efi filesystem.

Bump partition size to 24MiB, hopefully it will be enough this time.

Change-Id: If9515234f1a803cda32b2482f8abe10ddf0e6d26
'}, {'created': '2019-04-09 21:41:40.000000000', 'message': 'Increase size of EFI system partition (again)

When I said in I8594d1fe05242f246a5809740a115ab2f84ac5a3 that 12 MiB
ought to be enough, I should have expected that I would be proven wrong.
While 12 MiB is enough to fit shim-x64 and grub2-efi-x64, yum fails to
update these packages to newer versions:

Transaction check error:
  installing package shim-x64-15-2.el7.centos.x86_64 needs 7MB on the /boot/efi filesystem
  installing package grub2-efi-x64-1:2.02-0.76.el7.centos.1.x86_64 needs 3MB on the /boot/efi filesystem

Error Summary
-------------
Disk Requirements:
  At least 7MB more space needed on the /boot/efi filesystem.

It is recommended that the ESP partition be much bigger. This commit
bumps its size to 550MiB, following guidelines from Rod Smith to avoid
incompatibilities with some EFIs [1].

commit_message:
Increase size of EFI system partition (again)

When I said in I8594d1fe05242f246a5809740a115ab2f84ac5a3 that 12 MiB
ought to be enough, I should have expected that I would be proven wrong.
While 12 MiB is enough to fit shim-x64 and grub2-efi-x64, yum fails to
update these packages to newer versions:

Transaction check error:
  installing package shim-x64-15-2.el7.centos.x86_64 needs 7MB on the /boot/efi filesystem
  installing package grub2-efi-x64-1:2.02-0.76.el7.centos.1.x86_64 needs 3MB on the /boot/efi filesystem

Error Summary
-------------
Disk Requirements:
  At least 7MB more space needed on the /boot/efi filesystem.

It is recommended that the ESP partition be much bigger. This commit
bumps its size to 550MiB, following guidelines from Rod Smith to avoid
incompatibilities with some EFIs [1].

[1] https://www.rodsbooks.com/efi-bootloaders/principles.html

Change-Id: If9515234f1a803cda32b2482f8abe10ddf0e6d26

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-29 19:45:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fix regression with SW deployments when region not configured

The region name eventually has to pass through an os-collect-config.conf
file, the format of which is unable to distinguish between the JSON null
(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528
'}]
commit_message:
Fix regression with SW deployments when region not configured

The region name eventually has to pass through an os-collect-config.conf
file, the format of which is unable to distinguish between the JSON null
(equivalent to None in Python) and the string "null".

This means that Story 2002781 caused a regression for users who didn't
have the region_name_for_services config option explicitly set in
heat.conf.

To avoid this, only specify the region when we know what it is.

Change-Id: I23493b1c477d082c478f87167de2c1859ba5ace7
Story: #2005797
Task: 33527
Task: 33528

commit_message:
Default network segmentation ID correctly

Resolve an ansible 2.8 issue:
argument provider_segmentation_id is of type <type 'str'> and we
were unable to convert to int: <type 'str'> cannot be converted to an
int

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660697/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660772/
Change-Id: Ic88bb7d6f36fe9ad9ff66bfb5119eee5a5f67cd2

commit_message:
Return None for attributes of sd with no actions

If the 'actions' property of a deployment is [], we don't
create a software deployment in heat and resource_id of the
software deployment is None. However, there is a possibility
that we access the attributes of the sd in the template and
that results in TypeError as we try to make an rpc call to
show the software deployment for None.

Change-Id: Iefd3cdd20bb51c63e7267ae0628e0f15544c0427
Task: 33516

commit_message:
Remove fake_libvirt_utils from snapshot tests.

This is probably the most complicated transition for this file.
However, it makes it much clearer what each test expects in order
to work correctly.

Change-Id: Iddd5f1f31a7bdcfee94b5113af0b2b25fe677edd

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/586252/39 : SUCCESS in 1h 33m 27s'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-05-03 02:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 39: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

The code mostly looks good.  I have a few nits and questions, but nothing that couldn't wait for a respin or follow-on change.

How would you recommend running with this code in a way that would really simulate the smart nic experience, for those than want to pull it down and see the smart nic management in action?"}, {'account_id': 22948, 'date': '2019-05-05 13:44:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 40.'}, {'account_id': 22948, 'date': '2019-05-05 13:44:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 22948, 'date': '2019-05-05 14:05:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 40:

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > The code mostly looks good.  I have a few nits and questions, but
 > nothing that couldn't wait for a respin or follow-on change.
 > 
 > How would you recommend running with this code in a way that would
 > really simulate the smart nic experience, for those than want to
 > pull it down and see the smart nic management in action?

1- Add neutron agent (the one that would be on the SmartNIC)
To simulate what the agent would do in a smartnic, you need to add a neutron agent to your setup with config option baremetal_smartnic=True in ovs section in ml2.conf file.
You can use devstack to install the neutron agent.

2- Create a SmartNIC port[1]
Then create a Smartnic port with HOSTNAME and REP_NAME from the node created in step 1.
REP_NAME should be the representor port on the smartnic but you could use any interface e.x. eth2.

openstack baremetal port create $HW_MAC_ADDRESS --node $NODE_UUID \
    --local-link-connection hostname=$HOSTNAME \
    --local-link-connection port_id=$REP_NAME \
    --pxe-enabled true \
    --physical-network physnet1 \
    --is-smartnic

3- create a baremetal instance using the SmartNIC port.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/doc/source/admin/multitenancy.rst"}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-05-05 15:39:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40:

It would be good IMHO to add e.g. fullstack test for port binding process. So You can do 2 tests like:

1. Configure ovs agent with baremetal_smartnic=True in config and create port on this "host" - than check it's binding, should be fine,
2. Configure ovs agent with baremetal_smartnic=False in config and create port on this "host" - than check it's binding, should be failed

What do You think about such idea?'}, {'account_id': 22948, 'date': '2019-05-23 07:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 46.'}, {'account_id': 22948, 'date': '2019-05-23 07:53:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 45:

Extend the Neutron OVS mechanism driver and Neutron OVS Agent to bind
the Neutron port for the baremetal host with smart NIC. This will allow
the Neutron OVS Agent to configure the pipeline of the OVS running on
the smart NIC and leverage the pipeline features such as: VXLAN,
Security Groups and ARP Responder.

commit_message:
Add Smart NIC representor port to integration bridge

In case of Smart NIC vNIC type neutron should mimic nova-compute
that plug the port to the ovs bridge.

Extend the Neutron OVS mechanism driver and Neutron OVS Agent to bind
the Neutron port for the baremetal host with Smart NIC. This will allow
the Neutron OVS Agent to configure the pipeline of the OVS running on
the Smart NIC and leverage the pipeline features such as: VXLAN,
Security Groups and ARP Responder.

Story: #2003346
Closes-Bug: #1785608
Change-Id: I6d520d3bac2e9ceb30b5b6197c6eb0f958cc3659

[{'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-04-30 09:12:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-04-30 09:43:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-04-30 15:47:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Example of failure that could have being avoided with that http://logs.openstack.org/67/656467/1/check/tripleo-buildimage-overcloud-full-centos-7/afc007e/logs/build.log

I know for that that at least two failures were caused today by this lack of retry.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2019-04-30 16:21:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2019-04-30 17:01:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Since the failure happens so early in the build process is there a reason we need to change this default?  Not looked at the code but is it user overridable (sometimes I like fast failures)?'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-05-23 14:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Nobody has time to investigate random networking errors, which are not really so few. Once we have retries we could use logstash search to count how many we see over time.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-05-31 06:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-05-31 06:32:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I'd say it's reasonable enough to try with a bit of a back off.  I just made it so it's not then removed if we set the cache headers"}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-05-31 10:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks! This should make its execution more reliable.'}]

commit_message:
Makes image caching more resilient

Avoids failing on the first attempt to download the image to cache as
mirrors hosting them can randomly go down, usually with a connection
refused.

Change-Id: I9de9f33c2cc16596d04b35c4eb92621e6a2c7511

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-08 18:23:31.000000000', 'message': 'bindep: exclude zypper from debian-stretch

It seems that zypper was removed from debian-stretch which means
that we have to ignore it in bindep (likely for the same reason
that we are excluding bionic)[1].

[1]: https://tracker.debian.org/news/836378/zypper-removed-from-testing/

Change-Id: I60d83414fdc241d65eda8ab88c8e284e5d0bd257

Change-Id: I60d83414fdc241d65eda8ab88c8e284e5d0bd257

commit_message:
bindep: exclude zypper from debian-stretch

It seems that zypper was removed from debian-stretch which means
that we have to ignore it in bindep (likely for the same reason
that we are excluding bionic)[1].

[1]: https://tracker.debian.org/news/836378/zypper-removed-from-testing/

commit_message:
fail early when lates build information can not be fetched

When the mirror returns a error, it was trying to interpret the error
message (e.g. <html><title>Internal server error..) as a download link.
By using -f on curl we get an empty reply and an exit code, which, as
we run in set -e mode, aborts.

Change-Id: Ibaa39aedb7db286f859c4b090114c6a233b150c7

commit_message:
Cap sphinx for py2 to match global requirements

Sphinx 2.0.0 dropped Python 2.7 support. This is aligned with
[1] in requirements project.
[1]Change-Id If558f184c959e4b63b56dec3ca1571d1034cfe5c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-29 11:41:29.000000000', 'message': 'Respect tags in upgrade tasks

There seems to be a difference between how include_tasks and
import_tasks work.

`include_tasks` applies properties on the inclusion itself, and if we
want to apply something on the included tasks, we need to use `apply`
dict. We previously had to add `always` tag onto `include_tasks` to
make the inclusion happen when we ran upgrade with `--tags`.

`import_tasks`, on the other hand, is processed more like a block than
an individual task, and all its properties get applied on the tasks
inside. This meant that the `always` tag got applied on all tags in
the upgrade playbook, instead of on the import itself, which broke use
of tags in `upgrade_tasks`. This is now fixed by removing the tags
from `import_tasks`. The import should happen always regardless if
there are any `tags` on the import.

Change-Id: I66a4ed99f9e0cc199899494813073b4a085d99e7
Closes-Bug: #1830892
'}, {'created': '2019-05-30 07:35:54.000000000', 'message': 'Respect tags in upgrade tasks

There seems to be a difference between how include_tasks and
import_tasks work.

`include_tasks` applies properties on the inclusion itself, and if we
want to apply something on the included tasks, we need to use `apply`
dict. We previously had to add `always` tag onto `include_tasks` to
make the inclusion happen when we ran upgrade with `--tags`.

`import_tasks`, on the other hand, is processed more like a block than
an individual task, and all its properties get applied on the tasks
inside. This meant that the `always` tag got applied on all tags in
the upgrade playbook, instead of on the import itself, which broke use
of tags in `upgrade_tasks`. This is now fixed by removing the tags
from `import_tasks`. The import should happen always regardless if
there are any `tags` on the import.

Change-Id: I66a4ed99f9e0cc199899494813073b4a085d99e7
Closes-Bug: #1830892
'}]
commit_message:
Respect tags in upgrade tasks

There seems to be a difference between how include_tasks and
import_tasks work.

`include_tasks` applies properties on the inclusion itself, and if we
want to apply something on the included tasks, we need to use `apply`
dict. We previously had to add `always` tag onto `include_tasks` to
make the inclusion happen when we ran upgrade with `--tags`.

`import_tasks`, on the other hand, is processed more like a block than
an individual task, and all its properties get applied on the tasks
inside. This meant that the `always` tag got applied on all tags in
the upgrade playbook, instead of on the import itself, which broke use
of tags in `upgrade_tasks`. This is now fixed by removing the tags
from `import_tasks`. The import should happen always regardless if
there are any `tags` on the import.

Change-Id: I66a4ed99f9e0cc199899494813073b4a085d99e7
Closes-Bug: #1830892

commit_message:
Add get_usages_counts_for_quota to SchedulerReportClient

This adds a method for requesting /usages from placement for the
purpose of counting quota usage for cores and ram. It is used in the
next patch in the series.

Part of blueprint count-quota-usage-from-placement

Change-Id: I35f98f88f8353602e1bfc135f35d1b7bc9ba42a4

(2 comments)

I don't think this is safe as-is. The first iteration, simply disallowing swap-volume on a multiattach volume, was draconian but safe. This version makes it very easy for a user to unwittingly corrupt their data with no warning that they're doing it.

As noted below, though, we might be able to make it safe by listening for attach events from cinder.

I'd prefer if you updated the commit message. swap_volume was clearly designed to work (potentially with any hypervisor, but only implemented by libvirt) in a non-multiattach world. Its call contract is now broken, and would be broken wherever it was implemented, but it's only implemented by libvirt. It seems weird to call out libvirt for being ahead of the curve, especially with implementation details which aren't relevant to the bug. If it really makes you happy, though, I guess it's not that important ;)"}, {'account_id': 19944, 'date': '2018-06-07 10:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-06-07 12:40:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-07 12:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/572790/8/ : SUCCESS in 2h 39m 57s'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-06-08 11:10:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(8 comments)

Some nits and suggestions. I'd strongly prefer fixing _translate_attachment_ref() in a preceding patch rather than proliferating its cruftiness here, but on balance I wouldn't personally want to hold up this patch for that if you didn't have time.

However... in looking for where attach_mode is used I discovered that it doesn't appear to be used anywhere, either in nova or os-brick. This implies to me that ro attachments are actually rw attachments until this is addressed. I wonder if (1) this is correct, and (2) it's worth treating them as such, perhaps with a code comment? If they're actually rw, the copy would obviously not be safe."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-06-08 15:54:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

I'd kinda like a tempest tests for the new behaviour, especially since there seems to be some uncertainty about what exactly we can expect in the cinder API."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-06-08 18:29:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> I'd kinda like a tempest tests for the new behaviour, especially
> since there seems to be some uncertainty about what exactly we can
> expect in the cinder API.

Just so we don't duplicate work: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/573809/"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-09 13:53:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@mdbooth - I'm not following the concern about ro attachments being rw attachments; the way a read-only volume's attachments show up today are via the access_mode in the connection_info, see the libvirt volume driver code for the access_mode usage.

Cinder is a bit wonky in how it handles ro attachments today via the attach_mode and readonly volume admin metadata on the volume itself, rather than per-attachment, even though attachment records have an attach_mode field.  Part of that is going to have to get sorted out as dependent fixes as part of this spec to do per-attachment attach_mode:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/approved/volume-multiattach-enhancements.html"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-09 14:00:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(5 comments)

I'm running out of steam on this - I've already spent a couple of days working on this so would kind of like to move forward, get it backported, and then work on follow-ups to clean stuff up."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-06-11 00:52:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

My new tempest test is failing to detach the volume in the cleanup phase [1] and I can't tell if I'm doing something wrong in the test itself, or if this patch somehow renders volumes undetachable if there's been a swap attempt that was refused.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/09/573809/2/check/nova-multiattach/ebd4e2a/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-06-09_15_07_11_186979"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-11 19:01:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-08-24 15:28:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Re-reading, I was +1 on this *except* that I wasn't comfortable with the use of attach_mode.

The issue is that in _count_attachments_for_swap() we're counting up how many attachments we have with attach_mode='ro'. However, we actually set the mode in the generated libvirt xml based on 'access_mode'.

Do 'access_mode' and 'attach_mode' always correlate? A quick glance in cinder suggests they're handled quite differently, so is this a potential source of weird edge cases? I'd be more comfortable if we could get an opinion from a cinder person.

I'm +1 on this patch, apart from the question of cinder semantics which I simply don't understand."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-08-24 15:33:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Incidentally, to my inexpert eye attach_mode seems like the better option as it seems to be a documented part of the api, as opposed to access_mode which is only to be found in the wild west of connection_info. I wonder if we ought to use attach_mode in both places? If so, updating libvirt.volume obviously wouldn't be a part of this patch."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-24 15:35:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-25 20:08:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-25 20:12:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

[{'created': '2018-06-06 14:33:15.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Block swap volume with multiattach volumes

Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778
TODO: count attachments, tests, and link to a bug
'}, {'created': '2018-06-06 19:52:24.000000000', 'message': "Block swap volume on volumes with >1 rw attachment

The only virt driver that supports swap volume is the
libvirt driver and the blockRebase operation is not
designed to handle multiattach volumes, so if we're
swapping from a multiattach volume that has more than
one read/write attachment, another server on the
secondary attachment could be writing to the volume
which is not getting copied into the volume to which
we're swapping, so we could have data loss during the
swap.

This change does volume read/write attachment counting
for the volume we're swapping from and the volume we're
swapping to and if there is more than one read/write
attachment on either volume, the swap volume operation
fails with a 400 BadRequest error.

Closes-Bug: #1775418

Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778

commit_message:
Block swap volume on volumes with >1 rw attachment

If we're swapping from a multiattach volume that has more than one
read/write attachment, another server on the secondary attachment could
be writing to the volume which is not getting copied into the volume to
which we're swapping, so we could have data loss during the swap.

This change does volume read/write attachment counting for the volume
we're swapping from and if there is more than one read/write attachment
on the volume, the swap volume operation fails with a 400 BadRequest
error.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/573025/
Closes-Bug: #1775418
Change-Id: Icd7fcb87a09c35a13e4e14235feb30a289d22778

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-24 16:11:43.000000000', 'message': '[stable-only] Delete allocations even if _confirm_resize raises (part 2)

The backport https://review.opendev.org/#/c/652153/ to fix
bug 1821594 did not account for how the _delete_allocation_after_move
method before Stein is tightly coupled to the migration status
being set to "confirmed" which is what the _confirm_resize method
does after self.driver.confirm_migration returns.

However, if self.driver.confirm_migration raises an exception
we still want to cleanup the allocations held on the source node
and for that we call _delete_allocation_after_move. But because
of that tight coupling before Stein, we need to temporarily
mutate the migration status to "confirmed" to get the cleanup
method to do what we want.

This isn't a problem starting in Stein because change
I0851e2d54a1fdc82fe3291fb7e286e790f121e92 removed that
tight coupling on the migration status, so this is a stable
branch only change.

Note that we don't call self.reportclient.delete_allocation_for_instance
directly since before Stein we still need to account for a
migration that does not move the source node allocations to the
migration record, and that logic is in _delete_allocation_after_move.

A simple unit test assertion is added here but the functional
test added in change I9d6478f492351b58aa87b8f56e907ee633d6d1c6
will assert the bug is fixed properly before Stein.

Change-Id: I933687891abef4878de09481937d576ce5899511
Closes-Bug: #1821594
(cherry picked from commit dac3239e92fc1865cacc17bbfbd2316072a9d26e)
'}, {'created': '2019-05-29 00:52:49.000000000', 'message': '[stable-only] Delete allocations even if _confirm_resize raises (part 2)

Note that we don't call self.reportclient.delete_allocation_for_instance

commit_message:
[stable-only] Delete allocations even if _confirm_resize raises (part 2)

The backport https://review.opendev.org/#/c/652153/ to fix
bug 1821594 did not account for how the _delete_allocation_after_move
method before Stein is tightly coupled to the migration status
being set to "confirmed" which is what the _confirm_resize method
does after self.driver.confirm_migration returns.

However, if self.driver.confirm_migration raises an exception
we still want to cleanup the allocations held on the source node
and for that we call _delete_allocation_after_move. But because
of that tight coupling before Stein, we need to temporarily
mutate the migration status to "confirmed" to get the cleanup
method to do what we want.

This isn't a problem starting in Stein because change
I0851e2d54a1fdc82fe3291fb7e286e790f121e92 removed that
tight coupling on the migration status, so this is a stable
branch only change.

Note that we don't call self.reportclient.delete_allocation_for_instance
directly since before Stein we still need to account for a
migration that does not move the source node allocations to the
migration record, and that logic is in _delete_allocation_after_move.

A simple unit test assertion is added here but the functional
test added in change I9d6478f492351b58aa87b8f56e907ee633d6d1c6
will assert the bug is fixed properly before Stein.

Change-Id: I933687891abef4878de09481937d576ce5899511
Closes-Bug: #1821594
(cherry picked from commit dac3239e92fc1865cacc17bbfbd2316072a9d26e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-23 01:19:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix multiple mon deployment failures

When 4 or 5 mons are deployed, all mons will always be in the election
state, and the ceph cluster cannot be accessed.

After comparing with ceph-deploy, I found that when the cluster was
initialized, it did not use monmap. When adding a new mon node, it
needs to use monmap. According to the above situation, I fixed the
problem.

Change-Id: Idbfc6741d371adcb06ed97d578d75d3bce862743
Closes-bug: #1824783
(cherry picked from commit 285814353af29395932e15d78c6a154796978a21)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix multiple mon deployment failures

When 4 or 5 mons are deployed, all mons will always be in the election
state, and the ceph cluster cannot be accessed.

After comparing with ceph-deploy, I found that when the cluster was
initialized, it did not use monmap. When adding a new mon node, it
needs to use monmap. According to the above situation, I fixed the
problem.

Change-Id: Idbfc6741d371adcb06ed97d578d75d3bce862743
Closes-bug: #1824783
(cherry picked from commit 285814353af29395932e15d78c6a154796978a21)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-24 18:10:39.000000000', 'message': 'Remove HTTP configuration shipped in openstack-nova-placement-api RPM

The RDO openstack-nova-placement-api RPM ships with an HTTP
configuration deploying placement on port 8778, while Kolla-Ansible
creates another file to configure it to listen on port 8780. If
`placement_api_port` is changed to use port 8778, the placement_api
container will fail to start because the port is already in use.

This commit removes the configuration file shipped with the RPM package
to avoid this conflict.

Change-Id: I7babdb794bec3b08047101e2537f030e2217cedb
'}, {'created': '2019-05-24 18:11:56.000000000', 'message': 'Remove HTTP configuration shipped in openstack-nova-placement-api RPM

The RDO openstack-nova-placement-api RPM ships with an HTTP
configuration deploying placement on port 8778, while Kolla-Ansible
creates another file to configure it to listen on port 8780. If
`placement_api_port` is changed to use port 8778, the placement_api
container will fail to start because the port is already in use.

This commit removes the configuration file shipped with the RPM package
to avoid this conflict.

Change-Id: I7babdb794bec3b08047101e2537f030e2217cedb
Closes-Bug: #1830420
'}]
commit_message:
Remove HTTP configuration shipped in openstack-nova-placement-api RPM

The RDO openstack-nova-placement-api RPM ships with an HTTP
configuration deploying placement on port 8778, while Kolla-Ansible
creates another file to configure it to listen on port 8780. If
`placement_api_port` is changed to use port 8778, the placement_api
container will fail to start because the port is already in use.

This commit removes the configuration file shipped with the RPM package
to avoid this conflict.

Change-Id: I7babdb794bec3b08047101e2537f030e2217cedb
Closes-Bug: #1830420

commit_message:
Keep attach_mode as top-level field in _translate_attachment_ref

The attach_mode is a top-level field on the attachment record in Cinder.
There is an access_mode entry in the connection_info field which is used
by the volume driver in compute when making an attachment, but the
attach_mode field is read by the API during swap volume so we don't have
to dig into the connection_info details.

This changes _translate_attachment_ref to leave attach_mode on the
top-level attachment reference dict so the API does not need to look
into the connection_info data.

Change-Id: I1207687d1b00416482ac34ad3250e7121d9b4352

commit_message:
Fix session when user is not in default domain

Use the project_domain_name value returned by the
context instead of using a static value from the
qinling.conf configuration file.

Change-Id: Ic5943bc83e6aadd27d094e28bb60439ca2dbedbd
Story: 2005802
Task: 33537

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/661266/2 : SUCCESS in 2h 14m 33s'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-24 20:18:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ugh.  The lower-constraints failure is because configparser.py uses enumerate() to iterate over the lines of the (mocked) /etc/nova/release config file, and this uses __iter__() under the hood which was not supported via mock_open until https://bugs.python.org/issue21258 was fixed. The fix was backported to the external mock library for 3.0.0: https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/commit/73f6eed0d6867299fa2543b88a07cd8f12198361

but for some reason lower-constraints specifies mock==2.0.0 for all Python versions even though mock is built-in from Python 3.3 onwards:

https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/blob/master/README.rst

So I either need to give up on supporting mocking oslo config file contents, or add an option to patch_open which allows use of StringIO instead of mock_open. This has the disadvantage that mock assertions cannot be made on StringIO objects, but that's why we'd default to mock_open and only use StringIO when we need to.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-24 20:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-24 20:21:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Here's the cpython fix:

https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/2087023fdec2c89070bd14f384a3c308c548a94a

and the upstream Python bug which supersedes the previous one I linked:

 https://bugs.python.org/issue32933"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-24 20:57:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

You could bump the lower constraint on mock...

> give up on supporting mocking oslo config file contents,

...or this, by reverting that one delta (and leaving a TODO to fix it when able)...

> or add an option to patch_open which allows use of StringIO instead of mock_open.

...but please not this.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-24 23:39:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-24 23:40:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

>You could bump the lower constraint on mock...

Done and it seems to work.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-05-25 01:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

commit_message:
Move selective patching of open() to nova.test for reuse

Several existing tests patch open() to fake the contents of a file
outside the test virtualenv, whilst avoiding interfering with reading
and writing of other files inside the test virtualenv.  Currently they
do it by duplicating logic.

Furthermore, in the near future, more tests (specifically, some SEV
tests) will want to do the same selective patching, and similarly will
need to avoid impacting reads of other files within the test
virtualenv, e.g. placement-policy.yaml.

So create new patch_open() context manager / decorator in nova.test
for selectively patching open based on the path parameter, and reuse
this for existing tests.

Also add unit tests for all these cases.

mock >= 3.0.0 is required because configparser.RawConfigParser._read()
uses enumerate() to iterate over the lines of the (mocked)
/etc/nova/release config file, and this uses __iter__() under the hood
which was not supported via mock_open until a bug was fixed and
backported to the external mock library for 3.0.0:

    https://bugs.python.org/issue21258
    https://bugs.python.org/issue32933
    https://github.com/testing-cabal/mock/commit/73f6eed0d6867299fa2543b88a07cd8f12198361

Change-Id: I19f49c923d2c41eab0c7b4cab28c50498dc07046

commit_message:
Blacklist python-cinderclient 4.0.0

This release of the Cinder client broke support for the v3
volume-transfer APIs unless microversion 3.55 or higher was requested.
Depends-On https://review.opendev.org/#/c/587877/

Change-Id: Ieb685a476d51d92ad3f153fb3d1fabfb6d5a4376

[{'created': '2019-05-09 09:28:19.000000000', 'message': 'yum_update.sh improvements

* Use <yum|dnf> repoquery instead of repoquery directly

  "repoquery" is part of <yum|dnf>-utils which may not be installed, in
  which case no packages would end up updated.

* Use the --quiet flag with repoquery

  This prevents notices such as subscription-related stderr warnings
  from being added to the output and messing with the sorted order.

  It seems using else without a colon is the bash standard. This gets
  rid of the following error on RHEL:

commit_message:
yum_update.sh improvements

* Use <yum|dnf> repoquery instead of repoquery directly

  "repoquery" is part of <yum|dnf>-utils which may not be installed, in
  which case no packages would end up updated.

* Use the --quiet flag with repoquery

  This prevents notices such as subscription-related stderr warnings
  from being added to the output and messing with the sorted order.

* Remove the : after else

  It seems using else without a colon is the bash standard. This gets
  rid of the following error on RHEL8:
  "/tmp/yum_update.sh: line 34: else:: command not found"

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/662317
Change-Id: Id03405d49dc213d018941c44129521cca845e7d6

override container update repos for Fedora

Fedora jobs should not be using a centos ceph
yum repo in the config for container updates.

commit_message:
Add option to skip update packages

in same cases it is required to avoid update all existing packages,
doing so can result in release update which is currently not possible
unless you not include "base" element.

"base" element used for most distribution (rhel, debain), and is
necessary for most cloud operations, this patch add 
"DIB_AVOID_PACKAGES_UPDATE" parameter to skip updating all packages.

usecases for this patch can be:
 * Avoid release update when building old release ex. RHEL7.5.
 * build on network-less environment.

usage:
DIB_AVOID_PACKAGES_UPDATE=1

or
DIB_AVOID_PACKAGES_UPDATE=0

Change-Id: I71192b23c8f0bc48b348fe7377bf8a2399b53792

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-29 12:18:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix adhoc action lookup

Now to find an adhoc action definition by name action hanler takes
the name in runtime context first, and then provides this value along
with workflow name and workflow spec name to resolve_action_definition
method.

This method tries to find a definition by full name, i.e.
"wb_name.action_name" if wf_name != wf_spec_name, and, if nothing was
found, looks for a definition just by name, i.e. "action_name".

There is an issue, because runtime context already contains full name
for the action and substitution of a workbook name as a prefix is not
necessary.

It leads to the fact, that for all adhoc actions mistral tries to find
them by "my_wb_name.my_wb_name.my_action_name" first, and then, when it
fails, it looks for "my_wb_name.my_action_name".

This results in double the number of queries to the database and highly
innefficient.

This commit solves the issue by not providing workflow name and workflow
spec name to resolve_action_definition method for adhoc actions.
After that, the method will search for the action immediately by its
name.

Change-Id: I3b880ef29057afb041edd9095c279a944c77f2dd

commit_message:
Fix adhoc action lookup

Now to find an adhoc action definition by name action hanler takes
the name in runtime context first, and then provides this value along
with workflow name and workflow spec name to resolve_action_definition
method.

This method tries to find a definition by full name, i.e.
"wb_name.action_name" if wf_name != wf_spec_name, and, if nothing was
found, looks for a definition just by name, i.e. "action_name".

There is an issue, because runtime context already contains full name
for the action and substitution of a workbook name as a prefix is not
necessary.

It leads to the fact, that for all adhoc actions mistral tries to find
them by "my_wb_name.my_wb_name.my_action_name" first, and then, when it
fails, it looks for "my_wb_name.my_action_name".

This results in double the number of queries to the database and highly
innefficient.

This commit solves the issue by not providing workflow name and workflow
spec name to resolve_action_definition method for adhoc actions.
After that, the method will search for the action immediately by its
name.
For system actions this substitution is not necessary there either, so
the code can be safely deleted as well.

Change-Id: I3b880ef29057afb041edd9095c279a944c77f2dd

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-26 10:54:33.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate rhel7 in favor of rhel

The rhel7 element is deprecated and is left only for backward compatibility.
The rhel element should be used instead. Users should set DIB_RELEASE to 7 to indicate which release you are using.

The new element is a version-less RHEL element to handle both '7' and '8' DIB_RELEASE, which aligns with other elements which operate in the
same way such as the Fedora element.

Change-Id: Ic39ed85cacae9942448eb18ad685763f9369c2ed
"}, {'created': '2019-03-26 10:56:04.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate rhel7 in favor of rhel

commit_message:
Deprecate rhel7 in favor of rhel

The rhel7 element is deprecated and is left only for backward
compatibility.
The rhel element should be used instead. Users should set DIB_RELEASE to
'7' to indicate which release you are using.

The new element is a version-less RHEL element to handle both '7'
and '8' DIB_RELEASE, which aligns with other elements which operate in
the same way such as the Fedora element.

Change-Id: Ic39ed85cacae9942448eb18ad685763f9369c2ed

subject: Add version-less RHEL element for RHEL7 and RHEL8

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-03-28 03:41:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

The two yum-minimal files aren't related, right?  This is only for image builds via the official .qcow2 images?

I think it makes sense to just have a rhel element.  But how do we test this?  can the RDO tests be expanded to grab the upstream image from some redhat location internally and report back?  the subscription manager stuff in rhel-common again poses another issue -- I doubt that has ever received much testing at all.  Does it work?"}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-03-28 10:37:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> The two yum-minimal files aren't related, right?  This is only for
 > image builds via the official .qcow2 images?
 > 
 > I think it makes sense to just have a rhel element.  But how do we
 > test this?  can the RDO tests be expanded to grab the upstream
 > image from some redhat location internally and report back?  the
 > subscription manager stuff in rhel-common again poses another issue
 > -- I doubt that has ever received much testing at all.  Does it
 > work?

Hi Ian,

Thanks so much for taking the time to provide feedback again.
You make valid points, and I'm very open to discussions here. Let me try to answer your questions one at a time:

1. Regarding the two yum-minimal files: you mean yum-cleanup and yum-chroot. Aren't related to what? we tested this patch downstream and we were able to build a minimal image with it.

2. As for testing: Yes, this is a problem. The same problem existed for testing RHEL7 using public repositories since it is no there. We don't currently have a CentOS8 image to help us with this but: 
a. We do perform downstream tests, and I'll paste the logs if that helps.
b. I don't know about RDO tests expansion, from what I understand they use CentOS, but I can double-check.
c. RHEL8 cloud image can (possibly) be tested by a third-party Red Hat CI job, but I cannot make any promises since I can recall a precedent (and again, the rhel7 image got accepted without it).

3. subscription manager: not tested upstream (for rhel7) but I can say we did use it internally in the past and it worked. I have not yet tested this for RHEL8 (no official channels to check against as RHEL8 is still under development).

Lon might also be able to provide more answers, as we mostly tested this patch with his tools.

Nir"}, {'account_id': 8161, 'date': '2019-03-28 12:00:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> (1 comment)

Potentially.  The CDN repositories are likely to be named differently between RHEL7 vs 8 - and more/fewer might be required.

This could certainly be handled by checking the RHEL version and making decisions based on that in a common RHEL element.'}, {'account_id': 8161, 'date': '2019-03-28 12:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> I think it makes sense to just have a rhel element.  But how do we
 > test this?  can the RDO tests be expanded to grab the upstream
 > image from some redhat location internally and report back?  the
 > subscription manager stuff in rhel-common again poses another issue
 > -- I doubt that has ever received much testing at all.  Does it
 > work?

Good questions. I certainly have no idea whether the elements work or have been tested.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-08 11:50:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-08 12:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> we tested this patch downstream and we were able to build a minimal image with it.

Just to clarify, do you mean you used the "rhel-minimal" element (from 623137) or this exact patch? (because this seems to be missing most rhel-minimal parts, but as previously mentioned has some of the yum-minimal bits included)

It's not clear to me that rhel-minimal has a lifespan outside of the beta period.  Essentially, the repos that are used [1] a) may already be out of date (aren't being updated?) and b) will not be available after the beta period -- I don't see where a non-redhat-internal person would be able to get access to the repos to build.  This is why I've demurred a bit on the rhel-minimal patch.

However, I think using the rhel-guest-image*.qcow2 (as done by the rhel7 element, and proposed here for rhel8) is OK.  Any customer can grab those and realistically use it as a basis for some customisation.  I'm happy to accept that the subscription manager stuff may not be known to work until that is finalised upstream.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623137/9/diskimage_builder/elements/rhel-minimal/yum.repos.d/yum.repo'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2019-04-11 14:42:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2019-04-11 14:47:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623137/9/diskimage_builder/elements/rhel-minimal/yum.repos.d/yum.repo

yes, RHEL public betas are never updated, we'll need to wait until we can continue work on maybe generic EL-minimal, if we find a use-case for minimal DIB image."}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-04-15 09:11:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Patch Set 13 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-04-15 11:47:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Published edit on patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 8161, 'date': '2019-04-15 13:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 8161, 'date': '2019-04-15 14:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 11810, 'date': '2019-04-16 16:04:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

I tried to build a rhel image using these elements with nodepool, but nodepool on centos-7 can't mount the image:

2019-04-11 20:48:03.036 | + /var/cache/nodepool/dib_tmp/dib_build.8PE6FTcg/hooks/bin/extract-image:extract_image:91 :   sudo mount -o nouui
d /dev/mapper/loop0p1 /tmp/tmp.agQ2y2guyI/mnt                                                                                             
2019-04-11 20:48:08.268 | mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/mapper/loop0p1,

Do you know how to fix this issue ?

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2019-04-16 19:11:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

@nhicher iiuc you can't mount rhel8 xfs on rhel7, for libguestfs you can use workaround I mentioned in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/643731/13/diskimage_builder/elements/rhel/README.rst@22

I remember there was a proposed reimplementation DIB long time ago to use libguestfs instead of direct loopback mounts... I'll try to dig that out."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-17 08:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

the problem is that this does not configure any repos.  I guess this is because the subscription-manager stuff in rhel-common element doesn't do anything.  I really have little clue about how we are supposed to interact with that at this point of the development cycle ... any ideas?"}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2019-04-18 06:54:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1

@Nir / others -- this has squashed Ife6405d5edc147439c661802db9b2f6cfec740c7 which has served it's purpose; there didn't seem to be any significant issues in review

I've honestly pretty much reached my experience limit with RHEL deployment at this point.  For me, this mounts, extracts, and builds an image based on the upstream rhel8 .qcow2.  This built image has no repos enabled and thus can do none of the useful stuff you'd actually use dib for like installing packages, etc.  We don't have any CI to work with nor any documented plan or test-driven development type effort.

I'm more than willing to help here, but I (and ideally another core reviewer) need some guidance to understand what comes next."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:25:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Published edit on patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-15 09:25:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-15 11:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2019-05-17 11:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Thanks for that! I actually need to consume it for security hardened images'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2019-05-17 11:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

Ah, also the DIB_RELEASE var looks confusing to me. DIB_RELEASE seems to mention the dib version number. We need something specific for RHEL, like RHEL_RELEASE'}, {'account_id': 30457, 'date': '2019-05-20 14:32:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2019-05-20 14:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the update of the repos! My comments on patchset 21 already remain.'}, {'account_id': 30457, 'date': '2019-05-20 14:44:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

> Uploaded patch set 22.

The patch is intended to make hosts registered to Satellite work. The repositories mentioned in rhel-common element refer specifically to rhel7 repositories.'}, {'account_id': 30457, 'date': '2019-05-20 14:54:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

> Thanks for the update of the repos! My comments on patchset 21
 > already remain.

I don't know if that is a trivial change. We have our in-house custom elements that reference DIB_RELEASE. I don't assume we're the only ones. Also other elements seem to cross reference DIB_RELEASE for their logic. DIB_RELEASE is a generic version holder for any OS at the moment.

A 'grep -Ri 'dib_release' . | wc -l' in the elements folder returns 152 entries.

Should there be a special variable just for Redhat based distros?"}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2019-05-20 15:00:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

You're right regarding DIB_RELEASE, sorry. So just the other comments apply."}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2019-05-22 08:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

Thanks Jean for working on it,
This patch is required for RHEL8 testing, can we get this merged?'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-22 09:42:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-22 09:42:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-22 11:53:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

> Uploaded patch set 22.

Thanks for updating the repository names.
where you able to test this?'}, {'account_id': 30457, 'date': '2019-05-22 12:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

> > Uploaded patch set 22.
 > 
 > Thanks for updating the repository names.
 > where you able to test this?

It works fine for me. My build points to Satellite, and I get the repos from there.'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2019-05-23 07:40:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-23 11:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Workflow-1

Tested this again, against a rhel8 cloud image: rhel-guest-image-8.0-1854.x86_64.qcow2   

Currently what I get is a failure to boot with: "Failed to mount /sysroot."
log: http://paste.openstack.org/show/751983/

Setting W-1, until we figure out why.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-05-24 06:45:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

Still, progress!

> Currently what I get is a failure to boot with: "Failed to mount /sysroot."

hrm, so that suggests the root filesystem can't be mounted.

what does "systemctl status sysroot.mount" if you jump on the console? (this might tell us if we're missing drivers or something in initramfs ... but it seems to have found the drive, so that's something)

what happens if you open the .qcow2 under guestfish; can you mount it all OK and explore the root fs (that would rule out it being corrupt)'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2019-05-24 07:00:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

I was hitting something similar, but it happened to me if i was using Centos 7/RHEL 7 as the os in the buildhost. If i do with fedora 29, or rhel 8 in the buildhost, i don't get any problem."}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-26 08:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

> Still, progress!
 > 
 > > Currently what I get is a failure to boot with: "Failed to mount
 > /sysroot."
 > 
 > hrm, so that suggests the root filesystem can't be mounted.
 > 
 > what does "systemctl status sysroot.mount" if you jump on the
 > console? (this might tell us if we're missing drivers or something
 > in initramfs ... but it seems to have found the drive, so that's
 > something)
 > 
 > what happens if you open the .qcow2 under guestfish; can you mount
 > it all OK and explore the root fs (that would rule out it being
 > corrupt)

The vnc console in my OpenStack cloud does not work for some reason, so I was not able to try.
Will try on a different cloud and report back.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-26 08:02:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

> I was hitting something similar, but it happened to me if i was
 > using Centos 7/RHEL 7 as the os in the buildhost. If i do with
 > fedora 29, or rhel 8 in the buildhost, i don't get any problem.

for build host I used fedora 30, I can/will try fedors29 - but even if it does end up working we should probably figure find the RCA, as this will break at some point in the future."}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-27 14:06:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

> Still, progress!
 > 
 > > Currently what I get is a failure to boot with: "Failed to mount
 > /sysroot."
 > 
 > hrm, so that suggests the root filesystem can't be mounted.
 > 
 > what does "systemctl status sysroot.mount" if you jump on the
 > console? (this might tell us if we're missing drivers or something
 > in initramfs ... but it seems to have found the drive, so that's
 > something)

I wasn't able to get to a prompt, so couldn't try it.

 > 
 > what happens if you open the .qcow2 under guestfish; can you mount
 > it all OK and explore the root fs (that would rule out it being
 > corrupt)

how does that look? http://paste.openstack.org/show/752109/'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-05-27 21:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

I tried building one myself but I faced the same boot problem. The problem appears to be because diskimage-builder creates an ext4 file system image (default). Instructing diskimage-builder to create an XFS file system (default in RHEL) makes the built image bootable. The buildhost was Fedora 30.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-05-28 07:28:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

Thanks Carlos; yeah I can confirm I got a boot with FS_TYPE=xfs ... @yolanda does that maybe map with your environment that it was specified sometimes?  

I think this is because the ext4 modules aren't built into the initramfs ... will investigate but I think we could do something just like error out unless FS_TYPE=xfs too for now"}, {'account_id': 30457, 'date': '2019-05-28 07:33:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

> (1 comment)

I am using RHEl7 as build environment. However, I am compiling python37 an creating a virtual env to build everything, so effectively bypassing all the system's python. I am also partitioning the image, to mount /boot on it's own, and the rest of the OS goes to a volume group with one logical volume, formatted with XFS. I am also adding the heat agents. Had to create a /usr/bin/python link inside the image to make them work. This is done using our inhouse element. The image boots fine on RHOS 10."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-05-28 07:39:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

Ian, I agree. Is there a reason for changing to ext4 on RHEL-based images? XFS is the default file system in RHEL. If there isn't one, maybe we could change the default file system to XFS in RHEL."}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-28 11:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-28 14:57:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-29 11:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-05-29 12:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

Tested Okay for me: 2019-05-29 10:03:34.262 | Build completed successfully

I was able to boot the image and use it as an Amphora service VM in Octavia.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-05-31 06:58:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks everyone for updates and reviewing here.  I feel like there's enough of us who have had builds of this going in various ways we can merge it.

Ideally before next dib release i'd like to figure out the ext4 thing so we're ok for centos8 with infra.  also hopefully yolanda and a few of the other users of advanced partitioning stuff can make sure we're good too."}]

[{'created': '2019-03-17 09:55:17.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add rhel element

Change-Id: I90540675c70bb475d9db2ae24f81c648a31f3f95
'}, {'created': '2019-03-17 10:41:05.000000000', 'message': "Add vesion-less  RHEL element for RHEL7 and RHEL8

Make a version-less RHEL element to handle both '7' and '8' DIB_RELEASE.

"}, {'created': '2019-05-15 08:02:10.000000000', 'message': "Add version-less RHEL element for RHEL7 and RHEL8

Make a version-less RHEL element to handle both '7' and '8' DIB_RELEASE.
The element usage should align with other elements which operate in the
same way such as the Fedora element.

Additionally, this patch adds support for RHEL8 that operates with
Python 3.
As of now, users of diskimage-builder will still be able to use the
'rhel7' element, or migrate to 'rhel' and specify their respective
DIB_RELEASE value.

* mount the xfs file-system for extraction as read-only.  vaguely
  based on explaination in [1] and the fact we only read the image
  data into a tar, so can ignore this.

    XFS (dm-1): Superblock has unknown read-only compatible features (0x4) enabled.

* Use the redhat system python as the dib-python version.  dib was
  ahead of it's time making an abstracted python interpreter for
  system work ;) the system python should work for running the various
  dib element scripts.

[1] https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/247550/unmountable-xfs-filesystem

Redhat-Bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1700253
Co-Authored-By: Ian Wienand <iwienand@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I90540675c70bb475d9db2ae24f81c648a31f3f95

commit_message:
Add version-less RHEL element for RHEL7 and RHEL8

Make a version-less RHEL element to handle both '7' and '8' DIB_RELEASE.
The element usage should align with other elements which operate in the
same way such as the Fedora element.

Additionally, this patch adds support for RHEL8 that operates with
Python 3.
As of now, users of diskimage-builder will still be able to use the
'rhel7' element, or migrate to 'rhel' and specify their respective
DIB_RELEASE value.

* mount the xfs file-system for extraction as read-only.  vaguely
  based on explaination in [1] and the fact we only read the image
  data into a tar, so can ignore this.

    XFS (dm-1): Superblock has unknown read-only compatible features (0x4) enabled.

* Use the redhat system python as the dib-python version.  dib was
  ahead of it's time making an abstracted python interpreter for
  system work ;) the system python should work for running the various
  dib element scripts.

[1] https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/247550/unmountable-xfs-filesystem

Redhat-Bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1700253
Co-Authored-By: Ian Wienand <iwienand@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I90540675c70bb475d9db2ae24f81c648a31f3f95

commit_message:
The columns out of page range

Too many columns in the table, resulting in out of page range,
affecting the appearance.
Some information can be seen on the details page,
I think it can be deleted from the table.

Change-Id: Id3b45726f14087088767c5171b14fd8ec12da9ef

This is a slightly more accurate naming of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE
whic is still supported.

commit_message:
Changing import in driver class for nova_powervm

This change set is to correct the import statement in driver
class - os_resource_classes now provides cpu, ram and disk
keys instead of rc_fields class.

Change-Id: I1e2993aafb64920729fc87081bdd9337a81b1b6f

subject: feat: Adds workflow input dict Chinese parameter support
messages:
[{'account_id': 30524, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:00:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30524, 'date': '2019-05-31 07:09:08.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

Change-Id: If78607ddb6c8c99075cfe4ca902e36a2dbd1e31a
Closes-Bug: #1830827

commit_message:
Add karma-subunit-reporter

This adds a new karma plugin, 'karma-subunit-reporter', to generate
subunit streams for unit test output. These files should be compatible
with stackviz itself (via stackviz-export) and other tools like
subunit2sql and openstack-health.

Change-Id: I8ee5425e1688fa090d5dc9fe3021345e779e2c07

[1]https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/global-requirements.txt#L457'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2019-05-17 06:51:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi zhangboye. It should be fixed in the requirement repo. Thanks for pointing that out. I will submit a fix.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2019-05-31 02:14:50.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow+1 by Trinh Nguyen <dangtrinhnt@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Cap sphinx for py2 to match global requirements

We will still support py3.4 for now.

Change-Id: I31c8d3b244b93fd7d1731bc79dab6727aa2581ea

commit_message:
Handle 403 response when update image attribute

The part of angularjs code catch an HTTP 403 response and redirect
to logout, convert it to 404 response.

Change-Id: Iaf28306df7e1d77ee64501adee07a932c72c560c
Closes-Bug: #1818659

Change-Id: If2ee15f1e0fcf6d077cba524fad75dec7e1144b6
'}, {'created': '2019-05-24 12:45:56.000000000', 'message': "Fix haproxy stats network binding

a) The haproxy.stats stanza in haproxy config file has pretty much remained the same since newton:
listen haproxy.stats
  bind 192.168.24.8:1993 transparent
  mode http
  stats enable
  stats uri /
  stats auth admin:tRJre6PnQuN4ZwqKYUygTJArB

b) what we do today with the haproxy stats makes little sense:
- we bind it to the VIP running on the control-plane network on all controller nodes
- de facto we allow to look at the haproxy stat info via web only on the node holding the ctlplane VIP
- since haproxy does not share stats across nodes, we're effectively
  limited at looking at the stats info on a single node.

Now imagine ctrl-0 holding the internal_api VIP and ctrl-1 holding the
ctlplane VIP. Basically now the only stats you will be able to see are
the ones relative to keystone_admin (which for other silly reasons has
been moved to ctlplane by default) and very little else.

Tested this and am able to bind the haproxy stat to another network
and to have it listen to the IP of the node on said network (in addition
to the ctrlplane vip which we do not remove as it might break stuff):

    listen haproxy.stats
      bind fd00:fd00:fd00:2000::16:1993 transparent
      bind 192.168.24.15:1993 transparent
      mode http
      stats enable
      stats uri /
      stats auth admin:password

Closes-Bug: #1830334

Depends-On: Iab5f11c3065ff34a3543621554e7f05161d069f2

Change-Id: If2ee15f1e0fcf6d077cba524fad75dec7e1144b6
"}]
commit_message:
Fix haproxy stats network binding

a) The haproxy.stats stanza in haproxy config file has pretty much remained the same since newton:
listen haproxy.stats
  bind 192.168.24.8:1993 transparent
  mode http
  stats enable
  stats uri /
  stats auth admin:tRJre6PnQuN4ZwqKYUygTJArB

b) what we do today with the haproxy stats makes little sense:
- we bind it to the VIP running on the control-plane network on all controller nodes
- de facto we allow to look at the haproxy stat info via web only on the node holding the ctlplane VIP
- since haproxy does not share stats across nodes, we're effectively
  limited at looking at the stats info on a single node.

Now imagine ctrl-0 holding the internal_api VIP and ctrl-1 holding the
ctlplane VIP. Basically now the only stats you will be able to see are
the ones relative to keystone_admin (which for other silly reasons has
been moved to ctlplane by default) and very little else.

Tested this and am able to bind the haproxy stat to another network
and to have it listen to the IP of the node on said network (in addition
to the ctrlplane vip which we do not remove as it might break stuff):

    listen haproxy.stats
      bind fd00:fd00:fd00:2000::16:1993 transparent
      bind 192.168.24.15:1993 transparent
      mode http
      stats enable
      stats uri /
      stats auth admin:password

Closes-Bug: #1830334

Depends-On: Iab5f11c3065ff34a3543621554e7f05161d069f2

Change-Id: If2ee15f1e0fcf6d077cba524fad75dec7e1144b6

commit_message:
Update handling for falcon 2.0.0 behavior changes

The 2.0.0 release of falcon changed the default values for two request
query parsing options that would cause failures due to unexpected
results. This sets those options to their previous defaults to maintain
compatibility across 2.0.0 and pre-2.0.0 versions of the package.
Lower constraint version raised to 1.1.0 where the options were
introduced.

There are additional integration test failures with Falcon 2.0.0 that
were due to changes in the subscription URL path.

Change-Id: I4aa18510cc11827c2ef478bf4ca6bd1baa9878e4

commit_message:
Add refactored summary page with tests

This commit adds a (p)react/redux-refactored summary page and dataset
service. The components added here should be roughly at feature parity
with the current implementation, except where they might depend on
other components that have not yet been implemented (for example,
links to the timeline page). Unit tests have also been added in the
'test-refactor' directory.

These components should be considered a viable basis for the remainder
of the refactoring process; for more information, see:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/stackviz-refactor

Change-Id: I4f43a6b719ba0493cb8409767e555eed9d4f254d

commit_message:
Ensure openstack clients are installed

We need to ensure the openstack clients are installed on controllers for
the deployed server case. This should be handled by the overcloud images
themselves, however if the images are not used we should make sure the
clients get installed with our OpenstackClients service.

Change-Id: If7fad9f24c7294c2d749fc3838b1fb71182930fc
Related-Bug: #1829769

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-30 01:28:05.000000000', 'message': 'Run collectd socket cleanup on container start

This patch enables collectd deleting /var/run/collect-socket on startup.
It is created for monitoring purposes and on some conditions is created
by health check script sooner than collectd starts, which results on collect
failing to create the socket and listening on it.

Change-Id: I9fed91255f6857ac39a68278fb2c036606d88468
Closes-Bug: #1807683
(cherry picked from commit 36cfba38f8cf70e56fe039933d0ca844655ba20d)
'}]
commit_message:
Run collectd socket cleanup on container start

This patch enables collectd deleting /var/run/collect-socket on startup.
It is created for monitoring purposes and on some conditions is created
by health check script sooner than collectd starts, which results on collect
failing to create the socket and listening on it.

Change-Id: I9fed91255f6857ac39a68278fb2c036606d88468
Closes-Bug: #1807683
(cherry picked from commit 36cfba38f8cf70e56fe039933d0ca844655ba20d)

Pin ARA to <1.0.0

ARA 1.0 will be released in the near future and isn't backwards
compatible. Pin it so it doesn't break things unexpectedly.

Change-Id: Ifec1bebaa3fe6d6cce02fc4f36de1dcdf7c79ff3

Upstream is switching to xz so we need to be able to support it.

commit_message:
Remove zeromq from getting started with compute docs

ZeroMQ driver is deprecated, as per the Dublin 2018 PTG decision:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128055.html

This change simply replaces the zeromq mention with a link to the
other oslo.messaging drivers.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I0c8d488c1daecc71d7d2817ffb4ae10727771d19

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-28 16:40:45.000000000', 'message': 'Utility container is missing the shade library

Some service set up tasks use ansible modules that rely on shade.
When using a utility container as a service setup host these tasks
will fail if shade is not installed to the utility container.

Added shade to the list of pip packages installed to the container.

Change-Id: I25a89ed706cad0ae3376c466807f3ba024941c2a
Closes-Bug: #1830028
'}, {'created': '2019-05-28 17:05:22.000000000', 'message': 'Utility container venv is missing python libs for openstack ansible modules

Some service set up tasks use ansible modules that require external
python libraries. When using a utility container as a service setup host
these ansible tasks will fail if the required libraries are not present
in the utility venv.

Added shade to the list of pip packages installed to the container, as
required for ansible 2.5 / Rocky.

Change-Id: I25a89ed706cad0ae3376c466807f3ba024941c2a
Closes-Bug: #1830028
'}, {'created': '2019-05-29 08:28:43.000000000', 'message': 'Utility container venv is missing python libs for ansible openstack modules

Some service set up tasks use ansible modules that require external
python libraries. When using a utility container as a service setup host
these ansible tasks will fail if the required libraries are not present
in the utility venv.

Added shade to the list of pip packages installed to the container, as
required for ansible 2.5 / Rocky.

(manual cherry pick from commit 79bea6ef1f514395360bab040801a2edd3e78a33)
Change-Id: I25a89ed706cad0ae3376c466807f3ba024941c2a
Closes-Bug: #1830028
'}]
commit_message:
Utility container venv is missing python libs for ansible openstack modules

Some service set up tasks use ansible modules that require external
python libraries. When using a utility container as a service setup host
these ansible tasks will fail if the required libraries are not present
in the utility venv.

Added shade to the list of pip packages installed to the container, as
required for ansible 2.5 / Rocky.

(manual cherry pick from commit 79bea6ef1f514395360bab040801a2edd3e78a33)
Change-Id: I25a89ed706cad0ae3376c466807f3ba024941c2a
Closes-Bug: #1830028

commit_message:
Pin ARA to <1.0.0

ARA 1.0 will be released in the near future and isn't backwards
compatible. Pin it so it doesn't break things unexpectedly.

Change-Id: I8c29f04b7505bd3571928af9fa8c98f6f2ecd56b
(cherry picked from commit 34ba3c5a50ba0a80cd2179cbd716baa488d82635)

[{'created': '2019-04-11 14:38:01.000000000', 'message': "Remove amp_hw_arch from octavia_post

This patch is a followup to this[1] change.

The reasons for removing amp_hw_arch from octavia_post:
1. In stable/queens, we break since we don't feed ansible with any
value.
2. We don't support or ship an Amphora image that is non-x86_64.The
purpose of specifying the arch is (as stated here[1]) to hint the Nova
scheduler which compute nodes to take into account when it schedules
an Amphora instance.

Closes-Bug: #1824368

commit_message:
Remove amp_hw_arch from octavia_post

This patch is a followup to this[1] change.

The reasons for removing amp_hw_arch from octavia_post:
1. In stable/queens, we break since we don't feed ansible with any
value.
2. We don't support or ship an Amphora image that is non-x86_64.The
purpose of specifying the arch is (as stated here[1]) to hint the Nova
scheduler which compute nodes to take into account when it schedules
an Amphora instance.

Closes-Bug: #1824368

[1] Ia7be6503a40e08d0d1f7f4d89132c9e9b5bd6704
Change-Id: I36a851397a0adeadc3216656c96c58f8668fd7fc
(cherry picked from commit e2b67d33cf59464bf82e07e247f45c6b96f2bb6c)
(cherry picked from commit b1676eac87147096e76f4317226336411ffdf819)

commit_message:
Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: Iff8425e2aff37a35432202d9912b7bd00ddcd761

commit_message:
Fix monasca agent for leap 15

This ensures vars are properly loaded for Leap 15.
In order to test this actively, we'll rely on the integrated
jobs.

Change-Id: I08abf1796b0c4dc7b68dfe89795f59086113cfbf

commit_message:
Update openstack.org -> opendev.org

It updates the url from git.openstack.org to opendev.org and
also remove cgit from opendev.org.

Keeping vagrantfile, run_tests.sh and bindep.txt as itis
as these are updated automatically by openstack-ansible-tests.

Change-Id: Ia449079776e0339515ae1a2bca7553b03d9cde1c
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar <chkumar@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-25 14:26:46.000000000', 'message': 'Use py37

This commit makes to use python3.7 instead of python2.7 in postinstall
since python2.7 will be EOL soon. And, this commit encourages to use
py37 task instead of py27 as well.

Change-Id: I75f0045e88d20d04ecbcdc798bcf3f45d2c27e7a
'}, {'created': '2019-05-25 14:49:45.000000000', 'message': 'Use py37

This commit makes to use python3.7 instead of python2.7 in postinstall
since python2.7 will be EOL soon. And, this commit encourages to use
py37 task instead of py27 as well.
And also this commit changes to use node8 to test in the upstream gate.

Change-Id: I75f0045e88d20d04ecbcdc798bcf3f45d2c27e7a
'}, {'created': '2019-05-25 15:06:44.000000000', 'message': 'Use py36

This commit makes to use python3.6 instead of python2.7 in postinstall
since python2.7 will be EOL soon. And, this commit encourages to use
py36 task instead of py27 as well.
And also this commit changes to use node8 to test in the upstream gate.

Change-Id: I75f0045e88d20d04ecbcdc798bcf3f45d2c27e7a

commit_message:
Use py36

This commit makes to use python3.6 instead of python2.7 in postinstall
since python2.7 will be EOL soon. And, this commit encourages to use
py36 task instead of py27 as well.
And also this commit changes to use node8 to test in the upstream gate.

Change-Id: I75f0045e88d20d04ecbcdc798bcf3f45d2c27e7a

commit_message:
Group instance methods together in nova_helper

Some of the methods for retrieving data about instances was placed
at the bottom of nova_helper instead of being close to the other
instance based methods.

commit_message:
Improve exceptions and logging in ds manager

MetricNotAvailable and NoDatasourceAvailable allow to differentiate
between having no datasources configured and a required metric being
unavailable from the datasource. Both exceptions have comments so
that the use case is clear.

The input validation of the get_backend method in the datasource
manager is improved.

Additional logging information allows to identify which metric caused
the available datasource to be discarded.

Tests are updated to validate the correct functionality of the new
exceptions.

Change-Id: I512976cce2401dbcd249d42686b78843e111a0e7

messages:
[{'account_id': 28185, 'date': '2019-05-10 01:39:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-05-10 01:39:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-05-22 19:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-05-31 00:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
